THE SECOND PART OF SYMBOLEOGRAPHY, Newly corrected and amended, and very much
enlarged in all the four several Treatises. 1. Of Fines and Concordes. 2. Of
Common Recoueries. 3. Of Offenses and Indictments. 4. Of Compromises and
Arbitrements.
Whereunto is annexed another Treatise of Equity, the Jurisdiction, and
Proceedings of the high Court of Chauncerye: Of Supplications, Bills, and
Aunsweres, And of certain Writs and Commissions issuing thence, and there also
retornable: Likewise much augmented with diverse presidents, very necessary for
the same purpose, beginning at the 144. Section, and continuing to the end of
Bills and Aunsweres. Hereunto is also added a Table for the more easy and ready
finding of the matters herein contained: the new additions having therein this
mark set before them.

Ingenij cibus studium, studijque diligentia. AT LONDON Printed by Thomas
Wight. ANNO DO. 1601.

Cum Priuilegio Regiae Maiestatis.

Viro Iurisprudentiae and pietatis laud illustristrissimo EDVVARDO COKE
Armigero, serenissimae Reginae Maiestatis Procuratori summo, WILL. WEST veram
exoptat foelicitatem.
OVum ijs fere omnibus, qui lucubrationes suas de aliquo disciplinae genere in
publicum proferunt, in more positum esse videtur (vir illustrissime) vt in
Epistolis suis nuncupatorijs duo potissimum sequantur: vnum vt illum ipsum,
cuius patrocinio niti statnunt, dignis laudibus efferant; alterum, vt operas
ipsas grato encomio afficiant: erunt fortasse nonnulli, qui idem a me faciendum
arbitrabuntur; a quibus tamen ego long diuersum sentio. Vtrumque enim vt
vellem maxim certe non possem: Nam ab hoc, ingenioli mei tenuitas: ab illo,
pudor quidem ingenitus me remoratur. Et vero, si in lauds tuas excurrerem
longius, vereor, vt and ipse hoc non patereris, Et ego, cum corporis, tum animi
dotium, quas natura affatim in te quasieffudisse videtur, multitudine obrutus,
neque quid prae ceteris dicendum, neque quomodo finis faciendus sit, facile
reperire possem: sieve de eximia iuris nostri scientia, sieve de singulari
pietate tua dixero, quas in te (vir ornatissime) aetas etiamnum integra, tam
mature nobis exhibuit, vt ad quasuis respraeclaras gerendas, non factus, sed
natus, esse videaris. Quarum veluti suffragijs ad praeclaramunera iamdudum
euectus, alijsque, etiam grandaeuis, praelatussis. Sed quidquid ipse de te
dixero, dicturus illud sum tenuius, minusque splendide, quam dici debuisset,
and rei dignitas postularet. Itaque maluisilere, ac singulares illas animi,
corporisque tui dotes suspicere, quam nihil dicendo, infantiam meam prodere. De
opella autem mea gloriosius dicere nihil attinet: Illius enim argumentum
eiusmodi est, vt nullius adeo commendatione magnopere egere videatur, quippe
quodde ijs rebus tractat, quae ad pacem and concordiam, cum constituendam, tum
restituendam, spectant maxim: sieve enim, tractatum primum de finibus: sieve
alterum illum de recuperationibus, quae dicuntur: sieve tertium de criminibus
and accusationibus inde oriundis: sieve postremum de compromissis and arbitrijs,
contempleris, nihil aliud, quam quietem and tranquillitatem humanae societatis,
spirare videntur omnia. Nam arbitria, lites, easque suscitatas, leuiter
componunt: fines and recuperationes, dominia and proprietates firmant:
accusationes, nocentum peccata detegunt, vt nocentes ipsi vel sanentur, vele
medio tollantur, ne istorum virus proximos quosque vel conficiat vel inficiat.
Et certe haud scio, an pace quicquam augustius ad veram singulorum felicitatem
excogitari poterit, illa namque nobiscum commorante omnibus bonis ac commodis
abundamus, atque ex animi sententia succedunt omnia. At si dulcissima eius
consuetudine priuemur, eaque a nobis exulet, statim bello, omnibus malis atque
aerumnis expositi, vitam long miserimam ducimus. Modum autem, quo haec
tractaui, laudare, meum non est. Quod si enim is eiusmodi est, qui tibi,
alijsque bonis, and doctis viris placeat, satis per se ipsum commendatus erit:
sin minus, vana rei non probandae commendatio, ipsam laudabiliorem non
efficiet. De animo autem meo, hoc tua pace libere effari libet, voluisse me
prodesse quamplurimis, ijs autem praecipue, qui prima iuris nostri tyrocinia
exercent. Quod vt melius praestare possem, ista volui qualicunque methodo: cum
profecto nulla mihi videatur dicendi ars alia nisi methodus, quae a prioribus
natura, ad proxima: quae a notioribus, ad minus nota: quae a generalibus, ad
specialia: quae a finitis, ad infinita: quaeque ita demum ab instituto aliquo
genere ad media, tum definiendo, tum diuidendo, transit, donec tandem in
exemplorum infinitate consistat, quam quidem disponendi rationem tibi (vir
ornatissime) non ingratam fore confido, cum omnes tuae disputationes, atque
adeo dicta omnia, illam ipsam suauissime semper spirare videntur. Te igitur
horum maecenatem rogo, pro genuina and laudatissima illa tua in rem literariam,
literatosque omnes promouendi, promptitudine, and verae pacis amore singulari,
acerrimoque tuo in delicta odio, si alia reipublicae grauiora negotia non
impediant, hunc libellum cognoscere, suscipere, ac tueri velis; quo mihi animos
ad haec augenda and perpolienda, and hijs maiora alacriter aggredienda, addas.
Te (vir iurisconsultissime) aeternae pacis author, ad sui nominis gloriam,
ecclesiae commodum, and reipublicae tranquillitatem, quam diutissime seruet
incolumem:

Ex aedibus meis Firbectiensibus haud long a Doncastria burgo, in agro
Eboracensi, postridie calendas Maias; Anno salutis per Christi solius sanguinem
restitutae. 1594. Tibi deditissimus, WILHELMVS WEST.

SYMBOLEOGRAPHY Of Fines and Concordes.
The definition of Fines.
FOrasmuch as we have already in our first part Sect. 1.
of Symboleography showed the form of diverse Conditions and Covenants, as well
for the leuying of Fines of lands and tenementes, as also to raise and limit
the uses thereof: It now seems necessary to show how the Notes of writs of
Covenants and Concordes for Fines, with other necessary circumstances
concerning the same are to be made. Wherefore let us first learn what, and how
worthy things Fines be.

Tremayle 21. E. fol. 4. terms Fines, covenants made before Justices,

Brown says, Fines be fructus, exitus, and finis effectus Legis, Plow.

Glanuil in his eight book and first chapter terms a Fine Amicabilis And
Bracton tractatu quinto Lib. 5. ca. 28. Sect. 7. de Exceptionibus says, finis
ideo dicitur finalis concordia, quia imponit finem litibus, and est exceptio
peremptoria.

And Glanuil cap. 3. Lib. 9. says, Talis concordia finalis dicitur, eo

In which books may be seen thauncient form of leuying Fines and Plow. fol.
357. a. 368. b. which without question were long before the Conquest.

So that Fines having their commencement of Record long before Plow. 357. a.
368. b.

But chiefly we are to consider their effects, which be to make certeintie

As appears by the Statute* de Finibus 27. Edw. 1. Stat. 1. cap. 1. Quia
fines in Curia nostra leuati finem litibus imponere debent, and imponunt: Ideo
fines voca^tur maxim cum post Duellum and magnam Assisam in suo casu vltimum
locum finalem teneant imperpetuum: with which Statute agrees Bracton tractatu
5. Lib. 5. cap. 28. Sect. 7. de Exceptionibus.

And therefore by thauncient law, Fine and Nonclaime by the space Ed. 3. cap.
16.

And at this day Fines be of great force, puissance, and worthiness: 4. H. 7.
cap. 24. 1. R. 3. cap. 7. 32. H. 8. cap. 36. and 31. Eliz. Reg. cap. 2. They
are final ends, and sufficiently conclude, bar, and discharge for ever
as well parties and priuies as estrangers to the same, except women covert
(other then been parties to the fines) and every other person at the time of
the leuying of the same fine being within the age of xxi. years, or in prison,
or out of the Realm, or of unsound mind, and not parties to such fines: Saving
unto estrangers to such fines such right, title, claim, and interest, as they
have to the teneme^ts therein contained at the time of thingrossing thereof: so
that they pursue the same by action, or lawful entry within five years next
after proclamations thereupon made according to the said statutes: And saving
to all other persons such action, right, title, claim, and interest, in, or to
the tenements in such fines mentioned, as first shall grow, remain, descend,
or come to them after the said fine engrossed and proclamations made, by force
of any cause or matter had or made before the said fine levied: so that they
pursue their action, right, or title within five years next after that it is
to them accrued.

By which authorities we gather that fines are nothing else, but Instruments 20.
Ass. p. 1. 26. Ass. p. 37. Dyer fol. 179. Plow. fol. 146.
of record of agreements concerning lands, tenements, or hereditaments, duly
made by the Queens consent and license, and knowledged by the parties to the
same upon a writ of Covenant, a writ of Right, a writ of Customs and Services,
Warrantia chartae thereof, or such like, before the Justices of the Common
place, or others thereunto authorized, and engrossed of record in the same
Court, to end all controversies thereof both between themselves which be
parties and priuies to the same, and all estrangers not suing or clayming in
due time.

These Fines destroy estates tail, (other then such as be made by the 32. H.
8. ca. 36. And other then fines of lands restrained from alienation by act of
parliament, 32. H. 8. cap. 36. Or levied by an Intrudor of lands seized into
the kings hands, as by an heir which holds in Capite before Livery sued 1.
H. 7. ca. 5. for by the Praerogatiue cap. 13. by his entry he gayneth no
freehold.) And in time become perpetual bars against all men, end strife,
make peace, breed security and tranquillity, which is the very fruit,
effect, and end of all godly Laws.

Of the parties to fines.
IN every Fine two things are principally to be regarded, the persons, Sect. 2.
and the action.

Persons chiefly regarded in fines be the

Parties to the fines be the Cognizor and the Cognizee, which are

The Cognizor is he which does knowledge the fine.

The Cognizee is he to whom the fine is levied.

In the parties 3. things are specially to be regarded: Their Capacities, and
Estates.

Touching the Capacity of the Cognizor it is to be considered whether

What persons may be Cognizors, and what not?
ALl persons male and female may be Cognizors, but such as are prohibited Sect.
3*
that to do by nature or law.

By nature through defect of the nund, or of the body, but no longer

This defect of the mind is either natural or casual.

Of Infancy.
DEfects of the mind by nature is by age which is of Infants, Sect. 4.
that is persons under thage of xxi. years, as by Ideocy which ought not to be
Cognizors, because the law intends they want understanding and discretion
what to do in this behalf: Yet if a fine be levied by an Infant, it cannot be
reuersed but by himself by writ of Error during his infancy, that the Court
may see him and thereby judge his age, 50. E. 3. 5. 17. E. 3. 52. and 78.

Impediments of the mind casual such as affect, are furious mad 17. E. 3. 5.
and 78. 17. Ass. 17.

Defects of the body.
DEfects of the body be such infirmities thereof by which the principal Sect.
5.
senses necessary for understanding and to declare their consents are wanting:
Of which sort be such as are blind, deaf, or dumb, naturally.

But persons blind, deaf, or dumb accidentally may make cognizance

Impediments legal or civil.
Legal impediments be when such persons be prohibited by law as Sect. 6.
by nature are able to levy fines.

And they are either by reason of subjection or joint power.

Of legal subjection.
Subjection legal is when persons be under the rule of others, as a Sect. 7.
feme covert to her husband, 2. H. 5. 9. E. 3. 28. A villein to his Lord 33. E.
3. Persons ciuilly dead, as Friars, Nuns, Monks, Channons professed, and
other like supersticious votaries, who are in subjection to their Sovereigns,
14. H. 8. 16. 2. R. 2. 5.

Of couerture.
ANd therefore a feme covert within age ought not to levy a fine, Sect. 8.
for that she cannot reuerse it during the couerture, nor after if the
couerture continue till she be of full age, 50. E. 3. 5. 27. Ass. pla. 53.

And a feme covert ought not to levy a fine but with her right husband, 7. H.
4. 23. 42. E. 3. 20.

But a fine levied by a feme covert without her husband of her own 17. E. 3.
52. and 78. 17. Ass. 17. 7. H. 4. 23. But if living her first husband she take
a second husband, and with him and by his name knowledge a fine, this fine
shall not bind her, because she is misnamed, 7. H. 4. 22. and 23. Yet if she
with her right husband by a wrong christian name levy a fine, she is estopped
during her life, ^. Ass. pla. 11. Brook Fines 117.

A feme covert must beware how she with her husband do levy a fine Trin. 19.
Eliz. Dyer fol. 359. pla 49.

Neither ought the husband without his wife to levy any fine of her 28. 12. E.
4. 12. 42. E. 3. 20.

Villeines.
ANd Villeines by knowledging such fines should prejudice their Sect. 9.
Lords, thereby bereauing them of the lands aliened, for such fines be good.

Persons dead in law.
ANd fines levied by persons ciuilly dead are utterly void. Sect. 10.


Imprisonment.
ANd if men compelled by threatenings or inprisonment should be Sect. 11.
admitted to levy fines, they should thereby be barred, because the law
intends such persons are at liberty when they knowledge fines 17. E. 3. 52.
78. 17. Ass. 17.

Of persons having joint power.
PErsons prohibited to be Cognizors by reason of joint power, are Sect. 12.
they that have joint power and authority with others, as the single members
of every Corporation or Society, As a Bishop without his Deane and Chapter, A
Deane without his Chapter, An Abbot or Prior without his Covent, A Parson,
Vicar, Prebendary, or Chauntry priest without their Ordinary, A Mayor without
his Cominaltie, Masters of colleges without their Fellows, And of other
Societies incorporate, may not levy fines, Plow. 375. b. 11. Elizab. fol. 538.
a 21. Eliz. 21. E. 4. 13. 11. H. 4. 68. 12. H. 4. 11. and 12. 38. E. 3. 33.
Plow. fol. 538. a. 20. Eliz.

Of the estates of Cognizors.
ALbeit every fine be good to bind the parties, yet for the validity Sect. 13.
of the fine it is convenient that either the Cognizor or the Cognizee be
seized of the lands aliened, 41. E. 3. 14. 22. H. 6. 13.

For the fine is void if neither of the parties be seized at the leuying 41. E.
3. 14. 33. H. 6. 18. 3. H. 6. 27. 27. H. 8. 4. and 20. 37. H. 6. 34. 13. Ass.
p. 8. 3. H. 7. 9. 5. E. 3. 22. H. 6. 57.

Yet the vouchee after he has entered into the warrantie may leuy a 8. H. 4. 5.
5. H. 7. 40.

Persons attained or wayued in personal actions may alien by fine 9. H. 6. 20.
21. H. 7. 7.

And persons attainted of Felony or Treason may not be Cognizors, 8. Ass. pla.
25. for their estats remain in them during their lives.

Also tenant for life may levy a fine sur grant and releas of the lands 44.
E. 3. 36. But if the estate were larger, or the fine sur cognizance de droit
come ceo que etc. it were a forfeiture of his estate, 4. H. 7. fol.

The same law is of such sins by tenant in tail after possibility, tenant 39.
E. 3. 16. But such fine of a re^t seems to be no forfeiture, 2. H. 5. 7. Yet
a particular tenant, as in dower, by courtesy, or for life, cannot by fine
grant and surrender their estates to thowner of the reuersion or remainder,
but may by fine grant and releas the same, 17. E. 3. 62. 24. E. 3. 26. 20. E.
3. and 14. E. 3.

A tenant in commen or Iointenant may levy a fine of his part, 26. H. 8. 9.

So may a Coparcener of his part, Dyer 334. plac. 30. Pasch. 16.

A fine levied by the heir who is an Intrudor upon the kings possession per le
Praerog. cap. 13. 1. H. 7. 5. 24. E. 3. 65. But if such fine be levied without
intrusion, it binds the Cognizor and his heirs, 1. H. 7. 5.

If a disseisor levy a fine with proclamation, and the disseisee within Plowd.
fol. 353. 11. Elizab. inter Stowell and Zouch.

Also fines may be levied by the tenant in tail general, or special, And

Having thus passed the capacities and estates of Cognizors,

How Cognizors are to be named.
TOuching the names whereby parties to fines ought to be named, Sect. 14.
for so much as names be to no other end inserted into fines and other
writings, then that it may be certainly known, who be the parties thereunto,
it is requisite that they be certainly named by their right names of baptism
and surnames, whether the same be King, Prince, Duke, Marquess, Earl, Vicont,
Baron, Lord, or Knight, which be names of dignity, (some of which are
sometimes named without their Surnames: as Georg. Comes Salop^ without his
surname, Iohe^s Dux Lancastr^,) or he be an Esquire or Gentleman, which be
names of worship, nobility, and honor, 14. H. 6. 15. 21. E. 4. 84.

Whose addicions nevertheless of courtesy are communly used in as Archbishop,
Bishop, Archdeacon, Deane, Parson, Vicar, Clerk, etc. Or any Corporation, or
body civil, politic, or corporate, having covent or common seal: as
Baylife and Burgesses, Mayor and Comminaltie, or any other fraternity or
brotherhood, 11. H. 4. 44. 12. H. 4. 20. 14. H. 4. 21. 7. H. 6. 27.

And albeit it be not necessary always in fines to give the parties 37. H. 6.
29. 47. E. 3. 16.

What persons may be Cognizees in fines, and secondly by what names they must
be named.
ALl such persons as may be grauntees or take contracts, may be Sect. 15.


And if a fine be levied to a feme covert, she needs not to be examined, 3.
H. 6. 42. 41. E. 3. 7. 50. E. 3. 9. 24. E. 3. 62.

Neither shall an Infant being cognizee (...) 24. E. 3. 62. because 1. H. 7.
fol. 5.

And an Abbot, Deane and Chapter, Mayor and Cominaltie, and such quod
permittant finem illum leuari, 5. H. 7. 25. 19. H. 6. 25. A Prior may be
cognizee, 22. E. 4. 15. E. 4. 22.

But persons ciuilly dead, as Monks, Channons, and Friars, can not 5. H. 7.
25. 19. H. 6. 25. By what names.


2 Cognizees in fines must be named by their right proper names and surnames:
for a fine being levied to A. and Sibell his wife, (where her Christian name
was Isabell) was holden void. 1. Ass. pla. 1. See the Section how the Cognizors
are to be named, and that will satisfy you for the naming of Cognizees.

Before what persons Fines may be knowledged.
Having thus perused the capacities, estates, and names of cognizors Sect. 16.


And others at the time of the Concord.

And Judges of the cognizances, are such persons as have power to

All or two of the Justices of the Common place may in open court 15. E. 2. cap.

And the chief Justice of the Common place, by the privilege and Dedimus
potestatem, Dyer fol. 224. pla. 31.

And it seems by the Statute 15. E. 2. that if the parties be not able
Dedimus potestatem to enable them thereunto. But this course is long sithence
discontinued.

And it seems that ^^stices of Assizes by the general words of Dedimus
potestatem for the words be in effect as follows, that is to say: Necnon ad
recipiend' omnes fines, concordias, and recognitiones in circuitu suo,
coniunctim and diuisim recognit^ pro illa vice in circuituillo, non ob^lante
aliquo actu, statuto, sieve ordinatione in contrarium etc.

Yet such Justices use not now to certify them without a special Dedimus
potestatem, sued forth of the Chauncery, directed unto them, and giving them
thereby power, to take and certify such cognizances as they have already
taken, Dyer fol. 224. plac. 51. 5. Eliz. ^. H. 7. 9. And fines have been
levied before Justices Errants, Lib. Intrac' titulo Scire fac' in Aid 2.

Of a Dedimus potestatem de Fine leuando.
A Special commission for a fine is a writ of Dedimus potestatem directed Sect*
17.
Dedimus potestatem must contain the substance of the writ of Covenant, and
recite that it is thereof depending between the parties bearing Test after
the writ of Covenant, which writ of Dedimus potestatem ought to be directed to
men of good credit and conscience, and exptert in the laws, who must certify
the same with the cognisances to the Justices of the common Plees, as shall be
showed hereafter. And every such Dedimus potestatem to a special commission
must be signed by the Lord Chancellor, or Lord Keeper, and Lord chief Justice
of the common plees, or by some of the Justices of the circuit where the land
lies.

But now many writs of Dedimus potestatem to take knowledge of Error have bin
brought, because fines have bin knowledged by Dedimus potestatem before such as
were neither Judge, Abbot, Knight, nor Seriant at the law, And therefore such
recognisances have bin refused, Br. Fines 120.

A Justice or other person being cognisee in a fine, may not take cognizance 8.
H. 6. 21.

And when any cognizance of fines is taken, it seems convenient, Dyer fol.
320. P. 19. H. 15. Eliz.

And now by a late order, all fines taken by Dedimus potestatem by him that is
not Justice of Assise in that circuit where the la^d lies, must be signed by a
Justice of that circuit, Dyer fol. 220. pla. 15. The form of the Dedimus
potestate^ appears amongst the adjuncts of concords.

Judges, to whom cognisances are to be certified, and before whom they are to
be recorded.
IVdges for the recording of fines by the Justices of the common plees Sect* 18.
15. E. 2. cap. And therefore as is said, all cognisances thereof must be
certified thither, for in that Court only all fines are to be levied,
Notwithstanding 36. H. 6. 34.

And by special grant a fine may be levied in a base Court, 44. Ed.

But fines levied in Ancient demesne by any custom seem void, 44. E. 3. 38.
And so in other inferior Courts, 50. Ass. pl. 9.

Also by the statute of 2. E. 6. ca. 28. fines may beleuied in the county

And by 37. H. 8. cap. 19. fines may be levied of lands in the County

And by the statute of 5. Eliz. cap. 27. fines may be levied within the

Having thus r^n over the discourse of the persons used in fines,

Of the division of fines.
EVery fine therefore is either witohut proclamations, or with proclamations.
Sect* 19. Fines divided.


At this day a fine without proclamation, which is also termed a fine A fine
without ploclamation.
4. H. 7. ca. 24. upon which no proclamations were made, which fines do still
remain of such force, as they were at the common law, to discontinue the
estate of the Cognisor, if they Discontinuance.
be executed, 7. Ed. 3. fol. 35. 1. R. 3. cap. 7. Dyer fol. 216. p. 54. 4.
Elizab. Plow. fol. 265. b. 4. H. 7. cap. 24.

A fine with proclamations (the same is also termed a fine according A fine
with proclamation.

cap. 2. Plow. fol. 265. b

Of fines executed, and executory.
ANd every fine, as well with proclamation as without, is either executed Sect*
20. A fine executed.


A fine executed is such a fine, as of his own force gives a present
possession sur cognizance de droit come ceo que il ad de son done, which is in
very deed the surest fine of all, 8. H. 4. 8. 41. E. 3. 14. 42. E. 3. 5. 46.
E. 3. 15. 50. E. 3. 9. 13. Ass. p. 8.

Fines executory be such, as of their own force do not execute the possession
A fine executorie.
sur cognizance de droit tantum, Fines sur done, grant, releas, confirmation,
or render: for if such fines be not levied, or such render made unto them that
be in possession at the time of the fines levied, the cognisees must needs sue
writs of Habere facias seisinam, according to their several cases, for the
obtaining of their possessions. Nevertheless, if at the leuying of such
executory fines, the parties, unto whom the state is thereby limited, be in
possession of the lands passed, be needs no writ of execution for the same,
for then such fines do inure by way of extinguishment of right, but alter not
the estate nor possession Extinguishment.
of the cognisee, but perchance better it, 7. H. 7. 12. and 22. 2. E. 3. 6. 21.
E. 3. 44. 8. H. 4. 8. 41. E. 3. 14. 7. H. 4. 23.

Again some fines be single, and some double.
A Sngle fine is such a fine, by which nothing is granted, or rendered Sect*
21. A single fine.
8. H. 4. 8. 24. E. 3. 26.

A double fine is a fine containing a grant and render back again either A
double fine.
8. H. 4. 8. 24. E. 3. 26. and 35.

Of the parts of Fines, and of the writ of Covenant.
IN the form of every fine we are to consider the principal parts thereof,
Sect* 22.


The principal parts of fines be the writ or action whereupon the concord Parts
of fines.
is made, and the Concord it lelfe.

Of writs whereupon fines are levied.
THe writ is the very basis, ground and foundation of the fine, whereby Sect*
23.
35. H. 8. Br. Fines 116. Or a Warrantia chartae, 18. E. 4. 22. Or a writ of
Right, Or a writ of Mes^e, 26. Ass. pla. 37. Or a writ of Customs and
services, 26. Ass. pla. 37. Dyer fol. 179. pl. 46.

Whereof Fines be grounded.
IN every such writ thessential parts and the adjuncts are to be considered:
Sect* 24.
the principal parts thereof be the parties to the same, whereof we have spoken
already, And the things whereof a fine is levied.

Of what things Fines may be levied.
ANd touching the things whereof fines are leuiable, we are first to Sect* 25.
consider the nature of the things themselves, whether they will pass in fines
or no: And then of their names, by which they may pass or not. And how they
may be in order placed in the writs: Fines therefore may be levied of all
things inheritable being in Esse tempore finis, and certainly expressed in the
writs, 18. E. 4. 22. as de messuagio, tofto, columbario, gardino, terra. prato,
pastura, bosco, subbosco, bruera, mora, iuncaria, marisco, alneto, ruscaria,
redditu, per Registrum fol. 2. a de Rectoria Ecclesiae parochialis de M. ac de
decimis granorum, garbarum, and foeni, eidem Rectorie spectant^ etc. or cum
omnibus decimis granorum, garbarum, and foeni eidem Rectoriae spectant^, Thel
Lib. 8. cap. 9. Sect* 2. de Rectoria 2. E. 3. de furlongo terre, 4. H. 6. 14.
de passagio vltra aquam de T. de pastura ad certos boues, o^es, and alia
aueria, ac de communia pro omnibus animalibus, vel pro om^^modis auerijs, vel
de libera piscaria, libera warrenna, vel de Aduocatione Ecclesiae de D. vel de
aliquo seruitio speciali, vt de seruitio vnius fe^di Militis, vnius paris
Calcarium deauratorum, vel de seruitio inueniendi hominem, equitem vel peditem
ad eundem, vel ad equitandum cum le Cognisee in exercitu Walliae vel Scotiae,
etc. de Piscaria, 13. E. 3. de officio, 27. H. 8. fol. 12. de proficuis
officij, 12. E. 3. de Aduocatione, Reg. fol. 165. de Corodio, 18. H. 6. fol.
20. 4. E. 4. 6. de chiminio, 2. E. 3. fol. 49. de proficuo molendini, 18. E. 3.
fo. 56. de libero redditu in breui, and in the concord, Quod predictus A.
recogn^ praedict' redditum cum pertinen^ simul cum homagio and fidelitate B. C.
and haeredum suorum de totis ten^tis quae etc. 1. E. 3. fo. 1. et 5. de
frankfold', 1. E. ^. fo. 1. de Nundinis and Mercatu, 1. E. 3. fol. 4. de
franchisia, 1. E. 3. fol. 4. de Minera plumbi, and cuiuscunque geneis metalli
cum pertinen^, etc. Reg. fol. 165. de decimis garbarum ad Ecclesiam de N.
qualiter^unq^e spectant^, Reg. fol. 165. de Aduocatione tertiae partis
Ecclesiae etc. or* detertia part aduocationis Ecclesiae, or, de meditate
aduocati^^is Ecclesiae, or, de aduocatione medietatis Ecclesiae, 45. E. 3. 12.
33. H. 6. fol. 11. de Communia, 4. E. 4. 6. de caruca terre, de pastura ad cen^
^^ues, de homagio, de feodo Militis, Reg. fol. 166. 167.

And a fine may be of a Rent charge which had no being before, 21.

Or, of a chief rent or other rent in b^ing, 18. E. 4. 22.

Or, of a Seigniory, 48. E. 3. 23.

Or, of an acquitaile, 50. E. 3. 23.

Or, of a Chauntrie, 38. E. 3. 33.

And of many other things may fines be levied.

And as fines may be levied of things in possession, so may they be levied of a
Remainder, or Reuersion, 42. E. 3. 7. 44. E. 3. 45.

And a Reuersion or a Remainder will pass by the name of the lands, 43. E. 3.
22.

But where a fine is of a reuersion or a remainder, it behooves the cognisee Of
a reuersion or remainder.
to sue a Quid i^ris clamat against the tenant: When it is of rent, a writ Quem
redditum reddi^: And where of a Seigniorie or services, Per que seruitia, to
compel the tenant to attourne, as shall be showed hereafter.

Fines may be levied of thinheritance or freehold of parsonages, vicarages, Of
Ecclesiastical lands mad^ temporal.
porcions, pensions, tithes, oblations, or any other Ecclesiastical profit
made temporal, and admitted to abide in temporal, hands, and lay uses, by
the laws, and statutes of this Realm of England, 32. H. 8. cap. 7.

And to conclude, fines be leuyable of all things, whereof a Precipe qd' lies,
as will appear by the examples following.

And lands bought of diverse persons may pass in one fine, and then Of diuers^
purchase^*
the writ of Covenant must be brought by all the vendees against all the
vendors: And every vendor must warrant against him and his heirs only: for it
is absurd that one man should warrant the sale of an other without
consideration.

And such joint fines seem reasonable, especially where the several

But fines may not be levied of things incertaine: as de tenemento,
Incerteinty. Tenement.
3. E. 4. 19. 11. H. 7. 25. 12. H 7. 6. 47. E. 3.

Nor of lands given in tail by the king, for it is void against the issue
Tail by the King.
entaile and the king, 32. H. 8. cap. 36. Br. Fines 121.

Nor of lands restrained from being sold by act of Parliament, 32. H. Restraint.
8. cap. 36.

Nor of lands of the husband or of his au^cestors assured for Iointure, Dower.
Ioiture. Forfeitur^.
dower, or in tail, to any woman by means of her husband or his ancestors,
for such fine works a present forfeiture of her estate, if she grant a
greater estate then for her life, 11. H. 7. cap. 20. Plow. fol. 459.

Nor of lands seized into the kings hands before Livery or Ouster le Lands
seized*
maine ^^ed, 24. E. 3. 65.

Nor of lands in Ancient demesne: for if any fine be levied of such lands,
Ancient demesne.
it may be reuersed by a writ of Disceit, brought by the Lord of Ancient
demesne, and thereby he shall be restored to his seigniory, and it seems to be
void between the parties, quia, coram non Iudice, 7. H. 4. 44. 8. H. 4. 23.
21. E. 3. 20. Reg. fol. 13. b. de Fine adnullando etc.

Yet it is holden good to bind the parties, 17. E. 3. 31. and 7. H. 4. Br.
which seems not to be law.

But if such fines be of lands in Ancient demesne and of lands at the Ancient
demesne and lay fee.
common law, it shall be still good for the lands at the common law, 7. H. 4. 44.
21. E. 3. 20.

By what names things may pass in Fines.
NOw that we have partly set down what may pass in fines, let us Sect* 26.
Names.
see by what names the same may pass. An Honor, this may pass by the name of
a Manor, or by his proper name: as de honor de Tickhill, or, de manerio de
Tickhill.

It suffiseth also to demand a Manor by his proper name without naming A Manor.
of the Town wherein it lies, For it may be out of any town, or extend into
several towns and counties: as, de manerio de D. cum pertin^, yet it feemeth
best to express all the several towns into which it extends: as, de
manerio de S. cum pertin^ in D. and E. 19. Ed. 4. fol. 9. ^. 43. E. 3. fol. 9.
a. Bracton Lib. 4. cap. 31. Sect* 3. 9. E. 4. fol. 61. 9. a 16. ^ 17. b. 11. H.
7. fo. 22. b 49. For if any of the towns, into which the manor extends, be
omitted, nothing of the Manor in that town passes, 5. E. 4. 103.

A Castle or a Hundred may be parcel of a Manor, and pass by the A Castle or
Hundred. Manor Castle.
name of the manor, whereof they be parcel, 26. Ass. 54. And one Manor may be
parcel of an other, 2. E. 3. fo. 36. And a Castle may be demanded by his
proper name: as, de castello de B. cum pertin^, 1. E. 3. fol. 4.

An Hundred may be demanded by it self: as, de hundredo de S. 27. Hundred.
H. 6. fol. 2.

Mesuagiu^ is a dwelling house. By the name of a Mesuage, may pass A Mesuage.
a Curtelage, a gardein, an orchard, a douehouse, a shop, a mill, as parcel of
an house, Bracto^ Lib. 5. cap. 28. Sect* 1. Plow. fo. 169. 170. 171. The like
of a cottage, a toft, a chamber, a celler, etc. yet may they be demanded by
their single names.

A Chapel or an Hospital must be demanded by the name of a mesuage, A
Chahpell. A Hospital.
13. Ass. 2.

A Toft is the place wherein a mesuage has stood.

A Curtelage is a garden, or a yard, or fold, or a piece of void ground, A
Toft. A Curtelage.
lying near and belonging to a mesuage, Plow.

Molendinum is good without adding ventriticum, or aquaticum: albeit A Mill
the latter be more usual. 44. E. 3. fol. 13.

Of a Reuersion, by the name of the land, or otherwise, 43. E. 3. 22. A
Reuersion.


Land is to be demanded by the certain measure of the superficial Land.
quantity thereof: as hida, carucata, bouata, virgata, acra, roda terrae.

In like manner boscus, subboscus, bruera, mora, iuncaria, mariscus, and may be
demanded by the number of acres thereof, 16. Ass. 9.

Turbarie may be demanded by the name of More.

Rent by the multitude and number of the things which are to be re^dred: Rent
as, x. librar^, or sex denar^, or vno obulat^, or quinque solidat^ reddit^.

Housebote, Haybote, and Plowbote, may be demanded by the name Estouers
of Estouers: thus, de rationabili estouerio in boscis, viz. in december acris
bosci ipsius A. in D. etc.

Parsonages, Rectories, Aduowsons, Vicarages, or Tithes impropriate, A Parsonage
pass not by the names de Aduocatione Ecclesiae, but de Rectoria Ecclesiae de
S. cum pertin^.

But when it is but of a presentation, it must be de Aduocatione ecclesiae A
Presentatio^
de S. and not, cum pertin^.

And of all Vicarages endowed, the writ must be de Aduocatione A Vicarage.
Vicariae Ecclesiae de S. and not cum pertin^.

And where no Vicarage is endowed, it passes under these words, de

If an entier manor, mesuage, or other entier thing, be divided or parted,
Parts severed.
and after a fine is to be levied of some of the parts of the thing so severed,
the^ must not the fine be de medietate, or de quarta part, or, other part, of
the manor, mesuage, or other thing, but such part must be demanded by the name
of a whole thing: As if the manor of D. be divided into 2. parts, the fine of
the one part (if the division be so made, that the manor of that part be not
extinct) must be de manerio de D. So, if a mesuage and xx. acres of land be
parted into two parts, the fine of the one part must be de vno mesuagio and december
acris terre etc. and not de medietaie vnius mesuagij, and xx. acrarum terre:
for the things new divided from the rest, are now become whole things by
themselves, though less in quantity then the whole was before division thereof
made. If a thing be Twice named.
twice named in a writ of Covenant, it hurts not: as a Manor and an Hundred
parcel of the same manor, 27. H. 8. 2.

If lands in diverse Shires pass, there must be several writs of Covenant
Diverse Shires.
thereof accordingly, and but one Concord, Dyer 227. pla. 44. 15. E. 4. 33.

Of the names of the place wherein the lands do lie.
ANd the place wherein the lands do lie, is taken to be parcel of the Sect* 27.
Place.
name thereof: And thefore we must regard the places wherein the lands do lie,
as the shire, Town, Parish, or Hamlet: for a fine is good in a Hamlet, 38. E.
3. fol. 19. 8. E. 4. fol. 6. and 7. E. 6. Br. Fines 44. and 91. Hamlet. Town
decayed.
or in a Town decayed, 7. E. 6. Br. Fines 91.

Nevertheless, it is also good to name the Town wherein the hamlet

And if a Manor extend into diverse Towns: as, A. B. C. it is good to A manor
in diverse towns
expres al or none: as, de manerio de S. in A. B. C. for if any of the towns
be omitted, none of the manor in that town passes. Yet a fine of a manor cum
pertin^ would have carried the whole manor, 9. E. 4. 6.

But if a man have diverse Manors of one name: as, South S. and North Two manors
of one name.
S. it is good, in a writ of one of the same manors, to express certainly
which of them is intended to be passed, 47. E. 3. 12. H. 7. 6. Albeit it is
thought good enough by the name of the manor of S. without addition: for
certeintie is always best.

How several things must be placed in writs of Covenant.
NOw that we have partly learned, of what things fines may be levied, Sect' 28.
Orderly placing.
and by what names: yet seems time to show in what order and form they must
be therein placed one before an other, when diverse things pass by one writ,
for which we may observe these rules. First Worthyest.
the more worthy things must be put before things less worthy: as a Mesuage
is set before land, a Manor before a mesuage, a Castle before a Manor, 7. H. 6.
39. Plow. 168. 169.

Secondly, things general before things special: as land (being the Things
general.
general, or genus to meadow, pasture, wood, Iuncaria, mariscus, is first to be
placed: And wood (being the general to wood grounds, as alnetum salicetum etc.
is to be set before them the writs.

Thirdly, entier or whole things are to be set before their parts: as, Whole
things Parts.
de manerio de C. and medietate manerij de B. cum pertinen^ etc.

Fourthly, parts of things excepted must succeed those things out of Things
excepted.
which they be excepted. And if there be diverse parcels in one writ, that
parcel, out of which thexception is to be made, ought to be last placed,
Registr^ fol. 6. as, de manerio de D. cum pertin^ in C. (excepto vno mesuagio,
duabus acris terre, and aduocatione Ecclesie de C. etc.).

And every thing excepted ought to be certainly named. It needs Pertinencie.
not to say cum pertin^ after the thing excepted, 40. E. 3. 25.

And thexception must always be of such things, whereof the writ will Plowd.
fol. 362. a 362. b 370. a Registr^ fol. 228. 229. of which for the present,
view thensample ensuing: videlicet.

Praecipe A. B. quod teneat C. D. conuenc' etc. de vno mesuagio, vno cotagio,
and medietate vnius mesuagij, and december acrarum terrae cum pertin^, excepta vna
acra terrae in N. etc. And finally the form and order of placing the
particulers in a writ of Regula.
Covenant, is in all things as in a Praecipe quod reddat of lands.

And further, observe the rule of the Register fol. 2. which partly appears

suagium, tum, lendinum, umbare, dinu^, ra, tum, tura, cus, ra, Regula.

Mes, tof, mol, col, gar, ter, pra, pas, bos, brue, mora.
ria, cus, tum, caria, ditus,
Iunca, maris, alne, rus, red, sectare priora.
The writ of Covenant must bear Test before the writ of Dedimus Writ.
potestatem, 35. H. 8. Br. Fines 116.

Of Adjuncts proper to the writs whereof Fines be levied.
OF Adjuncts proper to writs of Covenant, and other writs upon Sect. 29.
which fines be usually levied, some be internal Adjuncts, and some external.

Adiu^cts internal be the days of return, and the date or Test of the
Adjuncts internal.
writ, which be also common to other writs.

In the Return it is to be observed, that there be xv. days at the Return.
least between the Test, and the day limited for the return thereof. 12. E.
4. 11.

The Test or date must not be upon any Sunday, or other festival Test.
day, which is not dies iuridicus in Court.

External Adjuncts to writs be, the writing, the Latin, the affidauit,
External.
or composition, the signing, and the payment of the fine, and returning, which
be in like manner common to other writs.

Touching the writing thereof, it is meet to be fair written without Writing.
rasing or interlining of any principal matter therein, for such rasing
Rasing. Interlining. False Latin.
or interlining will overthrow the writ in some cases, 45. E. 3. 18.

Also it behooves that there be no false Latin in any such writs, 7.

And therefore such writs should heedfully be examined twice or thrice
Examination of Writs.
over, for fear of errors.

The form used in the returning of such writs will appear amongst Returns.
the presidents, for the returns are nothing else but the Shirifes answers
touching that they are commanded to do by the same writs.

Upon what writs fines may be levied.

For so much as no fine can be levied but upon some original writ, Originals.
Stat. de Finibus, 18. Edw. 1. we are now to consider upon what original writs
fines are leuiable.

A writ of Covenant is the most usual writ whereu^o^ fines are levied,
Covenant.
Fitz. Not. bre. fol. 146. f. 35. H. 8. Br. Fines 116. Carliel St. 15. E. 2.

Yet may fines be levied upon a writ Warrantia cartae, 18. E. 4. 22. Warrantia
cartae. Mesne. Customs and services.
Carliel St. 15. E. 2.

Or upon a writ of Mesne, 18. E. 4. 2.

Or upon a writ de Consuetudinibus and Seruitijs, 22. Ass. p. 37. Pasc.

Or upon any writs of Right, 7. E. 3. fo. 335. Plow. fol. 358. Right. Without
original.


Yet Tremayle Justice holds, that if in a Praecipe quod reddat against Ideo
Quaere, 21. E. 4. 4.

A fine may be upon a writ Quod permittat habere chiminum vltra Quod permittat.
terram le Cognizor, 2. E. 3. 19. Fitzh. Fines 102.

The several forms of Concordes.
A Concord is the very agreement between the parties how the Sect. 30.
lands shall pass, in the form whereof many things are to be regarded: As if
it be single, whether it be sur cognizance de droit come ceo que il ad de son
done, Or, sur grant, done, releas, or confirmation. Or if it be a double fine
with a render, what estates are to be created nomine penae, and clause of
distress, and services, with the clause of warrantie. For which it is 3. H. 6.
42. 21. E. 3. 33. 43. E. 3. 11 24. E. 3, 64. as this:

Et est Concordia talis, scilicet, quod p^dictus A. cogn^ ten^t^ praedict' But
the kings tenant in Capite may knowledge the right of his lands to be in diverse
for the kings benefit, in having many such tenants in Capite, 7. H. 7. 4.

And likewise the releas and warrantie must be from the heirs of one 44. E. 3.
21. for in a fine from diverse, the fee must be supposed to be in one of them
only, 21. E. 3. 33.

In a fine sur grant and render, none can take the first estate upon the
render, but some of the Cognizors, but Reuersions or Remainders any estranger
may take: For if A. knowledge a fine to B. and B. render to the said A.
Habendum sibi and E. vxori eius, and the heirs of theri bodies etc. by this
fine E. must have none estate, because she is not named in the writ, 24. E. 3.
28. 30. H. 8. Br. Fines 108. 7. E. 3. 64.

And a man cannot by fine by way of remainder reserve a less estate 24. E. 3.
28. 14. H. 4. 31.

And a Concord cannot be of any other thing then is contained in the 18. E. 4.
22.

And a Concord may be with an exception of some part, 44. E. 3. 21.

If a man will, he may make a Iointure by fine thus: If I. levy sur cognizance
de droit come ceo etc. and after A. render to I. for life without impeachment
of wast, the remainder to B. his wife for term of her life, the remainder to
I. and his heirs, 38. H. 8, Br. Fines 108.

The Manors and tenements contained in the writ may be divided: As 43. E. 3.
11. 45. E. 3. 12.

And in like manner a fine is levied of the manor of G. cum pertinen^ 44. Ass.
p. 11. Or incerteinly by 3. third parts to A. B. and C. in remainder severally,
18. H. 7. Br. Fines 111.

A fine levied to one in tail upon condition with remainder is holden 27. H.
8. 24. Plowd. 34. b. 24. E. 3. 62. Contra per Prisot 33. H. 6. 52. and 44. E.
3. 22. But a fine with a reentrie was rejected, 44. E. 3. 22.

A lease for years may be made by a fine in this form: The less must but
gives nothing thereby, Br. Fines 106. tempore H. 8. 36. H. 8. Br. Fines 118.
Plow. 455. 14. Eliz.

Or, a lease for years may be made by fine to bind the tenant in tail, 36. H.
8. Br. Fines 118.

If an estranger, which has nothing in the lands, levy a fine to him
dependant sur estate pur vie, sur cognizance de droit come ceo que il ad de son
done etc. and the cognizee by the same fine render to the cognizor for years,
de comme^cer al Mich. ensuant, and dies, and all the proclamations are made
after his death, The tenant for life after such time as the said leas is
limited to begin dies, it is adjudged a good leas to bar the issue in tail
for the term, 14. Eliz. Plowd. fol. 437. b. inter Smyth and Stapleton, which
seems contrary to the opinion before, Br. Fines 106. 118.

A. by fine grants his tenements, which I. holds for life, and 44. E. 3.
45.

Fine sur cognizance de droit come ceo etc, is levied to A. in fee 50. E. 3. 9.
24. E. 3. 26. 39. E. 3. 1.

And if diverse join in a fine, the warrantie must be by them, and the 44. E.
3. 1. 21. E. 3. 27. 42. E. 3. 13. 24. E. 3. 66. Contr^ sur terres de Gauelkind,
ibm^.

A particular tenant, as for life etc. cannot surrender his term to him 44. E.
3. 36.

One Concord may be of lands in several Counties, and the fine pro of all
extracted entierly: Yet must there be several writs of Covenant, returnable
all at one day, 6. Eliz. Dyer fol. 227. pl. 44. 15. E. 4. 33.

And finally in Concord, all the special names of things contained

HEc est finalis co^cordia facta in curia domini Regis apud Westmonaster^ Sect'
87.
a die sancti Michaelis in xv. dies, Anno regni regis H. filij regis l.
quinquagesimo prim^, coram G. de P. et R. de M. Iustic' et alijs domini ^egis
fidelibus tun^ibi presentibus, inter, W. de P. quer^, er H. B deforc', de
consuetudinibus et seruitijs que idem W. exigerat de praedicto H. de libero
ten^to suo quod de prae VV. tenet in VV. and VV. scz. de vnofeodo Militis and
dimid' cum pertinen^. Et vnde idem VV. exigebat de praedicto H. quod faceret ei
ad wardu^ Castri de B. quando eueneri^, and ad muragium eiusdem castri cum
necesse esset quantum ad praedictum tenementum pertinet. Que seruitia idem H.
ei non cognouit. Et vnde placitum inter eos in eadem curia summonit^ fuit,
scilicet quod p^dict' W. concessit pro se and heredibus suis, quod praed' H.
and hered' sui and eorum tenent^ de honor de B. sint quiet^ de praedict'
seruitijs inperpetuum: Saluis eide^ W. and hered' suis omnibus alijs seruic' ad
praedict' tenement^ pertin^, Et pro hac concessione, fine, and concordia idem
H. dedit praed' W. december and octo marcas argent^. Et hec concordia facta fuit
ex assensu and voluntate eiusdem domini Regis eam concedentis. This old fine is
in Dyer, fol. 179. pla. 46.

A Fine knowledged by I. F. knight and M. his wife and R. H. of two messuages,
one garden, one or chard, and of land, meadow, and pasture, to T. P. and I. K.
with warrantie against all men And the conusees by the said fine grant and
render to the said R. one of the conusors in the fine vi. acres of land etc.
parcel of the premises for one month to come next, and afterward the same to
remain to one I. now the wife of R. N. and R. N. son of the said R and I,
during their lives and the longer liver of them. And after their deceases the
the said vi. acres of land to remain to I. N. daughter of the said R. and I.
his wife, during her life, reserving a rent with clause of distres for non
payment thereof. And the residue of the premises, viz. the two messuages, one
garden, one orchard etc. the said conusees grant and render to R. H. for one
month and afterward to one R. N. and I. his wife. To have and to hold to the
said R. and I. during their lives, and the longest liver of them, reserving
also thereupon a rent with a clause of distres for non payment thereof. And
lastly the said conusees do grant and render the reuersion of the whole
premises, and the several rents reserved upon the said graunts and renders
unto the said I. F. and M. his wife, two of the said conusors, and to the
heirs of the said I. F. for ever.

A Fine knowledged within the County of Chester, by H. S. Esquire. to W. F. and R.
C. of diverse manors etc. with warranty against all men. And the conusors by the
same fine, grant and render the same manors etc. unto the conusor and his
heirs males, and for default of such heirs males, then to certain persons
for the life of I. S. brother unto the said conusor, and after his death to his
heirs males. And if the said I. S. died without heir male, then to diverse
other of the name and kindred of the conusor, and to their heirs males, and for
default of such heir, the last remainder in fee to the right heirs of the
conusor for ever.

Nota que Dyer chief Justice dit que si les femmes fuissent soers que adonques
il ne besoigne double garrantie in form auantdit, mes single garrantie est
assets bone.

The order of taking the knowledge of a Fine by Dedimus potestate^ directed to
diverse, but the knowledge taken only by two of the Commissioners, and the
certifying thereof by the Commissioners that took the knowledge.
After the Fine is acknowledged, the Commissioners must write under the Concord
of the said Fine, as follows.

Capt^ and recognit^ die etc. Anno etc. coram A. B. armig', and C. D. gener^
virtute breuis dominae Reginae de Dedimus potestatem nobis and alijs direct.

Commissioners.
A. B. C. D.
Then write upon the back of the Dedimus potestatem.

Respons. A. B. Arm^, and C. D. gener^ duorum Commiss. infra nominatorum.

Execucio istius Commissionis pater in quadam Schedula huic commissioni annex'.

Then must the Commissioners subscribe their names.

the annuity and the penalty.

Notes to be observed in Fines.
1 Nota que ascun foits plusors chooses passa en le Praecipe q^ ne sont nosme en
le concord.

2 Nota q^ un clause de Reentrie ne poit estre en un fine.

3 Nota q^ si home purchase diverse parcels de terr^ de diverse homes il
purroit passer touts les parcels e^ un common fine, mes couient que il aver
several garranties de chescun de les parties pur lour several parcelles.

4 Nota que Catlyn chief Justice del bank le roy dit que south no^me de bois,
haut bois and Subbois passera en un fine.

5 Nota que per Dyer un Render ne poet estre fait mes ta^tum a luy que est
nosme en le fine: mes un remainder poet estre limited a un, per fine coment
que il ne soit nosme en le Praecipe.

A fine knowledged by the husband and wife unto two of 30. messuages, of
lands, pasture, wood, linge, heath, and rent in diverse places: The Conusees
render the same again to the said Conusors for term of their two lives, with
diverse remainders over after there deaths in general taeile to the children of
the said Conusors. And for default of issue of the said Conusors to the right
heirs of the wife of the Conusor for ever.

ten^ta pertinen^ imperpetuum.

^ Adjuncts of Concords.
THe Adjuncts of a Concord, be also of two sorts: Internal, and External
Sect. 147.
Internal be such as be contained within the very Concord it self. Of which
sort be the clause of reservation of service, rent, or other thing, the clause
of nomine penae, the clause of distress, and the Reservation. Nomin^ penae.
Distress.
clause of warranties: All which clauses of reseruations, nomine penae,
distress, and warrantie, are to be made in such words, and in such forms, as
the like are made in Instruments extraiudiciall: for which see Leases and
Graunts of rents charge in the first part of Symboleography, If the following
example do not sufficiently satisfy your desire herein.

And Warranties be sometimes general, that is to say, against all Warrantie.
men: Some against all, except certain persons: some against certain persons
only: some against every Cognizor, and his heirs severally: and some against
one of the Cognizors, and his heirs only: some of all the lands in the fine:
some of all, except part: and some of part only, certainly expressed.

The External Adjuncts of Concordes be the license of alienanation, Dedimus
potestatem, the examination of the parties, and the cognizance. The license of
alienation is a power or au^thority given License. Alienation*
by her Majesty to the parties, that lands may be aliened without incurring
the danger of contempt.

And every such license is either to alien lands holden in Capite, or to
Mortmaine.

The license of alienation of lands holden in Capite may vary from 32. H. 8.
Br. Alienations 4. 30.

For the obtaining of which license the Clerk of the licenses does Dogket.
or other deeds, whereby the alienation is to be made.

And thereupon affidauit or composition must be made for the value Assida^i^.
of the lands, which are to pass thereby, which is to be signed by the Doctor
of the Chauncery that has power to take oath: Then the Queens fine is to be
paid to the Receiuor of fines, who will sign the dogket: And afterward the
same is to be signed by two of the commisioners of the office of fines and
licenses, and upon that dogket, the Clark of the licenses is to make the
license, and get it sealed with the great Seal, which license is to be made in
form following.

A license of Alienation of lands holden in Capite.
ELizabeth dei gr^atia etc.
Omnibus, ad quos praesentes literae peruenerint Sect. 148*
salutem.
Sciatis, quod nos de gratia nostra speciali, ac pro tribus libris nobis solut^
in hanaperio nostro, concessimus, ac lice^tiam dedimus, ac per praesentes
concedimus, ac licentiam damus, pro nobis and haeredibus nostris, quantum in
nobis est, dilecto nostro I. F. quod ipse totam medietat^ manerij de C. cum
pertinentijs, ac quadraginta mesuag', vigint^ cotag', quadragint^ gardin^,
quinquagint^ acras terrae, quadragint^ acras prati, trescent^ acr^ pasturae,
xxx. acr^ bosci, trescent^ acr^ morae, and viginti libr^ reddit^, cum
pertinentijs in W. and alib^ in comitatu nostro N. eidem mediet^ pertinent^
sieve spectant^, parcell' inde reputat^ aut accept^ existen^, quae de nobis
tenentur in Capite, dare possit and concedere, alienare, vendere, barganizare,
feoffare, warrantizare, aut cognoscere, per finem in curia nostra coram
Iusticiarijs nostris de communi banco, aut aliter, seu aliquo quocunque modo,
dilecto nobis E. R. Habendum and tenendum eidem E. haeredibus and assignatis
suis, de nobis and haeredibus nostris, per seruic' inde debita and de iure
consueta imperpetuum: Et eidem E. quod ipse dictam medietat^ manerij praedicti,
ac caeterorum praemissorum cum pertinentijs a praefato I. recipere possit, and
tenere, sibi, haered', and assignatis suis, de nobis and haeredibus nostris,
per seruitia praedict' imperpetuum, sicut praedictum est, tenore praesentium
similiter licentiam dedimus, ac damus specialem: Nolentes quod praedict' I. aut
heredes sui, vel praedict^ E. haeredes vel assignati sui praedicti, ratione
praemissorum, per nos haeredes vel successores nostros, Iusticiar^, Eschaetor^,
Vicecom^, Balliuos, aut alios officiarios seu ministros nostros, haeredum vel
successoru^ nostrorum quoscunque inde occasionentur, molestentur, perturbentur,
vexentur, in aliquo, seu grauentur, aut eorum aliquis occasionetur, molestetur,
perturbetur, vexetur in aliquo, seu grauetur. In cuius rei testimonium has
literas nostras fieri fecimus patentes.

Test me ipsa apud Westmonasterium vltimo die etc.
A license to alien in Mortmaine.
ELizabeth dei gratia etc.
Omnibus etc.
Sciatis quod nos de gratia nostra Sect. 149.
speciali, ac pro xl. solid' nobis solut^ in hanaperio nostro, concessimus, ac
licentiam dedimus, ac licentiam damus, pro nobis and haered' nostris, quantum
in nobis est, R. S. quod ipse Aduocationem de L. Abbati and Conuentui de L. in
comitatu E. dare possit and concedere: Tenendum sibi and successoribus suis de
dict^ domina Regina and haeredibus suis, in liberam, puram, and perpetuam
Elemosynam imperpetuum. Ac eisde^ Abbati and Conuentui, quod ipsi Aduocationem
illam a praefato R. S. recipere, and Ecclesiam illam appropriare, and eam sic
appropriatam in proprios vsus tenere possint sibi and successoribus, de ipsa
Regina and haeredibus suis, in liberam, puram, and perpetuam Elemosynam
imperpetuum: Nolentes etc. vt supra.

Quod permittant finem leuari.
ANd after that such license is had, the use was (which is not now Sect. 150.
in use) to have a writ, mencioning the license and the effect of the fine,
directed to the Justices of the common Place, commanding them, quod permita^tt
finem illum leuari, Registr^ fol. 167. a. 1. E. 3. cap. 12. 34. E. 3. cap. 15.
33. H. 6. fol. 2. The form of which succeeds.

Regina, Iusticiarijs suis de banco, salutem: Cum per literas nostras

But before 20. H. 3. the kings tenant in Capite might have aliened his free
lands without license, 14. H. 4. 3. 20. Ass plac. 17. as it seems.

The writ of Ad quod damnum.
But before the granting of any such license, either to alien lands Sect. 151.
holden in chief, or, to alien lands in Mortmain, or, release right in
Mortmain, or exchange, the ancient use was to have a writ of Ad quod dampnum,
containing the substance of the Kings license out of the Chancery, directed to
the Escheator in the County wherein the lands lie, to be aliened, to inquire
and certify into the Chancery, what damage or prejudice thalienation thereof
will be to the king, or the other chief Lord, of whom they are holden, And of
what tenure and value the lands be, And whether there remain sufficient free
land besides those to the alienor, to sustain public charges, and to be in
Assi^es and Iuries etc.

And this is as well where the alienation is made by the king, or by a

The like inquiry by writ of Ad quod damnum, has been used before Fitzh.
Not. bre. fol. ^21. and inde vsque fol. 227.

But now experience is to the contrary, in liew whereof the use at Absque
aliquo breui de ad quod damnum, seu aliquibus alijs breuibus, seu mandatis,
superinde habendis, fiendis, aut prosequendis.

And one writ of Ad quod dam^um will serve for diverse purchases,

But not so of lands holden in chief, 22. E. 3. Fitzh. Not. bre. in breui

I purposely omit here the form of such writs de Ad quod damnum, because they
be so grown out of use. Of a Pardon for Alienation.
But if perchance any alienation of land holden in Capite, be made Sect. 152.
without license, a pardon must be sued, the fine of which is the value of
lands by one year, and the mean profits between the Inquisition A fine of
pardon.
and the pardon, 31. H. 8. Br. Alienation 29. unless the Commissioners will
more favorably compound for the same, as in some cases upon reasonable cause
showed, they use to do, which pardon being purchased, the purchasor is to hold
his land still, 14. H. 6. 26. 50. Ass. p. 2. 1. E. 3. ca. 12. 34. E. 3. ca. 15.

But the fine of a license, to alien lands holden in Capite, is, the third Fine
of a license.
part of the yearly value thereof, 26. H. 8. Br. Alienation 29.

But if alienation of lands into Mortmain be made without license, Mortmain.
the king may seize them as forfeited or escheated, Magna charta cap. 36.
Westminster 2. cap. 32. And for a license thereof to be granted, the fine thereupon
to be paid, is the value of the land by three years, 26. H. 8. Br. Alienation
29.

But variance between the license and the fine is not material, if it
Variance.
be all one alienation, 32. H. 8. Br. Alienation 30.

And it seems that a fine sur releas, or other releas, is none alienation,
Releas.
and therefore no fine due for the same, P. 37. H. 8. Br. Alienation 31.

But fines are payable, and licenses to be sued upon common Recoueries,
Recoueries.
39. H. 6. 32. H. 8. ca. 1. 4. E. 3.

Devise by will is an alienation, 3. Ma. 1. Br. Alienation 37. Will.


Of the Dedimus potestatem to take cognizance of a fine.
A Dedimus potestatem to take knowledge of a Fine, is, as aforesaid, Sect. 153.
a writ Commissionall directed to one, or more, giving them power to take and
certify to the Justices of the common Place, the cognizance of the Cognizees,
when they can not conveniently travel to do it in Court, and it ought to
recite the substance of the writ of Conenant, And bear Test or date after it,
Fitz. not. fol. 146. g. The form of the writ of Covenant, and Dedimus
potestate^. with the returns thereof, ensue:

The writ of Covenant.
Elizabeth dei gratia, Angliae, Franciae, and Hiberniae Regina, fidei defensor
Vicecom^ Ebor^ Salutem:
Praecipe T. B. armigero, and A. vxori eius, quod just and sine dilatione
teneant W. P. gener^, conuentionem inter eosfactam de manerio de T. cum
pertine^tijs: Ac de duobus messuagijs, tribus cotagijs, quinque toftis, vno
columbar^, quinque gard^is, quinque pomarijs, centum and december acris terrae,
quinquaginta acris prati, quinquaginta acris pasturae, december acris bosci,
ce^tum acris i^mpnorum and bruer^, quadraginta solidat^ reddit^, and communia
pasturae pro omnimodis animalibus, cum pertinentijs in W. and B. Et nisi
fecerint, and praedictus W. fecerit te securum de clamore suo prosequend', tunc
summ^ per bonos summonit^ praedictos T. and A. quod sint coram Iusti ciarijs
nostris apud Westmonaster^ in octab. Sancti Michaelis, ostensuri quare non
fecerint, and habeas ibi summ^ and hoc breue.

T. etc. xiij. die N. anno regni nr^i quadrages.
And the fine thereof is entered under the writ, thus:

Pro vigint^ solid' solut^ firmar^ fine dominae Reginae virtute warrant^ Fine.
regij.

Then must the writ of Covenant be endorced thus:

Per E. S. pro fine infrascr', q affid' quod Indorsement.
ten^t^ infrascr^ non exec' val' x. libr^ per annum. The Shirife return.

Pledg' de pros. Johannes Do. Richardus Roo.
Summ^ Johannes Den. Richardus Fen.
The Commiss. of fines. W. L. T. W. R. Eure armig Vic'.

The Dedimus potestatem thereof.
Elizabeth dei gratia Angliae, Franciae, and Hiberniae Reg. fidei defensor
Charissimo consanguin^ nostro Gilberto Comiti Salop^, ac p^dicto ac fideli
nr^o I. D. militi dn^o D. Necnon dilectis and fidelibus suis G. S. militi, and
C. C. militi, Ac dilecto nobis W. West armig', Salute^:
Cum breue nostr^ de conuentione pendeat coram Iustic' nr^is de banco, inter W.
P. gener^, and T. B. armigerum, and Annam vxore^ eius de manerio de T. cum
pertinen^: Ac de duobus messuag', trib' cotagijs, quinque toft^, vno columbar^,
quinque gardinis, quinque pomarijs, centu^ and december acris terrae, quinquaginta
acr^ prati, quinquaginta acris pastur^, december acr^ bosci, centum acr^ iampnorum
and bruere, quadragint^ solidat^ reddit^, and coi^a pastur^ pro omnimodis
animalibus cum pertin^ in W. and B. in Com^ Ebor^, ad finem inde inter eos
cora^ Iustic' nostris p^dict^ in banco p^dict^, secundum legem and
consuetudinem regni nr^i Angl' leuand': Ac praefati T. and A. adeo impotentes
sui existunt, q absque maximo corporum suorum periculo, vsque Westminster ad diem in
dicto breui contentum, ad cognitiones, quae in hac part requiruntur, faciend',
laborare non sufficient vt accepimus: Nos statuim^ eorundem T. and A.
co^patientes in hac part, dedimus vobis, quatuor, tribus, vel duobus vestrum,
potestatem recipiend' cognitiones, quas ijdem T. and A. cora^ vobis, quatuor,
tribus, vel duobus vestrum, facere voluerint de praemissis, Et ideo vobis,
quatuor, tribus, vel duobus vestrum, mandamus, quod ad praefat^ T. and A.
personaliter accedentes, cognitiones suas praedictas recipiatis, and cum eas
receperitis, praefat^ Iustic' nostris inde, sub figillis vestris, quatuor,
trium, vel duorum vestrum, distinct and aperte reddatis certiores, vt tunc
finis ille, inter parts praedictas, de praemissis, coram Iustic' nostris
praedictis in banco praedicto leuari possit, secundum legem and consuetudinem
supradicta^, mittentes eisdem Iustic' hoc breue,

test meipsa apud West. 14. die N. Anno reg. nr^i tricesimo qinto. Garth.

The name of the Curcester.
The said Dedimus potestatem, must be indorsed, thus: Per dominum

The Lord keepers name. Io. Puckering Cancel.

The Justice of the circuit. Fr. Beamont.

Executio istius breuis patet in quad' schedula eid' annexa. Retorn.

Capt^ and cognit^ apud K. in Comitatu Eborum, decimo nono die Ianuarij,

Dedimus potestatem super breue de consuet^ and seruicijs pro fine inde leuand'.

Regina etc. dilecto and fideli suo R. H. vni Iustic' suorum de Banco, eidem W.
facere debet, de libero tenemento suo, quod de eo tenet in N. vt in homagijs,
fidelitate, releuijs, and alijs, in comitatu S. Nosque ad petitionem
praedictorum W. and E^licentiam nostram eis dederimus inde co^cordand', ac
praefat^ W. and E. adeo impotentes sui existant, quod absque maximo corporum
suorum periculo, vsque Westmonaster^, ad diem in dicto breui nostro contentum,
ad cognitiones, que in hac part requirunt^, faciendas, laborare non sufficiu^t
vt accepimus, nos statuimus corundem W. et E. compatientes in hac part,
dedimus vobis potestatem recipiendi cognitiones, quas ijdem W. et E. coram
vobis facere voluerit de premissis: Et ideo vobis mandamus, quod ad praef. W.
and E. personaliter accedentes, cognitiones suas praedictas recipiatis: Et cum
eas receperitis, praefatos socios vestros inde distinct et aperte reddatis
certiores, vt tunc finis ille inter parts praedictas de premissis, coram vobis
and socijs vestris praedictis in banco praedicto, secundum legem and
consuetudinem regni nostri Angl', leuari possit, Et habeas ibi tunc hoc breue
T. etc.

Of the Queens silver.
THe Queens silver is the fine, which is paid unto her Majesty for Sect' 154.
her highness license of concord, which upon writs of Covenant, be taxed after
the rate following: That is to say, for lands of the yearly

value of Li. s.. is paid Li. s.. 3. 6. 8. 0. 6. 8. 5. 6. 8. 0. 10. 0. 7. 13.
4. 0. 13. 4. 8. 13. 4. 0. 16. 8. 11. 0. 0. 1. 0. 0. 12. 0. 0. 1. 3. 4. 14. 6.
8. 1. 6. 8. 15. 6. 8. 1. 10. 0. 17. 13. 4. 1. 13. 4. 18. 13. 4. 1. 16. 8. 20.
0. 0. 2. 0. 0. 22. 0. 0. 2. 3. 4 24. 6. 8. 2. 6. 8.

Every 5. marks and 20. shillings, paieth fine -- 6. s^. 8. From 5. marks and
20. s^. unto 5. marks and 40. s^. paieth -- 10. s^. And above 5. marks and
40. s^. unto 10. marks and 20. s^. paieth -- 13, s^. 4. And in like proportion
for all other fines.

And it is commonly entered by the Clerk of the Queens silver, in this form.

Ebor^. ss. I. W. dat Reginae x. s. pro licentia concordandi cum E. Entry of
the Queens silver.
W. armig' and I. vxore eius, de placito conuentionis, de vno messuagio, december
acris terre, december acr^ prati, and december acris pasture, cum pertinentijs in D.
reciting the substance of the writ. Et habent Cirographum per pacem admiss.
coram R. W. vno Iusticiariorum dn^ae Reginae de banco, Iusticiar^ in patria.

Observations necessary at the knowledging of Fines.
When a Fine is to be knowledged, it is meet, that before the Sect' 155. The
tytling of the note.
parties come before the Judges, or Commissioners, the titling of the writ of
Covenant and Concord be fair written, according to the parties minds, and
duly examined, and also signed, or subscribed by all the Cognisors.

It is also requisite that either the Cognisors be known to the Justices,
Knowledge of the Cognisor.
or Commissioners, that must take the Cognizance thereof, or that some other
credible person, known to him which takes the cognisa^ce, who knows the
party, be present: And do sufficiently inform the Judge, that they be the
self same parties, against whom the writ is brought: for some will couenously
knowledge fines in the name of others that be owners of the land, 34. H. 6. fo.
19.

And if a Feme covert be cognisor, she must be persuaded to yield her
Examination of wives.
consent and be fully agreed with, before she be examined, for in all cases,
where a Feme covert is to depart with any thing by fine, she must be examined
by the Justices or Commissioners that take the cognizance, and confess that
she does make cognizance freely, and not through fear or compulsion of any,
before the cognizance will be accepted. But where she is to take benefit by a
fine, she shall never be examined, 42. E. 3. 7. 3. H. 6. 42. 46. Ed. 3. 15. 8.
H. 6. 4. 24. Ed. 3. 62. Statut^ de Finibus 18. Ed. 2.

Also the yearly value of lands should be set down under the Concord, Value.
And some honest person, which knows the land, brought thither, to make oath
for the value thereof: For without such oath, or, composition, Oath.
the fine can not pass.

And composition with the Commissioners will not readily be made Composition
without oath, or some late fine, license, or other matter of record, to
inform the Commissioners of the value thereof: Which being done, the writ of
Covenant is again there to be entered, and the fine thereof (if it be fineable)
must there be paid to the Receiver, and then the writ must be signed by the
said Commissioners, and that done, the said writ must be sealed, and returned
with the Concord and Dedimus potestate^, if the cognizance was taken by Dedimus
potestate^, and then the said writs must be taken out and signed by the Custos
breuium, and thence they must be carried to the Clerk of the Queens silver,
who must take a note thereof for the entry of the Q. silver, and sign the
same again, and then must they be delivered to the Chyrographer of fines, to be
engrossed and proclaimed. The examples whereof appear in their apt places.

How, and when, cognisances of Fines must be certified, and what may hinder the
same.
IF they, which have taken cognizance of a fine, will not certify the same
Sect' 156. Certificat.
in convenient time, a Cerciorari is to be awarded unto them, comprehending the
matter of the Dedimus potestate^, and commanding them to certify etc. which,
if they do not, there lies against the Commissioners, an Alias, Pluries, and
Attachment etc. Fitz. na br. 147. b.

But they are not bound to certify such recognisances, but within the Time.
year after such caption thereof, but if they do, it is good enough, 23. Eli.
ca. 3. And with every such certificate they must certify the day and year
wherein the same was knowledged. Thus, capt^ apud R. in com^ Ebor^ xx. die
October. A nno regni Eliz. Reginae tricesimo nono.

Else no Clerk or officer may receive the same, but shall for fait for every
Forfaiture.
writ otherwise received v. li. 23. Eliz. ca. 3. If any of the partics to a
fine die after recognisance thereof and before it be certified, it ought not to
be certified, 1. H. 7. 9. 33. H. 6. fo. 52. Dier fo. 146. pl. 68. 7. Eliz.

But if such cognizance of a fine be certified, and the Queens silver entered,
Q. silver.
the fine is good, and may afterward be engrossed, though it be in an other
term. Thus.

Haec est finalis concordia facta etc. in crast' Pur^ beat Mariae, and postea

co^missionerdieth
fine, die before it be certified, their executors or administrators may

not. br. fol. 147. b. The form of which Cerciorari is such.

pertin^ in T. in com^ E. per praed' nuper Iustic' capt^, ac in custodia tua

In like manner, if a Justice having taken cognizance of a fine, be discharged
Justice discharged.
of his office, before he have certified the same, he may not certify it
without a like writ, notwithstanding that he be restored to his place again,
8. H. 4. 5. 1. H. 7. 9.

And thereupon it has bin used that a writ has bin directed to the F. N. 147.
b

kings death.
thereof, the Justices cannot then certify, Nam per mortem seu dimissionem

in effect, viz.

By the death and demise of any king, no action, bil, or plaint, that shall 1.
H. 7. 9.

If a feme sole by Dedimus potestatem, knowledge a fine, and before Feme.
the return thereof marry, this fine may be certified and engrossed as of a
feme sole, because the taking of her husband after the fine knowledged is her
own voluntary act, and such fine shall bar her and her heirs for ever,
Dyer fo. 246. pl. 68. Mich. 7. and 8. Eliz.

Every writ of Dedimus potes^atem, to spiritual Commissioners for Signed.
the taking of the cognizance of fines, ought to be signed by the L.
Chanceller, or L. Keeper, or chief Justice of the Common place, or the Justice
of the circuit where the land lies.

Of thinrolement of writs of Covenant, Dedimus potestatem and knowledges
thereupon, which is termed the foot of the fine.
BEfore thingrossing of the fine by the Cirographer, the writ of Covenant,
Sect* 157.
the writ of Dedimus potestatem, with the knowledges and notes of the same,
must be enrolled in a roll to be of record for ever, to remain Inrolment.
in the safe custody of the chief Clarke of the Common place (which is Custos
breuiu^) and his successors, who must have xxii. d. fee for entering Custos
breui^ Fee.
of the Concord, to the intent that if the notes of the fines in the custody of
the Cirographer be imbesilled, execution may be had upon the said roll,
Imbeselling. Proclamatio^s. The foot of the fine.
5. H. 4. cap. 14. Upon this Roll the Proclamations are endorsed and these
notes are termed the foot of the fine. Dyer fol. 321. plac' 19. 15. Eliz.

What Process lie in a Quid iuris clamat.
THe Process, in a Quid iur^ clamat, is summons and distres infinite, Sect.
163. Process. Correction.
Nature. br. 169. a. but if the tenant appear, and plead no good bar, and yet
will not atturne, he shall be imprisoned. 37. H. 6. 14.

Regina dilecto and fideli suo I. M. militi etc. Cum breue nostrum de
conuentione pendeat, coram vobis and socijs vestris iusticiarijs nostris de
banco, inter R. and P. de centum acris etc. quas I. tenet ad vitam suam de
praefato P. ad finem inde inter praefatos R. and P. secundum legem and
consuetudinem regni nostri Angliae, leuand', per quod vicecomiti nostro Norff.
per breue nostrum mandauimus, quod venire faciat coram praefatis iusticiarijs
nostris, praedictam I. ad diem in breui illo contentum, ad cognoscendum quid
iuris clamat h^bere in terra praedicta, ac praefata I. adeo impotens sui
existat, quod vsque bancum praedict', ad diem sibi datum, absque maximo
corporis sui periculo laborare ^on sufficit, ad cognoscend' quid iuris clamat
habere in terra praedicta: no^ statui ipsius I. compatientes in hac part,
dedimus vobis potestatem recipiendi cognitionem, and testificandi
atturnamentum, quae praefata I. coram vobis facere voluerit in hac part: Et
ideo vobis mandamus, quod ad praefatam I. personaliter accedentes, cognitionem
quam coram vobis in hac part facere voluerit, recipiatis: Et cum eam
receperitis, and ipsa coram vobis, prout moris est, se atturnauerit, praedictos
socios vestros de cognitione praedicta distinct and aper^e certificetis,
praedictum atturnamentum testificantes, vt finis ille, inter parts praedict',
de terra praedicta coram vobis and socijs vestris praedictis, in banco
praedicto leuari possit, secundum legem and consuerudinem supradictas, Et
habeatis etc.

An atturnement by Dedimus potestatem.
And as the tenant may make an attorney by Dedimus potestatem, ^o he may
atturne, The form whereof follows,

Regina, dilecto and fideli suo I. de M. salutem. Cum breue nostrum de
conuencione pendeat, coram vobis and socijs vestris Iusticiarijs nostris de
banco, inter R. and P. de centum acris etc. quas I. tenet ad vitam suam de
praefato P. ad finem inde inter praefatos R. and P. secundum legem and
consuetudinem regni nostri Angl' leuand', per quod vicecomiti nr^o Norff. per
breue nostrum mandauimus, quod venire faciat coram praefatis Iustic' nr^is,
praed' I. ad diem in breui illo contentu^, ad cognoscend' quid iuris clamat
habere in terra praed', ac praefata I. adeo impotens sui existat, quod vsque
bancu^ praed' ad diem sibi datum, absque maximo corporis sui periculo, laborare
non sufficit, ad cognoscend' quid iuris clamat habere in terra praedicta: Nos
statui ipsius I. compatientes in ha^ part, dedimus vobis potestatem,
recipiendi cognitionem, and testificand' atturnamentum, quae praefat^ I. coram
vobis facere voluerit in hac part, and ideo vobis mandamus, quod ad praefatam
I. personaliter accedentes, cognitionem, quam coram vobis in hac part facere
voluerit, recipiatis: Et cum eam receperitis, and ipsa coram vobis, prout moris
est, se atturnauerit, praedict' socios vestros de cognitione praedicta
distinct and aperte certificetis, praedictum atturnamentum testificantes, vt
finis ille inter parts praedictas de terra praedicta, coram vobis and socijs
vestris praedictis in banco praed', leuari possit secundum legem and
consuetudinem supradictas. Et habeatis etc.

Quem redd' reddit.
Having thus perused the writ of Quid iuris clamat in every circumstance, Sect.
166.
we are now in like manner to peruse the writ of Quem redd' reddit.

The writ of Quem redd' reddit, is a writ judicial, and issues Definition.
out of the note of the fine against the tenant of the land, to compel him to
atturne to the Cognizee, upon the grant of a rent charge, or rent seck issuing
out of the land, Not. br' fol. 170. b. The form whereof insueth:

Elizabeth Dei gratia etc. Vic' E. salutem. Praec' etc. tibi, quod venire Writ.
fac' hic a die S. Mich. in quindecim dies E. F. ad cognoscend' quem reddit^
reddere consueuit, exeun^ de vno messuag' cum pertin^ in E. que^ A. B. in curia
nostra coram Iusticiarijs nostris de banco, concessit C. D. per finem inde
inter eos fact'. Et habeas ibi hoc breue. Test etc.

vno messuagio cum pertinen^ in L. quod A. B. in curia nr^a etc. concessit C. D.

defaltis. Et habeas etc.

E. F. in mi^a pro pluribus defaltis etc.

I write thus briefly of this writ, because it so much resembles a Quid iuris

Per que seruitia.
PEr que seruitia is a Judicial writ, issuing from the note of a fine, and
Sect' 167.
lies for the Cognisee of a manor, seigniory, chief rent, or other services,
to compel him that is tenant of the land at the time of the note of the fine
levied, to attorne unto him, 43. E. 3. 8. H. 6. 17. Plow. 46. b. which is made
thus.

Regina etc. Vic' K. salutem. Praecipimus tibi, quod venire facias coram The
writ.
Iusticiarijs nostris apud W. in crastin^ etc. S. F. R. L. etc. ad L. etc. ad
cognoscend' per que seruitia tenent ten^ta sua cum pertin^ in B. que seruitia
E. L. in curia nostr^ coram Iusticiarijs nr^is apud W. conces^it W. B. per
finem ibi inde inter ^os factum. Et habeas ibi hoc breue. Test etc.

If the Lord grant the services of his tenant by fine, or otherwise, the Lord
before attorneme^t shall have such things, as lie in prender: as the ward of
the body of the heir and of the land, escheates etc. But not such things as
lie in render: as, rents, and relief, heriots, and other feruiuices, for he
cannot auow for them before the atturnement.

If a man grant the services of his tenant for life, this writ lies, Br. Sur
grant for life.
Per que seruitia 13.

If services be granted to I. S. for life, the reuersion to N. N. and Per que
seruitia, 20. H. 6. 7.

If Per que seruitia be brought against diverse, of which some only 21. E. 3.
48. T. 32. E. 3.

Upon whose alienations the tenant is not compellable to atturne.
IF tenant in tail of services levy a fine thereof, the tenant of the land
Sect' 168. T^^ tail.
is not compellable to atturne, 48. E. 3. 23. Because that if the cognisor die,

tail, 24. E. 3. 25. 43. E. 3. Nevertheless upon a fine with proclamation in
such case, which barreth the issue in tail, the tenant seems compellable to
atturne.

If a fine be levied by him which was never seized of the services, the Conisor
never seized.
tenant is not compellable to atturne, H. 6. E. 2.

particular tenant.

Recluse.
