Of the Engrossing of Fines.
WHen the note of the fine is made with the Custos breuium, if it Sect' 170.
be of lands in possession, or, when atturnement is made, if it be of a
reuersion, remainder, rents or services, then may it be engrossed by the
Chirographer.

And the Engrossing of a fine, is nothing else but the entering of the concord
Engrossing
thereof with the Chirographer, and the writing and delivery of the Indentures
thereof. Fitz. na. 147. a 5. H. 4. ca. 14. which be called the Chirographe of
the fine, and is made in form following, viz.

Haec est finalis concordia, facta in curia dn^ae Reg. apud Westminster, a die Fine
en tail de reuersion de rent.
Pasch. in 15. dies, An^ regni Eliz. etc. 39. coram Edmundo Anderson. T.
Walmsley, R. O. and R. B. Iustic' dn^ae Reg. and alijs fidelibus tunc ibi
presentibus, inter A. B. quer^, and L. C. deforc', de december mercat^ reddit^ cum
pertin^ in B. quem P. de A. tenent ad terminum vite, vnde placitum conuentionis
sum^ fuit inter eos in ead' cur^, scz. quod praed' L. concessit pro se and
heredibus suis, quod praed' redd' cum pertin^, quem praed' P. tenuit ad
terminum vite ex dimissione p^d' L. in praed' vill', die, quo hec concordia
facta fuit, and qui post decessum ipsius P. ad praedict' L. and heredes suos
debuit reuerti, post decessum ipsius P. integre remaneant praedict' A. Rem^ as
heirs de corpse.
and hered' de corpore suo procreat^, tenend' de capital' dominis feodi illius
per seruitia que ad praed' redd' pertinent imperpetuum: and si contingat, Rem^
as droit heirs.
quod idem A. obierit fine herede de corpore suo procreat^, tunc post decessum
ipsius. A. praed' redd' cum pertin^ integre remanebit rectis heredibus ipsius
A. tenend' de capitalibus dominis feodi illius per seruitia que ad praed' redd'
pertinent imperpetuu^: Et pro hac concessione, fine, and concordia, idem A.
dedit pref. L. centum marcas argenti. And so of others according to the
diversity of their cases.

Of the Tabling of fines engrossed.
The Chirographer of fines of the common plecs, for ever must write Sect' 172.
Tables.
and make one table for every county, where her Majesty's writ runs,
containing the contents of every fine, that shall pass in any one term, as
the name of the County, towns, and places, wherein the tenements mentioned in
any fine be, the name of y^ plaintiff and deforceant, and of every manor named
in any fine. And the first day of the next term, after thingrossing of every
such fine, shall fix every of the said tables in some open place of the court
of Common plees, and so every day of the said term during the sitting of the
said Court, and the said Cirographer shall deliver to every sheriff of every
County, his vndersherife, or deputy, fair written in parchment, a perfect
content of the table so to Contents.
be made for that shire in the term that shall be next before thassises to be
holden in the same county, or else mean between the term and the said assizes
to be set up the first day and every day of the next assizes in some open place
of the Court, where the Justices of assizes then shall sit, to continue there so
long as they shall sit in the said Court, if either the Chirographer or sheriff
fail herein, he forfaiteth v. li. and the Chirographers fee, for every such
table is iiii. d. 23. Eliz. cap. 3.

How many proclamations are to be made upon fines, and when.
Four proclamations only are now to be made upon every fine with Sect' 172.
proclamation, that is to say, one in the term in which the fine is engrossed,
and in every one of the three terms next ensuing the engrossing thereof, one
proclamation, 31. Eliz. cap. 2.

But if any of the same proclamations fail, by reason of the adiornement
Adiourneme^t.
of any of the said terms by writ of adiournement duly made, yet is such fine
good, and a good fine with proclamations, as if the same had bin proclaimed, 1.
Mar. ca. 7.

Bu if any proclamation be made upon a sunday, it is error, because it Sundaies
is not dies Iuridicus, Dyer fo. 128. pl. 53. 55. 2. Eliz.

Of Proclamations of fines at the assizes and general Sessions how they must be
certified.
TO the end better notice of fines may come to them, to whom it appertains,
Sect' 173. Sessions
it is ordained by the said statute of 4. H. 7. ca. 24. That the Justices of
the common place shall send a transcript of such fines to the Justices of
assizes in the counties where the lands do lie, to be proclaimed Assizes.
openly and solemnly at all the assizes, which shall be there in holden, within
one year after the Engrossing of such fines: And that the like Transcript be
made to the Justices of the peace, there to be proclaimed at four general
Sessions in the said Counties, and both the same proclamations to be made and
certified into the common place the second day of the return of the term then
next following: And it is to be noted, That while the said fines are read, all
plees must cease, 4. H. 7. cap. 24.

The form of every such proclamation is thus: After the crier has
Proclamation.
made an O yes for silence, saying: O yes, les fines lies, or to that effect,
the Cirographer or his deputy, reads the fines thus:

Ebor^. A Fine with proclamations between A. B. plaintiff, and C. D.
deforciant of tenements, in D. etc.

If the cognisees in fines die, before thingrossing thereof, no Proclamations
Cognise^ dead.
shall be made, because they had their election to have y^ fine with
proclamations or without, which election is now by their death determined, Dier
fo. 254. pl. 104. 8. Eliz. Plow. fo. 266. b.

Of the Inrolement of all the parts of fines after the engrossing thereof and
Proclamations passed.
BY the Statute of 23. Eliz. ca. 3. it is ordained, that there shall be for
Sect' 174. Office of Inrolment of fines etc.
ever and office of Inrolment, called the office of Inrolments of fines and
recoueries: And the Justices of the common pleas, for the time being, other
then the chief Justice, shall have and take the care and charge of and for the
Inrolments aforesaid, see the examinations thereof, and write their names unto
the rolls thereof, and have and enjoy the said office and the disposition
thereof, and carefully see and look to thexecution thereof. And have for the
Inrolment and examination of every such fine vi. s. viii. d.

And for every exemplification of every such Inrolment of any fine v.
Exemplification.
s^. for one years search iiii. d. for every sheet of paper containing xiiii.
lines iiii. d.

And the Justices of the common place have power to take order in all
Punishment.
their misprisions, contempts, or negligences for not doing or misdoing of any
thing, of, in, or concerning any such fines, as they shall think meet and
convenient, 23. Eliz. ca. 3.

And every writ of Covenant, and other writ, whereupon any fine is Inrolment of
fines.
levied, the return thereof, the Dedimus potestatem made for the knowledging
thereof, the return thereof, the concord, the note, and foot of every such
fine, the proclamations made thereupon, and the kings silver, upon the request
or election of any person, may be enrolled in the said office: And the
Inrolments of the same, or of any part thereof, shall be of as good force and
validity in the Law to all intents, for so much of any of them so enrolled, as
the same being extant and remaining were or ought by Law to be, 23. Eliz. cap.
3.

Of the exemplification of the parts of fines enrolled.
When any of the parts of a fine be enrolled according to the said Sect' 175.
statute, then may the same be exemplified, either under the seal of thoffice,
or under the great seal of England: But to exemplify such a fine under the
great seal has this discommoditie, that if any errors remain in the record
of the same fine, they be not amendable after the exemplification thereof, 23.
Eliz. ca. 3. but it seems this extends only to fines levied before the same
statute of 23. Eliz. ca. 3.

These Inrolements and exe^plifications seem very necessary, because 23. Eliz.
cap. 3.

The Exemplification of a fine enrolled according to the statute of 23. Eliz.
ca. 3.

How fines executory be executed.
THe execution of a fine, is the obtaining of actuail possession of the Sect.
176
things contained in the same, by virtue thereof, and it is either by entree
into the lands, or by writ.

By entree into the lands, as if upon a fine sur cognizance de droit If the
cognizor remain still in possession, And the cognizee by virtue of such fine
enter upon him, as he lawfully may, without any writ of habere fac' seisinam,
because such fine is executed, 41. E. 3. 14. 42. Edw. 3. 5. And if fine be
levied to the husband and wife in special tail, the rem^ to the heirs of the
body of the husband, and the wife dies without issue, the remainder is
executed in possession in the husband, for the estate tail meets with the
freehold and drowneth it. 7. H. 4. 23.

Execution of fines by writ.
EXecution of fines by writ, is either by Habere facias seisinam, or by Sect.
177.
Scire facias.

A writ of Habere facias seisinam, in this case is a writ judicial, issuing
Scire facias. And may be made in these forms.

Regina Vic' etc. Praecipimus tibi, quod sine dilatione habere facias

Of Execution of fines by Scire facias.
A Writ of Scire facias upon a fine, lies in the same case that a writ Sect.
178.
of Habere facias seisinam does, saving that it is to be sued a year and a day
after the fine is levied, whereby the Shirife is commanded to warn the terre
tenant to appear, and show cause if he can, why the Cognisee or his heirs
should not have execution, At the return where of, if the tenant appear, and
show no cause to the contrary, the plaintiff shall have an Habere facias
seisinam, vt supra. And the form of diverse Scire facias in like case ensue:

Rexvic' salutem. Cum quidam finis leuasset in curia domini E. filii Scire fac'
horse de fine for the heirs in tail.
Regis H. progenitoris nostri, scilicet apud W. in octab. etc. anno regni sui
tricesimo quarto, coram R. H. et sociis suis tunc Iusticiariis ipsius
progenitoris nostri de banco, inter G. P. and I. vxorem eius quer^, per W. F.
posit^ in loco eorum ad lucrand' vel perdend', and S. H. deforciantem, Attorney
in fine.
de manerio de C. cum pertinentiis, vnde placitum conuentionis summonitum
fuisset inter eos in eadem curia, scilicet quod praedict^ G. recogn^ maneriu^
praedict' cum pertinentiis esse ius ipsius S. vt illud quod idem S. habuisset
de dono praedict' G. Et pro illa recognitione, fine, and concordia, idem S.
concessisset p^dict' G. et I. praedict' manerium cu^ Render to the husband and
wife, and to the heirs of the husband of ^

pertinent^, quae fuerunt parcella manerij praed', modo ingressus est, and illa
tenet co^tra formam finis pred', Et quia volumus ea etc. ostens. si quid pro se
habeat aut dicere sciat, quare p^dictum tenementum cum pertinen^, praed' A.
filio and heredi p^dicti T. remanere non debeat, iuxta formam finis praedicti,
fi sibi viderit expedire etc. Et habeas etc.

Et modo hic ad hunc diem venit tam praedictus I. S. per S. atturnatum Scire
facia^ verse several tenants. Retur^ scire fecit. Cosinage allege.
suum, quam praedict' W. and A. per F. atturnatum suum, and vicecomes mand'
quod scire fecerit eisdem W. and A, essendi hic ad hunc diem ostensur^
seperatim in forma praedicta* per R. and S. probos etc. and super hoc praedict'
I. dicit, quod ipse est consang' and here is p^dict' I. and E. videlicet etc. and
petit versus praedict' W. and A. seperatim executionem in forma praedicta etc.

Et iam praedicti W. and A. quoad predicta tenementa, vnde executio A bar
that the parties to the fine had nothing in the land at the time of the fine,
but I. whose estate the tenant has*
versus eos secuta est, quam praedict^ R. and I. quo ad praedicta tenementa,
vnde executio versus eos seperatim petita est, singulatim dicunt, quod nec
praed' I. nec praed' W. and B. quos per finem praedict^ supponit^ esse parts
finis illius, nihil habuer^ in tenementis pred' cum pertinent^, vnde executio
versus W. and A. sepetatim petita est, te^pore leuat^ eiusd' finis, imo quida^
I. C. fuit inde seisitus te^pore leuationis finis illius, cuius quid I. C.
statu^ in ten^tis illis, vnde executio versus eos petita est, quam praed' R.
and I. seperatim habent in tenementis praed' vnde executio versus eos
singulatim petita est, seperatim petunt iudicium, si praed' I. executione^ inde
versus eos habere debeat etc. Et praed' I. dicit, quod tempore leuationis finis
illius, praed* I. and I. qui fuerunt parts finis illius, fuerunt Issue that I.
was seisied at the time of the fine levied.
seisiti de tenementis praed' cum pertinen^, vnde executio versus praed' W. and
A. seperatim in forma and modo praedict^ secuta est, prout per finem illum
supponiour, and hoc petit etc. Ideo xij. etc.

Cum quidam finis leuasset in curia domini E. quondam regis Angliae Scire

aui nostri, a die sanctae Trinitatis in quindecim dies, anno etc. coram I. de

comitatu tuo scire faceres p^dict^ Iohannae, quod esset coram Iusticiar^
nostris apud Westminster a die sancti Michaelis in quindecim dies proxim^

idem I. postea in eadem curia nr^a dixit quod predict^ Anthonius sequeretur

ideo tibi praecipimus, quod per bonos etc. scire facias praedicto N. quod sit
etc. apud Westmon^ a die etc. ad respondent' prefato A. simul cum predicta
Iohanna de praedicto placito si voluerit* Et habeas ibi nomina etc. Test etc.

Certain cases of the nature and form of a Sci. Fa. upon a fine.
ANd a Scire fac. to execute a fine, must agree with the fine, and then Sect.
179. Surplusage.
it is not material, if one thing be twice demanded thereby, as a manner and a
hundred parcel of the same manner, 27. H. 8. 2.

A Scire facias may be sued upon the note of the fine, before it be engrossed
Upon the note.
by the Cirographer, 22. H. 6. 13.

But of a fine levied before time of memory, a man shall not have execution A
fine before memory.
by Scire facias, 1. E. 4. 6. Contr^ 16. H. 7. 9.

Where a fine executory is levied of a Seigniory, if the land escheat, Of land
in lieu of the services.
or the tenant be foriudged etc. the Cognizee shall have a Scire facias of the
land in lieu of the services, 48. E. 3. 11.

A Mittimus makes no mention whether the fine be engrossed or no, cum quidam
finis leuasset etc. 22. H. 6. 13.

If a fine be levied to A. in tail, the remainder to B. in tail, the
remainder Mittimus, at the suit of him in the first remainder, and thereupon he
had a Scire facias to execute the fine, and died without issue before execution
had, he in the remainder in fee shall not hereupon have a Scire facias, without
a new commandment, because the record was once out of the Court, and came
again at the suit of him in the first remainder, unto whom he in the remainder
in fee is an estranger, yet thissue of him, which removed the record in this
cause, might have a Scire facias, without any new commandment, because he is
privy, 14. H. 7. 16. 9. E. 4. 15. 11. E. 4. 13.

If two sue a Scire fac' to execute a fine, and the one dies, the sur^^or
Scire fac' without any new commandment, 1. E. 4. 13.

But if diverse persons, as heirs unto A. B. pray a Scire fac' it is not 11. E.
4. 13. T. 21. E. 4.

In a Scire facias to execute a fine, as cousin and heir to him in the
remainder Coment cousin and heir.
or reuersion, after the death of the particular tenant, the plaintiff needs
not to show how cousin and heir, so long as the plea has continuance by Idem
dies etc. given to the tenant, nor at his appearance, nor until the plaintiff
pray execution: And then the coment cousin and heir, is to be entered thus in
the Roll only: Et praedictus I. dicit quod ipse est consanguineus and haeres
I. W. videlicet, filius and haeres T. W. fratris and haeredis eiusdem I. W. 33.
H. 6. 54. 41. E. 3. 13. and 24. 8. H. 4. 31.

In Scire facias by him in the remainder upon an estate tail verse A. Bastardy.
B. supposing the donee to be dead without issue, if A. B. plead that he is
issue to the donee, and the plaintiff replieth that he is a bastard, it is a
good replication, 40. E. 3. 16.

Scire facias upon a fine levied to T. R. and W. and to the heirs of Upon
estate executed.
the body of R. the remainder to the right heirs of the said W. T. died, and
R. died without issue, and W. suruiued and died, his heirs need no Scire
facias to execute this fine, because it is executed in his life, by the union
of the fee and franktenement in W. 40. E. 3. 20. And so if a fine be levied to
baron and feme, and to W. and his heirs, and he dies, and then the baron and
feme do die, the fine is executed for one moitie in the life of W. Fitz h.
Scire fac' 19. 42. E. 3. 9. 24. E. 3. 57.

Tenant for life in Scire facias had aid of him in remainder, 41. E. 3. Ayd^.
fol. 16. and 20. 22. E. 3. 12.

In Formedon in Reuerter or Remainder, the demandant must mention Death showed
the death of every one, which had estate and suruiued his auncester. But not
so in a Scire facias sur fine, 42. E. 3. 19.

If the plaintiff have several estates created by one fine, needs but
Several estates.
one writ of Scire fac'. 43. E. 3. 11. though it be of several things against
several tenants, 11. H. 4. 15. 21. E. 3. 14. 24. B. 3. 25.

If in a Scire facias the Shirife cetorne the party summoned, and he Default.
appear not, execution shall be awarded, 43. E. 3. 13. ^

If a fine sur cognizance de droit come ceo etc. be levied of a reuersion
Reuersion.
by the name of the land, it is not executory, 43. E. 3. 15.

If the services escheat after a fine levied of the seigniory, the Cognizee
Seigniory.
shall have execution of the land escheated, 48. E. 3. 11.

A Scire fac' lies sometimes of things not comprised in the writ: as Of things
ou^ of the writ.
if in a fine sur releas, the Cognizee render rent in tail, 49. E. 3. 8.

If land be given by fine for life, the remainder to baron and feme in
Execution by entry of him in remainder.
tail, and the baron dies, and then the tenant for life dies, and the feme
enters, the fine is execute, so as their issue needs no Sci. fac' 49. E. 3.
12.

Scire facias lies for the donor in tail against any that abateth after Of a
Reuersion.
the death of the donee in tail by fine without issue, 22. E. 3. 12.

Upon general Nontenure pleaded, the plaintiff may take execution at Nontenure
general or special.
his peril: But special Nontenure seems a good plea, 7. H. 6. 25.

A man shall not have execution upon nihil returned, because the tenant Nihil
returned.
may be summoned in the land demanded, 24. E. 3. 25.

If a fine be levied to husband and wife in tail, the remainder to his Demi
sank.
right heirs, and they having issue, the husband dies, the wife has issue by
another husband and dies, thissue by the first husband, enters and dies
without issue and his next heir enters as into the remainder in fee, against
whom the issue by the second husband brings a Scire fac', and recouereth, by
reason that the fee could never execute in possession, in thelder brother,
during the state tailly, 24. E. 3. 30. and 62.

Feoffement with warranty from the plaintifes auncestor is a good Feoffement*
plea in Scire facias upon a fine, 22. H. 6. 39.

The heir shall have his age in Scire fac' Contr^ Westminster 2. cap. 45.

What fines with proclamations bar not thissue in tail.
NO fine levied by tenant in tail barreth his issue maintenant, but Sect. 180.
where the tenant in tail is cognizor, as if tenant in tail bring a writ of
Covenant against an Estranger, and recognize the land to be the right of the
tenant in tail, as that which he has of his gift etc. and the tenant in
tail grant and render the land to the cognizor for years, yielding rent etc.
and die, this fine is void against thissue in tail. M. 10. and 11. Eliz. Dyer
f. 279. p. 7. 36. H. 8. Br. fines 118.

A fine with proclamation levied by tenant in tail, the reuercion or Br.
fines. 121. But if such lands wear entailed by the king, such fine barreth not
thissue in tail. 32. H. 8. ca. 36.

If an Estr^ levy a fine to tenant in tail sur cognizanee de droit and he
render to him a rent in fee, and die after proclamation, yet thissue in tail
may avoid it, for he is remitted, and the rent is another thing then the land.
15. Eliz. Plo. fol. 435. b. per Thornton.

If tenant in tail of an aduowson, grant and render by fine the nomination
15. Eliz. Pl. f. 435. b. per Thornton.

If tenant in tail of a rent disseise the tenant of the land, and levy a per
Thornton, and granted 15. Eliz. Plo. f. 435. b.

If tenant in tail grant a rent by fine, his issue may avoid it. 15.

What time after a fine levied, and proclamation made, any man has to enter or
claim by action, or otherwise, and who are thereby barred forthwith, and who
not.
Hitherto of the forms and execucion of fines, now let see how they may be
avoided. TO know what time, persons, that have cause to enter or claim, may
Sect. 181.
enter or claim, after a fine levied, many things are to be weyed: for some
persons have more time, and some less: for the discussing of which question,
we must not only consider the quality of the persons, which should claim or
enter, but also the quality of their rights and estates: And the parsons be
either such, as are void of impediments, or such as have impediments: And the
same be either parties, or, priuies to the fine, or, estrangers to the same.
And again, they have either present right, or, future right: And unto those
which have future right, such have the same, either wholly after the fine, or,
partly before, and partly after: And some of them, have, but one title, and
some diverse: And, others have no right to the tenements comprised in the fine,
but to some things therein, or, issuing out of the same.

Parties to fines, void of impediments at the time of the leuying of Parties.
the same, and their heirs, are thereby barred presently, and have no time at
all, to avoid the same, by entree, or claim, 1. R. 3. ca. 7. 4. H. 7. c. 24.
whether they be persons, having natural capacities, or, civil.

If they be such civil bodies, or, corporations, as have in themselves Plow.
338. a. T. 20. Eliz.

But, Deanes, Bishops, Priors, Abbots, Masters of Hospitals, Parsons, Iuris
vtrum, Fitzh. Not. fol. 48. r. or, sine assensu capituli: Fitz. Not. fol. 118.
i. are not barred by such fines if the patron and ordinary join not with
them. Plow. 538. a 20. Eliz. 375. b. 11. Eliz.

How priuies in blood, are bound in fines.
ANd by the same statuts 1. R. 3. c. 7. 4. H. 7. c. 24. Priuies in blood, Sect.
182. Priuies.
as heirs of the cognizours, claiming by the same title, that their ancester
had, that levied the fine, be barred presently thereby, whether they be void of
impedime^ts, or no. As if lands of Socage tenure, be given to baron and feme,
in special tail, the remainder to the right heirs of the baron in fee, and the
baron sole leuieth a fine with proclamation to his own use in fee, and after
deuiseth the same lands to A. in fee, and has issue, and then the baron and
feme die, thissue in tail is barred, because he can not otherwise convey
himself to the title and descent in tail, then as heir of the body does of
his father and mother. Tr. 18. Eliz. Dyerf. 251. p. 24. 9. H. 8. Dier f. 3. p.
6. 32. H. 8. Br. Fines 109.

So if husband and wife, tenants in special tail, have issue, and the wife
Priuies.
die, and the husband marry an other wife and have issue, and levy a fine sur
cognizance de droit come ceo etc. and by the same fine take estate in special
tail, the remainder over etc. and die, thissue by the first wife, is barred,
because he is privy in blood, the continuance of the possession in the husband
notwithstanding, 32. E. 3. Dyer pla. 16. Eliz. f. 334. p. 31. and 32.

But if my fathers brother disseise him, and levy a fine with proclamation, P.
19. H. 8. Dyer fol. 3. p. 2.

Nevertheless, if my father disseise my graund father of an estate in Priuies.
fee, and thereof levy a fine with proclamation, and first my graundfather,
and then my father die, I am now barred, as privy, because I cannot otherwise
convey my self to the lands, then as their unto my father the Cognizor, P. 19.
H. 8. Dyer fol. 3. p. 3.

Of Estraungers having present right, and no impediment.
BUt Estraungers to fines (which be all persons not parties nor priuies) Sect.
183.
and being void of impediments natural and legal, having present right to the
lands in the fine, have only five years after proclamations, to enter and
claim their right, 1. R. 3. ca. 7. 4. H. 7. ca. 24.

As if one have a Remainder, or a Reuersion, depending upon an Tenant in
remainder or reuersion upon estate for years, or at will.
estate for years, or by statute Staple, statute Merchant, or Elegit, and the
termor be disseised, and a fine levied etc. and five years passed, they be all
barred thereby: for that these Termors might presently have entered, and he in
the Reuersio^ or Remainder for such disseisin might have had an Assise: So that
Statute 4. H. 7. ca. 24. seems to bar the termors through negligence, by
this word interest, which comprehends a term. Plow. fol. 374. a.

And if a tenant in tail be disseised, and a fine levied with proclamation,
per Dyer and Catlyn, for the right was present to the tenant in tail at the
time of the fine levied, and he can not claim, but by the same title, which
his father had, which was barred in his life time, Plow. fol. 374. a. Dyer fol.
3. p. 6. 19. H. 8. 7. The like it is of the laches of him in the remainder or
reuersion, for it barreth him and his heirs, Plow. fol: 374. a. Dyer fo. 3. p.
6.

Of Estrangers having present Right and impediments.
BUt estraungers to fines, pestered with impediments, of Infancy, Sect. 184.
couerture, madness, ideocy, lunacy, imprisonment, or absence out of the Realm
at the leuying of fines, and having then present right, or interest, have yet
liberty five years, after such infirmity removed, to make entry, or claim,
etc. 1. R. 3. ca. 7. 4. H. 7. ca. 24.

And therefore an Infant has five years, after he accomplish his full Infants.
age (though he be in his mothers womb) Plow. 367. a. because the law
intends that Infants by reason of their tender years, do want understanding,
to know their right, and whether their entries be lawful or no, And how to
make their entries and claim, or bring their actions, according to their
title, Plow. fol. 359. b. 4. H. 7. ca. 24.

Yet if my fathers brother disseise him, and leauie a fine with proclamation,
Dyer fol. 3. p. 2. In like manner, and for the same reason, if the father, or
other auncester, be disseised, and the disseisor levy a fine with
proclamation, and within five years after the proclamation, the auncester
dies, his heir being within age, yet if he make not his entry, or claim,
within the first five years after the proclamation, he is barred, Plow. fol.
367. b. 377. a. As it is there adjudged.

Mad men, and lunatiques, estrangers to fines, have the like liberty, Non sane
memoriae.
to enter, or claim, that Infants have for their indiscretion, 1. R. 3. c. 7.
4. H. 7. ca. 24. Yet, as it seems, if non sanitie of memory happen after ye
fine levied, and before the last proclamation to be made, the parties be not
tied to make claim or entry, during the first five years, but shall have five
years after they be cured of their said maladies, because they grow by the act
of God, Plow fol. 375. a. and 366. a.

And a Feme covert, being an estranger to a fine, has five years, after
Couerture.
she be discouert, to pursue her right, for that during the couerture, she
wanted power to do the same without her husbands consent, who perchance would
neither do it, nor suffer it to be done: Howbeit if a Feme sole being an
estranger to a fine, and have present right etc. take a husband, who suffers
the five years to incur, she is thereby barred for ever, because it was her
own voluntary act and folly to marry such an husband. Plowd. fol. 366. a.

Estra^gers to fines, imprisoned at the time of the fine levied, have the
Imprisonm^t.
like liberty to avoid fines, that Infants have, because the law inte^deth,
that prisoners are so closely and straictly kept from the conference of others,
that they know not, what happens abroad, And do also want liberty to take
counsel, and make their entrees and claims, and therefore no laches is in
this behalf imputed to them. Plo. f. 360. a. and 366. a. But if such
imprisonment happen after the fine levied, before the last proclamation made,
it seems he shall have 5. years after his enlargement, because thimprisonment
is not his voluntary act. Plow. 375. a. 366. a.

An Estr^ to a fine, being out of the realm, at the leuying thereof, has Out
of England.
5. years after his return to enter or claim, But if he had bin in England
at the leuying of the fine and after had gone beyond the seas, and suffered the
5. years after proclamation to pass, he had been barred. Plo. f. 366. a. 7.
Eliz. 4. H. 7. ca. 24. But if he be sent beyond the seas in the kings service
by his commandment, it seems otherwise.

And such civil bodies or corporatio^s, as have in themselves absolute
Corporations.
estate and authority of their possess so as they may maintain a writ of
Right thereof, as, Mayor and Co^minaltie, Deane and chapter, colleges,
societies incorporate, and such like, they and their successors, are barred by
fine and nonclaime by 5. years. Plo. f. 538. T. 20. Eliz.

But, Deanes, Bishops, Priors, Abbots, Masters of hospitals, Parsons,
Corporations.
vicars, prebendaries, chauntrie priests, and such like, having joint power,
and which may not have a writ of Right, but either a Iuris vtrum, Fitz. Not. f.
48. r. or, fine assensu capituli, Fitz. Not. f. 118. i. are not barred by such
fines, and nonclaime by 5. years. Plow. 538. a. 20. Eliz. 375. b. 11. Eliz.

Of Estrangers having diverse defects,
ANd moreover, estrangers to fines, having diverse defects or insirmities, Sect.
185.
as infa^cy couerture, non sanitie of memory, imprisonment, absence out of the
realm, to avoid fines, must have 5. years after the last of the said
infirmities removed. Plow. 375. a.

But if they have diverse impedime^ts, which be al, once after the proclation,
said five years, binds them, as their said auncesters should have been bound
thereby, if they had remained void of such impediments during all the same five
years, Plow. f. 375. a

Of Estrangers, without impediments, having future Right for cause precedent.
THus much of Estrangers to fines, having present right: now of Sect. 186.
such, as have future right, which right is of two sorts: for it grows,
either wholly before the proclamation, or, partly before and partly after the
same.

And therefore Estr^ to fines, void of the said impediments, whose 1. R. 3.
ca. 7. 4. H. 7. ca. 24. As if a Morgagee be disseised, and the disseisor does
levy a fine with Proclamation, and the five years after the proclamation the
morgageour paieth or tendreth the money according to his bargain, he may
lawfully enter at any time within five years after the said payment or tender,
because his title first accrueth thereby after the proclamation, by reason of
the condition and morgage made before the same. Plow. fol. 378. a. b.

In like manner, and for the like cause, he, which has a Remainder or Plow.
fol. 374. a. b.

And if the tenant in tail levy a fine with proclamation, after y^ five Plow.
fol. 374. b.

And if tenant in tail discontinew in fee, and the discontinuee leuieth Plow.
374. a. 19. H. 8. 7. Dyer f. 3. p. 5.

Of Estrangers with Impediments having future Right.
ANd Estrangers to fines, having future right for any cause precedent Sect. 187.
the fine, being affected with such impediments, when their right first
accreweth have five years after such impedime^ts removed, to pursue for the
same. 1. R. 3. c. 7. 4. H. 7. c. 24. As Infants, as well those which be borne, as
those which be in their mothers womb, when such right happens to them. Plo.
fo. 367. a. Femes covert, madmen, Lunatiques, prisoners, persons beyond the
Sea, as appears before where it is spoken of them having present right. Plo.
366. a. 7. Eliz.

As if a man have issue a son and a daughter, which son purchases Plo. fo.
374. b.

But if an estranger to a fine, to whom a Remainder, or other title, first 19.
H. 8. Dyer fo. 3. pl. 6.

And in like manner, if the first issue in tail, to whom the title of the
intaile 32. H. 8. Br. Fines 100.

If he, which abaceth after the death of a tenant in fee, make a feoffement
Assise of mortdauncester against thabator, or entry upon him at any time, and
he has no defense. For if he plede in bar of the assise the fine levied to
the cognisee, and that he has his estate, the special matter of the
abatement, condition, and reentrie, may be pleaded in defesance thereof, for he
can never challenge privilege by the state of the cognisor, which he himself
defeated, Plo. fol. 358. b. 7. Eliz.

Of Estrangers having no right for any cause before the fine.
But estrangers to fines, having neither present, nor future right etc. Sect*
188.
at the leuying thereof, by reason of any matter had before the fine, whose
right grows either entirely after the Proclamation, or partly before and
partly after, may enter or claim, when they please, within the time of the
prescription.

As if the father die seized, his eldest son being professed, and the younger
Plow. fo. 373. a.

So if the husband leuy a fine of his own lands, whereof his wife is Dowe^
dowable, and die, and five years pass after his death she is not barred of
her dower, because her title to be endowed accrueth after the fine levied,
namely by the death of her husband, for before his death, she had only a
possibility of dower, and not any right, title, or interest thereunto, Plo.
fol. 373. a.

And if a tenant cease one year, and then a fine with proclamation is cessauit
perbiennium xx. years after the Proclamation made, because his right and title
grows partly before the fine, and partly after the fine levied, that is at
the end of the two years of his tenants ceasser, Plo. fo. 373. b.

Of Estrangers having diverse future Rights, by diverse titles.
But if Estrangers to fines, have several future Rights, by diverse titles Sect*
189.
growing at several times, it seems, that they shall have several five
years, to make entry or claim, commencing from such time as their several
titles first accrewe unto them: As if tenant for life, the remainder in fee,
make a feoffement in fee. And the feoffee leuy a fine with etc. and he in the
Remainder suffer the first five years to pass, he is by his laches barred of
his entry, for the forfaiture growing by the alienation of his tenant during
his tenant for life, because he had present right at the leuying of the fine to
enter for the same, yet if after the tenant for life do die, he has other v.
years, to bring his Formedon in Remainder, because that is a n^we title or
right, by which he could not have his Formedon during his tenant for life,
And he had his election to take advantage of the forfaiture or not, Plo. fo.
373. b. Quere, for there Catlyn thinks otherwise, because his title to the
land by the forfaiture accrued to him in the life time of his tenant for life.

If I. S. be tenant Pur auter vie, the Remainder to an other for life, cestuy
que vie, and he in the mean remainder die, now, I. S. shall have other five
years, to enter for his remainder in fee, for it then first remains unto him
by the death of him in the mean Remainder, and cestuy que vie, for cause
grown wholly before the fine, that is, the state so made before, which is an
other title, Plowden 367. b. per Welshe, and diverse Justices, Plow. 367. b.

In like maker, if land: be given to I. S. for the life of A. the remainmainder
Saving of the Stat^. 4. H. 7. cap. 24. And v. years after the death of A. by
the second Saving, which is of future right, and other v. years after the
death of B. for his second remainder, for quando duo iura in vna persona
concurrunt, aequum est, ac si essent in diuersis, Plo. 368. a.

If a man disseise a feme sole, and after marry her, and have issue by Plow.
367. b.

So if the husband makes a feoffement of his wives lands upon condition, Plo.
367. a.

Estrangers to fines, having neither present, nor future right, to the
tenements in the fine, at the leuying thereof, but only unto rents, common,
etc. issuing out of the same.
ANd Estrangers to fines, having neither present, nor future right to Sect* 190*
the tenements in the fine, but unto some thing, in, or, issuing out of the
same, seem not barrable at all, by any such fine and nonclaime. As if a tenant
in Ancient demes^e leuy a fine with etc. at the common law, of his lands in
ancient demes^e, the Lord in ancient demes^e may have his writ of Deceit,
and thereby avoid the fine at any time, and thereupon his tenant shall be
restored to the land, because the Lord claims not the land, whereof the fine
is levied, but his ancient Seigniory and services issuing out of the same,
Plo. 370. b.

It seems, such fines do not bar such estrangers, as have rent, common,
Brook tit^ Fines 123.

Pleas to a^oide Fines.
IT is a good plea to say, that I. S. was seized tempore leuac', and before
Sect* 191.
the fine levied, without that that the parties to the fine, had any thing
therein at the time o^ the fine levied, 9. H. 4. 27. 3. H. 6. 27.

Or to say, that the parties to a fine had nothing etc. but A. B. whose Et de
hoc ponit se super pri^am, 33. H. 6. 18. 26. H. 6. f. 9. 42. E. 3. 20. 4. H. 4.
8. 14. H. 4. 33. 4. H. 7. ca. 24.

If there be two R. D. of one name, and the one leuy a fine of the land of 34.
H. 6. 19. Contr^ ten^ 19. H. 6. 44. because it is a matter of record,
therefore has no other remedy in such case but an action of disceit.

Neither parties to fines, nor their heirs, may plead in auoidance Stat^ de
finibus 27. E. 1. ca. 1. 12. E. 4, 15 and 19. yet by Fairefax, if tenant in
tail, the remainder in fee, levy a fine sur cognizance de droit come ceo etc.
he in the remainder, may auerre the continuance of possession, notwithstanding
the fine and statute, because he is neither the party, nor his heir, and so
may a Feme covert, where her husband sole leuieth the fine, 12. E. 4. 12.

The issue in tail may auerre continuance of possession against a fine sur
cognizance de droit tantum, or surrender, but not against a fine sur cognizance
de droit come ceo que il ad de son done, because that fine is executed, and the
other executorie, 12. E. 4. 15. and 19. 11. H. 4. 85.

Of a writ of Error.
A Writ of Error to reuerse a fine, lies where there is Error in any Sect' 192.
fine, and thereby not the record of the fine it self shall be removed, but the
transcript thereof, upon which transcript of the note of the fine, the
plaintiff may assign his errors: And if the Justices think, that the point
assigned for error, is error, they may send for the note of the fine, and
reuerse the same, Fitz. not. fo. 20. f. As if baron and feme levy a fine to an
estraunger, the feme being within age, they may have a writ of error to reuerse
the fine, for this cause during her nonage, Fitz. not. 21. d. 27. ass. pl. 17.
50. E. 3. 4. And when a fine is to be reuersed by error, the course is for the
plaintiff in the writ, to have several writs of Error, one directed unto the
chief Justice of the court of Common plees to certify the record and process
of the fine, another unto the Custos br. of the same court to certify the
transcript of the foot of the fine, and the third unto the Chirographer to
certify the transcript of the record and process of the fine: the several
forms whereof be, as follows.

A writ of Error directed unto the chief Justice of the court of common plees.
Regina etc. dilecto and fideli suo Edm. Anderson Militi, salutem. Quia in
record' and processu, ac etiam in leuatione cuiusdam finis in cur^ nr^a, coram
vobis and socijs vestris Iustic' nostris de banco, apud Westminster in octabis S.
Michaelis vltimo preteritis, per breue nostrum de conuentione inter I. G.
seniorem armig' and M. vxor^ eius and I. G. iuniorem generosum querent^ and G.
H. deforc', de manerio de G. cum pertin^, ac de vno messuagio, xv. cottagijs,
quindecim toftis, quatuor horreis, quindecim gardinis, duobus pomarijs,
ducentis acr^ terre, octoginta acr^ prati, centum acr^ pasture, sex acr^ bosci
trescentis acr^ more, and communia pasture pro omnibus auerijs com pertin^ in
G. in com^ Ebor^ leuat^, error interuen^t manifestus, ad grave dampnum ipsius
G. sicut ex querela sua accepimus: Nos err^rem, si quis fuerit, modo debito
corrigi, and eid' G. plenam and celere^ Iustic' fieri volentes in hac part,
vobis mandamus quod recordum and processum finis praed', cum omnibus ea
tangen^, que in custodia vestra existunt vt dicit^, nobis sub sigillo vestro
distinct and a perte mittatis, and hoc breue, Ita quod ea nabeamus in octabis
S. Hill', vbicunque tunc fuerim' in Angl', vt inspectis recordo and processu
finis p^d', vlterius inde pro errore illo corrigendo* fierifaciamus, qd' de
iure and secund' legem and co^suetud' regni nostri Angl' fuerit faciend' etc.

A writ of Error unto the Custos breuium of the Court of Common plees. Regina
etc. dilecto sibi Tho. Spencer armig', custodi breuium suoru^ de banco salutem.
Quia in recordo and processu, ac etiam in leuatione cuiusda^ finis in cur^ nr^a
de Banco apud Westminster in oct^ sancti Mich. vltim^ p^terito, coram Ed. Anderson
Milite and socijs suis Iustic' nr^is de banco p^dict^ per breue nostrum de
conuentione inter etc. de etc. Vobis mandamus quod transcriptum pedis finis
praed', cum omnibus ill'tangen^, que in custod' vr^a existunt vt dicitur, nobis
sub sigillo vestro etc. vt Inspect^ transcript^ pedis finis praed' vlterius
inde etc.

A writ of Error unto the Chirographer of fines. Regina etc. dilecto sibi: Th:
Crompton Armig' Chirographario suo de Banco salutem, quia in recordo and
processu, ac etiam in leuacione cuiusdam finis in curia nostra de banco apud
Westminster in octabis S. Mich. vltimo preteritis, coram Ed. Anderson Milite, and
socijs suis Iustic' nr^ris de banco p^d', per breue nostrum de conuenc' into
etc. de etc. vobis mandamus, quod tra^scr^ recordi and processus finis p^d',
cum omnibus ill tangen^, que in custodia vr^a existunt vt dicitur, nobis sub
sigillo vr^o distinct' and apertemittatis and hoc breue etc. vt inspect'
transcript recordi and processus finis-praed' vlterius inde etc.

And note that a writ of Error, is not maintenable by an Infant, to reuerse a
fine for his Infancy, but during his Infancy, 50. E. 3. 4. 17. E. 3. 52. 78.
27. Lib. ass. 53.

For what Errors, sines and proclamations be not reuersable. No sines, or
proclamations upon sines, or common recoueries, shall be reuersable 23. Eliz. ca.
3.

Of Error in the proclamation of a fine. If Error be in the procalmations of a
fine, they shall be reuersed by sublato subiecto tollitur eius accidens, Plow.
266. a. Dyer fol. 216. p. 54. 4. Eliz.

Of a Cerciorari.
IF a man have recovered, and before he have execution, the Records Sect' 193.
thereof be removed into the receipt or Treasory, the plaintiff may have a
Cerciorari our of the Chancery to the Chamberlain and Treasorer, to remove the
tenor of the Record and process thence into the Chauncerie, And when it is
there, it may be sent thence by Mittimus into the Court whence it came, as the
Kings bench, if it came thence: or into the common Place, if it came thence,
and there may execution be sued, 37. H. 6. 16.

A Certiorari with a Mittimus, to remove a fine, bearing date before the 1. R.
3. 4.

In a writ of Error to reuerse a fine, the Record it self shall not be
removed, 40. ass. 19. 29. ass. 43.

Yet 5. Marie, it is holden that in a writ of Error upon a fine, the record Br.
Tit^ Record 79. Ideo quere.

A Certiorari of the transcript of the foot of a fine. Rex, Thesaurario and
Camerarijs, salutem: Quia quibusdam certis de leuati in curia nostra, coram
Iusticiarijs nostris dudum vel vltimo itinerantibus apud N. in com^ tali per
breue nostrum, vel in curia dn^i Ed. nuper Regis Anglie aui nostri, vel patris
nostri, anno regni sui decimo etc. coram l. and socijs suis tunc lustic'
eiusdem aui nostri, vel, patris nostri de banco, per breue suum, inter A.
petentem, and B. tenentem, de vno messuagio cum pertin^ in N. vobis mandamus
quod, scrutatis pedibus finium de eodem itinere tempore praedicto leuatorum,
vel finium coram p^fatis Iusticiarijs anno praedicto leuatorum, qui sunt in
Thesaurario nostr^ sub custodia vestra vt dicunt, transcriptum pedis finis
praedicti nobis in Cancellariam nostram sub sigillo scaccarij nostri distinct
and aperte sine dilatione mittatis, and hoc breue. Test etc.

Rex dilecto clerico suo W. salutem, volentes certis etc. super tenore A liter
de tenore non finis.
note cuiusdam finis leuati etc. anno etc. inter A. petentem, andC. tenente^

transcript^ note praed' nobis in Cancellar^ nr^am sub sigillo vestro distinct

A Mittimus of the Transcript of a fine out of the Chauncery into the Common
place.
DOmin' Rex, mand' Iustic' hic breue suum clam^, in hec verba, Hen^ Sect. 194.
etc. Iustic' suis de banco, salutem, transcript^ pedis cuiusd' finis leuat^ in

manerio de C. cum pertin^, nobis in Cancell' nr^a de mandato nr^o missum, vobis
mittimus presentibus inter clus. mandantes, quod inspect^ praed' vlterius ad
prosecutionem I. L. and M. vxor^ eius vnius, and T. V. and T. vxor^ eius
alterius, necnon H. B. tertij consang' and hered' praed' G. and I. de corpor^
suis procreat^, fieri facias quod de iure and secundum legem and consuetudin^m
regni nr^i Angliae fuerit faciend'. Test meipso apud W. octauo die I. anno
regni nostri decimo septimo: Transcript^ pedis finis, vnde in breui praedict^
fit mentio, sequitur in hec verba: Hec est finalis concordia facta in cur^
domini Regis apud W. in Oct' sancti M. anno etc. cora^ R. H. W. B. P. M. W. H.
L. T. and H. S. Iusticiarijs, and alijs domini Regis fidelibus tunc ibidem
presentibus, inter G. P. and I. vxor^ eius quer^, per W. F. posit^ loco eorum
ad lucrand' vel perdend', and S. Attorney in fine.
P. deforc' de manerio de C. cum pertinentijs, vnde placitum conuentionis
summonit^ fuit inter eos in eadem curia, scilicet quod prae G. recogn^ prae
maner^ cum pertinen^ esse ius ipsius S. vt illud quod idem S. habet de dono
praedict' G. and pro hac recogn^, fine and concordia, idem S. concessit praed'
G. and I. praed' manerium cum pertinentijs and illud eis reddidit in eadem
curia, habend' and tenend' eisd' G. and I. and hered', quos ide^ Render in tail

service.
pro omni seruitio considerac' and exactione ad praed' S. and hered' suos

contingat Rem^ in tail.
qnod praed' G. obierit sine hered' de corpore ipsius I. procreat^, tunc post

Whether any but he, which reuerseth a fine, may reap benefit thereby.
IF the estate, con^eined i^ a fine, be once within fi^e years after
proclamations Sect. 196.
lawfully defeated, That party has thereby lost his whole estate both against
him which did reuerse the same, and all others which had right or title
peramont, and made no claim within the five years: Al^eit he which brought
his action have not judgment and execution within 7. years after the
proclamations, P^o. fol. 358. b.

In like manner if there b^ tenant for life, the remainder for life, the Plowd.
fol. 359. a. 7. Eliz.

Warrantia chartae.
A Writ of Warrantia charte, lie^h where a man by deed of grant, Sect. 197.
feoffement, releas, or confirmation, or fine, or by exchange, binds himself
and his heirs to warrant the land to an other, who being tenant of the land
is impleaded for the land, or rent out of the same, in an Assis^, or writ of
(...) in (...) of an Assi^e, or in a Scire facias upon a fine, or in any other
action real, wherein the tenant may not vouch, he may sue a Warrantia chartae,
against him, and his heirs which made warrantie. And for a tenant by homage
auncestrel, or any particular tenant upon reservation of rent, or for egalty of
services upon particion, Fitz. Not. f. 1^4. d. f. g. h. Fitz. Not. 135. e. 31.
E. 3. 8. E. 4. 11.

Rex etc* quod just etc. wa^antizet D. vnu^fi messuagium cum pertinentijs
Brief de Warrantia chartae.
in R. qd' tenet, and d^ eo t^nere cla^nat, and vnde chartam suam habet vt
dicit. Et si etc. vel sic. Manerium de N. cum pertinentiis, and aduocationem
eiusdem villae, quae tenet etc. vsque ibi, vnde charta^ suam habet, vel chartam
R. patris, vel matris, vel alterius antecessoris praedicti H. cuius haeres ipse
est, vt dicit. Et nisi etc. vel

De eo quod idem A. wa^antizet praefato D. maneria de N. and K.

But if a man in feoffe an other with warrantie by ^eede, and the Fitz. not.
fol. 135. a.

So if A. disseise B. and infeoffe C. with warrantie, who infeoffeth Fitz. not.
135. g. 21. H. 6. 41. 22. H. 6. 22.

per Iointenants.
deraigne the former warrantie by voucher, or Warrantia chartae, for they be in
a third part by the release, 40. E. 3. 41.

Warrantia chartae lies against a villein, 48. E. 3. 17. Villenage.


The writ of Warr^ cha^tae must be sued ha^ging the principal plea, and Assise,
or Enter in nature of assise, 48. E. 3. 22. Registr^ orig' f. 158. a. for then
if the warrenter do die, yet the writ shall not abate, but his heir shall be
resummoned to answer upon the same, yet may a Warr' chartae be sued before he
be impleaded, quia timet implacitari, and the bl shall recover in valne pro loco
and tempore, of such lands as the defenda^t had at the purchasing of the writ.
Fitz. na. f. 134. k. 12. H. 4. 12. 21. H. 6. 41. 22. H. 6. 22. 24. E. 3. 35.
But he must not have execution, but if afterward he be put out by judgment,
he shall have his warranty upon his first recovery. 21. H. 6. 41. 21. H. 6. 22.
12. H. 4. 12.

In Warr^ chartae, it is a good plea for the defenda^t, that hanging the
Nontenure.
plea, the demandant in the principal plee, has entered upon the plaintiff
being then tenant of the land, or that the plaintiff in this actio^ had nothing
in the land the day of the fist writ purchased, nor at any time after. 21. H.
6. 49. 3. E. 3. 45. E. 3. 5.

Warr' chartae may be brought in any county, if the deed bear not County.
date in a place certain. 31. E. 3.

Tenants in commen may join in Warr' Chartae. 28. E. 3. 90. Tenant in comen.

SYMBOLEOGRAPHY, Of Recoueries for Assurances etc. called common, or feigned
Recoueries.
IN every Recovery are to be regarded the demandant, Sectio 1.
Enter, as in writs of Covenant, whereupon fines are levied. The end and effect
of such recoueries, is to discontinue and distroy estates tails, remainders,
and reuersions, and baire the former owners thereof.

The Demaundant is he that brings the writ of Enter, and may

The Tenant is he, against whom the writ is brought, and may be

The Vouchee is he, whom the tenant voucheth, or calls to warranty

And such persons may be demaundants, tenants, and vouchees, in Covenant, and
by such names, Mutatis mutandis. Saving that if any recovery be had against any
tenant in tail, the reuersion or remainder being in the Queen, of the gift of
the Queen, or of any of her Majesty's progenitors, kings of England: such
recovery will neither bar the issue in tail of his Enter, nor discontinue
his estate, nor pluck such reuersion or remainder out of her Majesty, 34. H.
8. cap. 20. Quaere tamen si tiel recovery bar lissue in tail, during the
continuance of the estate tail, Dyer fol. 132. pla. 1.

Item before such persons, by such means, and in such manner may Dedimus
potestatem. And fines must be paid upon writs of Enter, as upon writs of
Covenant. And all such writs of Enter must be signed by the Queens Attorney
before they can be sealed.

In a Recovery with double voucher, the fine must bt sued first to Enter must
always be brought against him that is tenant of the freehold of the land
demanded at the time of the writ brought, 18. R. 2. and Dyer fol. 252. pla.
98. for that, that the estate of the tenant in tail which is vouchee, is
barred in respect of the assets only which is, or may be recovered in value.
Plow. Basset verse Manxel fol. 11. a, and of execution sued by the tenant
against him.

And if the tenant have but an estate for life, or in dower, or by the
courtesy:

See the like Surrender in the Chapter of Surrenders, in the first part of
Symboleography.

Of what things writs of Enter may be brought, and by what names.
PRaecipe quod reddat lies, de vna acra terre, aqua cooperta, vel de Sect* 2.


Praecipe quod reddat lies of all manner of Ecclesiastical or Spiritual

A Praecipe quod reddat lies detofro and situ molendini 14. Ed. 3. de Town,
and not in a Hamlet, 8. E. 3. fol. 55. 7. E. 3. 9.

Of what things a writ of Enter lies not.
PRaecipe quod reddat lies not, de fossato, nec de stagno, nee de piscaria
Sect' 3.
8. E. 3. 381. nec de deaduocatione, decimarum vnius carucat^ t^re, Registr^
fo. 29. nec de co^munia pastur^ 27. H. 8, f. 12. de estouerijs 2. E. 3. de
homagio and fidelitat^, nec de seruitijs faciendis 6. E. 2.

A Praecipe quod reddat lies not de bouat^ marisci 13. E. 3. fo. 3. de selione
for the incerteintie, because a Selon which is a land, sometime contains an
acre, sometime half an acre, sometime more, and sometimes less, It lies not
of a garden, cottage, or croft, 14. ass. 13. 8. H. 6. 3. 22. E. 4. 13. de
virgata terre 41. 43. 13. E. 3. defodina, de minera, de mercatu, 13. E. 3. for
they lie not in Demesne, but in Gain, nec de superiori camera 3. H. 6. fo. 1.

A writ of Enter ought not to contein one self thing twice, as a message, 2.
Ed. 4. fol. 28. 46. E. 3. fo. 26. Nor to name a Town and a Hamlet within the
same town, 22. E. 3 fol. 14. 41. Ed. 3. fol. 22.

In every warrant of Attorney it is good to put 2. Atturneis at the

In a county Palantine, as Lancaster, Durisme, Chester etc. may be

If the writ of Enter be returnable Crastino Martini, the writ of Summons
thereupon must bear Test from the return of Crastino Martini, and be
returnable ix. Returns after the return of the writ of Enter inclusiue: that
is accompting Crastino Martini for one of the ix. returns, and tres Paschae,
which is the ninth return after Crastino Martini for another. And the Test of
the writ of Seisin must be the day of that ninth return, and be returnable xv.
days after. Then the writ of Seisin may be returned, that seisin was delivered
by virtue thereof to the demandant, by the sheriff of the County where the
lands lie upon any day (not being Sunday) between the Test and return of the
said writ of Seisin. Then the writs of Enter, Summons, and Seisin must be
returned and filed with the Custos breuium, and the judgment entered by the
preignotary, and the warrants of Attorney by the Clark of the warrants.

If a single recovery and a fine be against the tenant, the writ of Enter
Test, before the writ of Covenant, and be returned before.

If a writ of Covenant be brought against the tenant, and a writ of Enter
against the demaundant: then the writ of Covenant must bear date, and be
returned before the writ of Enter, and this is called a double voucher.

A Certiorari to the executor of the Justice, before whom the Warrants were
acknowledged.

Et quod ijdem P. and W. habeant de terra praed' G. ad valentiam etc. Et quod
idem G. vlterius habeat de terr^ praedict^ D. ad valentiam etc. Et idem D in
misericordia etc. Et super hoc praedicti R. and R. petunt Misericordia.
breue dominae Reginae Vicecomiti comitatus praedict' dirigend', de habere
faciend' eis plenariam seismam de manerijs, tenementis, and redditu praedict'
cum pertinentijs. Et eis conceditur, returnabile hic a die S. Martini in
quindecim dies.

Ad quem diem hic venerunt praed' R. and R. in proprijs personis suis.

Test etc. Anno Regni nostr^ 36.
A Dedimus potestatem to take knowledge of a warrant of Attorney of the vouchee.
REx and Regina
dilecto and fideli suo Ra. To. seruienti ad legem salutem.

A common Recovery by diverse before the Justice of Chester and Judges of the
