SYMBOLEOGRAPHY. Of Indictments and Offenses.
Of Indictments.
AN Indictment is a bill or declaration Sect' 1.


In every indictment two things seem principally to be considered:

Wherefore as in my treatise of Extraiudicial Symbolaeography, I

Offense.
AN offense therefore is a fact done unlawful and forbidden by nature Sect' 2.
or Law, whether the same be in committing or omitting, whereof the one for
learning sake, may fitly be termed an offense, and the other a default, for in
Law, thought is free from offense.

Endeavor.
But so is not endeavor many times, because therein, is guile and purpose Sect'
3.
to offend.

Offense private and public.
ANd every offense is of thestate, public, or private, and is thereof Sect' 4.
so termed.

The description of both which offenses, is drawn sometime from the manner of
doing: but may perchance more fitly be taken from the object which is hurt,
unless some think good to conioine them both.

Symphathie between the common wealth and her members.
FOr certes, when a private person is offended, it cannot lightly be deuied,
Sect' 5.
but that the common wealth is thereby also offended, and again, the common
wealth being endammaged, how can it be chosen but every Subject thereof is
also affected, as being a member of the same.

So great a Sympathy and mutual suffering being in them, as between

But in as much as some offenses done, more merely respect private

Offense public and private.
A Public offense, is a grievous fault committed against the common Sect' 6.
wealth, A private offense is an offense against the wealth of a private person.

Offenses blind.
EVery offense of his own nature makes the offender bound to the Sect' 7.
common wealth, or to a private person, or to both, and not only they which
actually commit offense, but they also which command, persuade, counsel,
procure, abbet, aid or consent that an offense be perpetrated or conceal it
being done, are censured to offend.

Offenses named and unnamed.
ANd offenses are either named or unnamed. Sect' 8.


Offenses named be such offenses as have certain names in

Ofences unnamed.
Unnamed offenses be those which albeit they bin committed, yet Sect. 9.
have they no certain name set forth in our law, whereby they may be called.

Offenses named.
Again offenses named be either our own or other men's faults, by Sect' 10.
which we are bound, and they have a certain name in law, whereby to be termed.

Offenses simple.
Our own proper offenses be either simple or mixed. Sect' 11.


Our simple offenses be such as be committed by our own sayings

Offenses mixed.
ANd the mixed be those which be committed by words and deeds both Sect' 12.
together.

Offenses by word.
Offenses by sayings only, be they by which the mind, dignity, or Sect' 13.
fame of an other man (which is compared to life) is hurt and not his body,
and these are also done by counsel or by contumelious words.

Counsel.
BY Counsel, as through wicked persuasion.

Wicked persuasion is fraudulent counsel given to any, whereby Sect' 14.
his mind is corrupted and made worse to do or attempt any thing noughtly:
which yet does not induce necessity to do the thing, though it bind him that
gives such counsel.

Offense by contumelious words.
ANd offense or crime by words, is when through perverse words, Sect' 15.
the good name, credit, or dignity of a man is impaired.

Slander.
ANd it is either by voice or writing, and is called Slander, which Sect' 16.
is either against God or man.

Slander against God.
Slander against God, is whereby the Majesty divine is evil spoken Sect' 17.
off. Of this sort be blasphemy, Magic, Heresy, Apostasy, and Perjury.

Blasphemy.
Blasphemy is a wicked saying, or slander pronounced against God, Sect' 18.
touching his essence or word revealed.

Magic.
MAgitio^s be those which by uttering of certain superstitious words Sect' 19.
conceived, adventure to attempt things above the course of nature, by
bringing forth dead men's ghosts as they falsely pretended, in showing of things
either secret or in places far off, and in showing them in any shape or
likeness. These wicked persons by oath or writing written with their own
blood, having betaken themselves to the devil, have forsaken God, and broken
their covenant made in baptism, and detest the benefits thereof, and worship
the devil only. And settling their whole hope in him, do execute his
commandments, and being dead, commend both their bodies and souls unto him.

South saying wizards.
OF this kind of Magicians be al those which ensue, as Southsaiers Sect' 20.
or Wizards which divine and foretell things to come and raise up evil spirits
by certain superstitious and conceived forms of words. And unto such questions
as be demanded of them, do answer by voice, or else set before their eyes in
glasses, crystal stones, or rings, the pictures or images of things sought
for.

Divination.
THe professors of ^hart of Divination which be puffed up with prophesing Sect'
21.
spirits. And can manifest who has stolen things, and tell where things lost
or stolen be.

Iugling.
IVglers and sleightie Curers of diseases which for the curing of all Sect' 22.
sicknesses and sores of man and beast, use either certain superstitious words
or writings called charms or spelles hanged about the neck or some other part
of the body.

Inchauntings and Charming.
INchanters or Charmers through certain words pronounced and charecters Sect.
23.
or images, herbs, or other things applied, think they can do what they list,
the devil so deceives them, or in very deed dispatcheth those things which the
Inchantors would have done, from these somewhat differ witches or hagges, and
Augurers or Southsaiers by birds, di^^ors by seeing thintrals of beasts
sacrificed.

Witcherie.
A Witch or hagg is she which being eluded by a league made with Sect' 24.
the devil through his persuasion, inspiration and iuggling thinks she can
design what manner of evil things soever, either by thought or imprication, as
to shake the air with lightnings and thunder, to cause hail and tempests, to
remove green corn or trees to an other place, to be carried of her familiar
which has taken upon him the deceiptful shape of a goat, swine, or calfe etc.
into some mountain far distant, in a wonderful short space of time. And
sometimes to fly upon a staff or forke, or some other instrument. And to
spend all the night after with her sweet heart, in playing, sporting,
bankqueting, dancing, daliance, and diverse other deuelish lusts, and lewd
desports, and to show a thousand such monsterous mockeries.

Heresy.
Heresy, is a resolute and obstinate error in some article of our christian
Sect' 25.
faith, 1. Timo. 4. 1. 2. Peter 2. 1. 1. Cor. 11. 19. Romans 16. 17.

Anabaptisme.
AMongst Heretics are numbered, Anabaptists, which wickedly iterate Sect' 26.
holy baptism, which heinous offense is very grievous, as by which the
Majesty of almighty God, and the promise which in the first baptism was
effectual, are violated.

Apostacy.
Apostacy follows, which is a forsaking of the Christian faith. Sect' 27.


And Apostasy happens two ways, either when any man partly

Perjury.
Perjury, is a lie affirmed by oath. Sect' 1.


So much of slanderous speeches, against God.

Slander against man by word.
A Slander against man is an injury done to him by words or writings. Sect'
29.
By words when any thing is said or done by words to the contempt or reproach
of an other.

By writing.
I Niurie by writing is done by a slanderous libell or picture. Sect' 30.


By libell.
A Slanderous libel, is when a libell, epigram, rhyme or other writing Sect' 31.
is produced, written or composed to the note or contumely of any man, or the
same procured to be bought or sold, that by that means the dignity or fame of
an other man may be hurt.

By Picture.
AN infamous or slaunderots picture, is when any man to his infamy Sect' 32.
or ignominy is painted in any infamous or dishonest habit or sort, as hanging
upon the gallows, or in some evil place or manner.

We have showed thoffences committed by words, by which a man's

Offenses by deeds.
ANnd they be said to be done by deed, not because they are not also Sect' 33.
done of mind and purpose: but for that they chiefly consist in the fact
without which it may uneath be Judged of their punishment. And for that such
offenses are not perpetrated against the mind, but the body either of man or
his goods, whether it be done mediatly or immediately. Offenses by deeds either
altogether distroy a thing, or at the least impair the same.

Destruction.
DEstruction is the utter killing or corrupting of things.

And it is either of a fact permanent and apparent: or transitory, Sect' 34.
and during but a little while.

Facts Permanent.
A Permanent fact, is that whose very steps or prints abide, and are Sect'
35.
to be seen after thoffe^ce done: of this kind be slaughter and burning.

Slaughter.
SLaughter is a killing done by any means, and it is either of man Sect' 36.
or beast.

Homicide.
THe slaughter of Man is called Homicide, which is every taking away Sect' 37.
of life from any person bond or free, by man done with violence by which the
sole is severed from the body, by what manner of means so ever it chance,
whether by sword, staff, or other weapon, or by venim or poison, the cause of
death be given.

Voluntary.
HOmicide is either voluntary or casual. Sect' 38.


Homicide voluntary is that which is deliberate and committed

Malicious.
HOmicide voluntary is either without precedent malice or with Sect. 39.
precedent malice.

Of homicides voluntary without malice precedent, some are commanded,

Commanded.
HOmicides voluntary commanded by law are such as are done either Sect' 40.
for Justice sake, or upon urgent necessity.

For Justice.
HOmicide for Justice sake, is thinflicting of ordinary punishment Sect' 41.
upon heinous offenders by death, which is dispunishable, yet in this case it
behooves the Judge and other officers to be free from desire of blood and
private revenge.

Necessary.
HOmicide upon necessity is either in the due and orderly execution of Sect' 42.
Justice, as the killing of thoffendors in felony which resist or fly
officers having warrant to arrest, or deteine them, or persons pursuing them
with hue and cry, or riotors resisting Justices of the peace, which come to
arrest them, or prisoners resisting their gailors, if such offenders cannot
otherwise be attached or holden. So is it of persons riotously assembled
resisting persons aucthorised to apprehend them, 1. Mar. ca. 1* 2. And likewise
of offenders in parks, forests, and warrens, resisting or flying away after hue
and cry, 21. Ed. 1. and Burglers and Robbers all which homicides are
dispunishable, 26. Ass. 32. and diverse other in like cases by sundry statutes.

Se defendendo.
HOmicide upon necessity in ones own defense is termed Se defendendo, Sect' 43.
and is where any man being assaulted by any other, flies so far as he can
without eneuitable danger of death, and then in defending himself kills his
adversary, yet for this offense he loses his goods, and must procure pardon
for his life, Glouc* cap. 9. 43. Ass. 31.

Forbidden.
HOmicides voluntary forbidden by Law, without precedent malice Sect' 44.
is manslaughter or homicide, or by chance medley, which is where two men void
of all former malice and evil will, meeting together by chance, and upon
sudden falling out, the one of them kills the other with violence neither for
Justice, nor in case of necessity, Plow. f. 100. and 101. 21. H. 7. fol. 23.

Homicide malicious.
THus much of volu^tarie homicides without malice precedent, now Sect. 45.
of homicide volu^tarie of malice proceeding which is termed murder, and is the
felonious killing through malice prepensed of any person living in this Realm
under the Queens protection.

Of a man's self.
ANd it is either of himself, or of another.

Homicide of the party himself, is termed felo de se. And is Sect. 46.
where any man of hatred conceived against himself, does desperately, wilfully
and feloniously kill or destroy himself by hanging, drowning, poisoning or
otherwise.

Murder.
MVrder of others then the self party, is the like wilful and felonious
Sect. 47.
killing of any other of premeditate malice. And if thoffendor did owe by Law
unto the party slain any civil obedience, it is in some cases termed petie
treason. As if the wife kill her husband, the servant his Master or Mistres, or
a Clerk his Ordinary by reason of the reciprocal trust, and loyalty which
the law requires between such persons, and this offense is therefore far
more heinous then any of the other of homicides.

Homicide casual.
THus briefly of Homicides willingly done, Homicide casual which Sect. 48.
may also be termed, Homicide by mischance, misfortune, or misaduenture, is
when he that kills an other, had no will, intent, mind, or purpose so to do,
or the* man is slain by some other thing then a man. In which case th^ffender
is to have his pardon of course for life and land, but yet must loose his
goods. And this homicide is either mearely casual or mixed.

By Chance.
HOmicide by meare chance, is when by meare fortune against the Sect. 49.
mind of the killer, a man is slain. As if one hewing, the are flies of the
shafte and kill one, or if a man lopping a tree warns the bystanders, that
the tree is ready to fall, and yet by the same some of them is slain, or in
throwing tiles from an house or such other lawful acts, or the party is killed
by some other thing then man by misfortune, as by falling from an horse or
cart, by a stroke of an horse or any other moveable thing then man, In which
case the thing which killed him, and all things that moved the same are
forfaited to the Queen, and termed a Deodand, as if a cart wheel go over a
man and kill him, the wheel, cart, and al things therein, and the horses that
drew the same, be all Deodans, 3. E. 3. vndeversus.

Omnia quae mouent ad mortem, sunt Deodanda. Dyer fo. 78. pl. 37.

Mixte.
Mixed is when the killers ignorance, or negligence is joined with Sect. 50.
the chance, as if a man loppe trees by an high way side, by which many
usually t^auaile and cast down a bough not giving warning to take heed
thereof, by which bough one passing by, is slain, in whith case he offends
because he gave no warning that the party might have taken heed to himself.

Thus you see the diverse kinds of Manslaughter. Slaughter of beasts.
THe slaughter of beasts follows by what mean soever it comes, Sect. 51.
which is a damage done by injury and wrong, guile or default against the Law,
which might or ought to have been taken heed of. Of this offense springs an
action to the owner of the beast according as the value thereof shall be
esteemed by a Jury.

Burning.
THus far of slaughters of man and beast: burning ensues which Sect. 52.
is also felony, as the wilful burning of a dwelling house, 3. H. 7. 10. And
burning of a barn adjoining to a dwelling house by night, 11. H. 7. fol. 1.
And burning of a barn with corn not adjoining to a dwelling house by day.

Offenses transitory.
ANd these concerning offenses of continuing facts, those follow Sect. 53.
which are of transitory or momentarie factes, as unlawful copulation,
burglarie and theft.

Adultery and fornication.
Unlawful copulation, is every carnal conjunction had out of Sect. 54.
lawful matrimony, and it is termed fornication or adultery, which is first
either natural or against nature, and either voluntary or violent. Fornication
naturally committed, is between man and woman, which if it be perpetrated
between kinsfolks, is said to be incest. Copulation vilent is termed a rape or
rauishment of a woman against her will, which is carnal knowledge had of a
woman, who never consented thereunto before the fact nor after, and this
offense is felony in the principal and his aydors, 11. H. 4. 13. 1. E. 4. 1.
Westminster 2. cap. 13. And carnal abuse of a woman child, under x. years old is
felony, 18. Eliz. cap. 6.

Sodomy or buggery.
COpulation against nature, is by male or female against nature, or Sect. 55.
by female with female, or with beasts which is called* Sodomy or buggery, 25.
H. 8. cap. 5. 5. Eliz. cap. 17. which be felony.

Burglarie.
BVrglarie is a felonious entering into an other ma^s dwelling house Sect. 56.
wherein some person is, or into a Church, in the night time, to the end to
commit some felony therein, as to kill some man, or to steal somewhat thence,
or to do some other such felonious act there, albeit he execute not the same,
if the intent or fact of this offender be to steal, this is like robbery, If to
murder, it differs not much from murderers, and so of other felonies.

House-robbing.
THe offense against the Statutes of 23. H. 8. cap. 1. and 3. Edw. 6. Sect. 67.
cap. 9. somewhat resemble this, for by them it is ordained, that if any person
do rob another in any part of his dwelling place, or in his booth, or tent,
in any fair or market, and the owner of his wife, children or servants being
within the same, he commits felony.

Theft.
THeft ensues, in which not so much the destruction of a thing, as Sect. 58.
the taking away of the same chances.

Theft is an unlawful felonious taking away of another man's

From the person.
THeft from the owners person or presence, is of two sorts, the one Sect. 59.
putting thowner in fear, the other not.

Robbery.
Robbery is a felonious taking away of another man's goods, from Sect. 60.
his person, or presence, against his will, putting him in fear and of purpose
to steal the same goods.

And this robbery is sometime termed violent theft, because the party is in the
law thereby terrified.

Without fear.
THeft from thowners person, not putting him in fear, is by cutting Sect. 61
or picking his purse, and stealing the money, or purse, or both: this is done
slightly, without the owners fear and priuity,

But to perfect this offense, an actual possession of the thing taken

Theft of goods in the owners absence, is termed Larc^ny, which is is either
great or small: For great Larciny is, when the things stolen though they be
taken at several times exceed the value of xii. d. And petie Larcinie is,
when the goods so taken exceed not the value of xii. d.

Hurting and violence.
NOw then crimes coming from the destruction of things, being Sect. 62.
thus hastily run over. Let us step on to the other which have their name of
the hurting of the thing, and violent hurting destroys not the body, but
harmeth and anoyeth it, and makes either the body, or the state and condition
thereof worse.

Hurts to the body of the common wealth, as treasons.
ANd through certain offenses is hurt to the common wealth immediately, Sect.
63.
and always, or the members thereof. The common wealth is hurt either in
respect of the amplitude and majesty thereof, or of the profit and commodity
thereof, which is hindered or intercepted.

When the Amplitude and majesty thereof is harmed, the offense is

And these treasons be high treason, or petie treason: High treason

Or to kill the Kings Chauncellor, Treasurer, Justice of the one 25. Ed. 3. cap.
2.

Forging of the kings sign Manuell, or privy signet, privy seal, 2. Mar.
cap. 6.

Diminishing or impayring of money current, 2. Eliz. cap. 11. and 18.

The second offense in refusing the oath of supremacy, 5. Eliz. cap. 1.

Or the compassing to deprive the Q. of her crown, 1. Eliz. cap. 6.

Or to destroy the Queen, 1. Eliz. cap. 6.

Or to levy war within the realm against the Queen, 1. El. ca. 6.

Or to affirm that the Queen or the heirs of her body, is not or 1. Eliz.
cap. 6.

Or intending the bodily harm of the Q. 13. Eliz. cap. 1.

Or to levy war against the Queen. 13. Eliz. cap. 1.

Or to move foreign invasions of this Realm, 13. Eliz. cap. 1.

Or to declare, that the Queen is not Queen, 13. Eliz. cap. 1.

Or to declare that any other ought, etc. 13. Eliz. cap. 1.

Or to affirm the Q. to he an Heretic, Scismatike, tyrant, infidel, 13. Eliz.
cap. 1.

Or to claim the crown after the Queen, 13. Eliz. cap. 1.

Or to affirm that the common Laws or statutes cannot bind the 13. Eliz.
cap. 1.

Or to maintain the aucthority of the Bishop of Rome, 5. Elizab.

Or to obtain any Bull from Rome, 13. Eliz. cap. 2.

Or to give, take or promise absolution thereby, 13. Eliz. cap. 2.

Or to conspire to enlarge any imprisoned by the Queens commandment 14.
Eliz. cap. 2.

Or to withhold any of the Queens Castles, or holds, 14. Eliz.

Or any of her ships or ordinance of war, 14. Eliz. cap. 1.

Or not to render the same Castles, within six days after proclamation, 14.
Eliz. cap. 1.

Or to destroy any of the Queens ships, 14. Eliz. cap. 1.

Or to bar any of the Queens havens, 14 Eliz. cap. 1.

Or to persuade any subject from natural obedience, or Religion: or 23. Eliz.
cap. 1.

Or for Jesuits to come into, or be in this Realm, 27. El. ca. 2.

Or to be a Seminary, and not return into this Religion, within 27. Eliz.
cap. 2.

It is also to be noted, that al manner of accessaries to the several treaons

Or of misprision of treason, which is the concealment or not disclosing 2. R.
3. fol. 9.

Offenses hindering the commodity of the common wealth.
NOw succeed thoffences which hinder the commodity of the common Sect. 64.
wealth.

The profit of the common wealth is hindered diverse ways, as by

Forestalling, is the buying or bargayning for any victuals or

Or the moving of any person to enhaunce the price of the same victuals 5. Ed.
6. cap. 14. 5. Eliz. cap. 12. 13. Eliz. cap. 25.

Regrating, is the buying and selling of any wares or victuals in the 5. Edw.
6. cap. 14. 5. El. ca. 12. 13. Eliz. cap. 25.

Engrossing, is buying of Corn growing, or dead victual to sell 5. Edw. 6.
cap. 14. 5. Eliz. cap. 14. 13. Eliz. cap. 25.

Offenses against Subjects.
IN these few, have we touched such offenses as immediately, and always Sect.
65.
are committed against the common wealth it self: now will we entreat of those
which always for the most part are perpetrated violently against the inferior
members of the same (that is to say) either private men themselves, or their
goods, which are effected partly by force, and partly without force.

Force is an offense by which violence is used to things or persons.

And force is either simple or mixed.

Simple force is that which is so committed, that it has none other

Mixed force is that violence, which is committed with such a fact, as of it
self only is criminal: as if any by force enter into another possession,
and kill a man, or ravish a woman there etc.

And those offenses which are achieved with force, are done by true

Those offenses which are finished hy true force, are either done by

And force with men assembled is private or public.

Private force is when any with weapons by men assembled, does

Public force is that violence which is done by any men assembled 1. Mar. cap.
12. 1. Eliz. cap. 17.

A forcible entree is a violent actual entree into a house, or land etc. 5. R.
2. cap. 7. 15. R. 2. cap. 2. 8. H. 6. cap. 7.

A forcible deteyning or withholding of a possession, is a violent act 29. Ass.
49.

An unlawful assembly, is the meeting of three, or mo persons together,

A rout is an assembly of three persons or mo, going on about forcibly Brook
tit. Riot, 4. 5.

A Riot is the forcible doing of an unlawful act by three, or more persons

A rebellious assembly, is an assembly of twelve persons or more intending, or
baies, or to burn stackes of corn, or to abaterents, or prices of victuals,
1. Mar. 12. cap. 1. Eliz. cap. 17.

Also by the same statutes an unlawful assembly may be of persons

It follows how force may be committed without a multitude. culpa or dolo,
that is negligently or unwittingly, or guilefully or of set purpose, whether it
be assaulting, beating, wounding, maiming, or hurting, brusing, or impairing of
the body of man or beast by any means: Or the brusing, breaking or empairing
of any other thing whatsoever without a multitude, also breaking of prisons, to
escape thence, breaking of houses to steal something thence, or to do some
felony there, which being in the night is termed Burglary, whereof we have
spoken before entreating of theft. In this rank also may be placed the pulling
up or removing of meares, bounds, or marks, set for the dividing of one man's
land from another, and many other such trespasses wherein is none apparent
force or terror, as to hawke, hunt, fish, or foul, or to cut, eat, tread or
foil grass in another man's soil unlawfully, 11. Ass. 16. 11. H. 8. 4. 16.
21. E. 3. 34.

Hitherto of offenses done by true force indeed: now of such as are

Those offenses of briberie, extortion, and exaction, are committed

To this crew as it seems, may be referred the exaction of unlawful 37. H.
8. cap. 9. 13. Eliz. cap. 10.

And all unlawful games, which be all games, but shooting, 33. H.

And every other taking of more then is due by color or pretense of prises for
ale, bread, victuals, wares or other things.

Offenses springing from words and deeds.
SO much then of single offenses, springing from only words, or only Sect' 66.
deeds. Now follow those which issue from both together, as those which arise
from the crime of falsehood.

The offense of falsehood is a guileful and fraudulent imitation of the

Falshod by word, is by lying, as if any man should feign unto himself

Falsehood by deed is as if a man write or sign a false testament, or

Hitherto may we refer maintenance, and champerty and suits, embrasing

Also falsely to collude in pleading, or to betray, or to loose his clients

Other men's offenses, and how far they bind us.
WE have entreated of our own offenses: other men's succeed, Sect' 67.
namely, when, and how far we are bound by them.

And we are bound by other in offenses, when we are tied by the faults of our
family, or of our beasts.

Our family offends by lying, or casting, or hanging of any thing in the high
way, whereby it is stopped or hindered: which offense is called a Nuisance.

We are bound by many trespasses of our wives, but not to sustain

Also if our beasts or cattle offend in eating other men's corn or grass,

Offenses unnamed.
Enough of named offenses, it remains that we view those which be Sect' 68.
unnamed.

For when the variety of offenses grew so manifold, that all could not be
distinguished by special names, it was appointed that proper or special names
aforesaid, failing, the offense of cosening, and deceit, should come in place.

Thoffence of cosening takes place, if any thing be done by guile in,

Deceit is a subtle wily shift or devise having none other name. Hereunto

Of Indictments as remedies for the former diseases.
THus have we rather slightly shadowed, then perfectly portraied Sect' 69.
the ugly shape of such enormous offenses, as with their deformity most
blemish the body of our beautiful, (otherwise flourishing) common wealth. Now
therefore we are to show the ways how to prepare remedies for the same, which
must be done by indictme^ts, in which are chiefly to be eyed the matter and
form.

The matter or object of indictments in nothing else but the several

Touching thoffence or fact it self, we are here fully to regard the very
deceit, or some other offense, and of what several ^^nd it is, and whether it
be punishable by the common law, or by some penal statut, that the indictment
thereupon may be framed accordingly.

The circumstances of the fact are seven, that is to say, cause, person,

Touching the cause of thoffence we are to weigh ^^^ther thoffence be of cause
just or unjust: whether by chance or of malice and purpose, or upon a sudden,
or by negligence, or by guile, which makes some homicides lawful, some
punishable, and that in several degrees.

The person is in two sorts to be regarded, that is, as he is agent or patient.

The time also in offenses makes difference between offenses, as in

The place in like manner makes the self same fact either theft, burglarie,

By the consideration of the quality we discern whether an offense

The view of the quantity of thoffence showed us whether it be punishable

The event looks to the final cause, purpose, or issue, of the fact, whether

All which circumstances, are partly seen before, in the very handeling

Of the form of Indictments.
IN the form of every Indictment, besides the ordinary words of Sect' 70.
form, precise certenty to every intent is to be as warily looked unto, as in
declarations in civil suites and return of Sherifes, 3. H. 7. fol. 11. and 12.
3. Ed. 4. 21. otherwise is the Indictment insufficient, for Indictments and
appeals be the very base and foundation of every criminal controversy.

This certentie consists, first in the name and surname of the party

2. In the certain name and surname of the party offended.

3. In the certeinty of time, wherein the offense is done, as the certain

4. In the place where thoffence is perpetrated.

5. In the very matter of the fact, and nature of thoffence committed, as

6. In the name and value of the thing, in which thoffence is done.

Unto the name of the party indicted must be united the addition of 13. H. 6.
fo. 30. if the town where the offender dwells bears one self name with
the parish, he may be named of either: but if there be 2. towns of one name,
in one parish, he ought to be named of the parish 4. E. 4. fo. 129. 22. E. 4.
fo. 22. and 22. H. 6. fo. 41. Alias dictus in Iurato^ pro dn^a reg' present^
quam I. S. nuper de D. in com^ Essex husbandma^ etc. And 5. die Feb. anno regni
dn^ae nostr^ Eliz. dei gratia Angl' etc. And in some indictments, as of murder,
and burglary, the very hour is to be expressed, as hora 6. ante merid' (if it
were before noone) and post mer^ (if it were after) eiusde^ diei: if thoffence
be committed after noone and before midnight, it must be laid in the same day:
if after midnight, and before sun rising, then in the day following: and if
the time be expressed by the year of our Lord God (as it may be) then the year
begins with us evermore upon the 25. day of March: but in Indictments which
present that a thing is omitted, or not done, there needs no time of the not
doing or omission thereof be set forth, as that a ditch was not skowred, by
means whereof meadows be overflowed, and such like. If a man be stricken or
poisoned in one county, and dies thereof in another 2. and 3. Eliz. ca. 24.
and if one become accessory in one County to a murder or other felony done in
another, he may well be indicted in the county where he was accessory. He
which robs in the county of D. apud B. in comit^ For it is not good to say
in com^ praedict' referring to the name of the county written in the margent
of thindictment: and the place of the offense is sometime more specially set
down thus, apud B. in com^ C. in quodam loco ibide^ vocat^ the northclose etc.
also it is to be regarded, that if a county be divided into several divisions,
so that those which be Justices in one division, be not Justices in another
division thereof, as the county of York, which is divided into 3. deuisions,
called ridings, as the westriding, eastriding, and northriding: it is requisite
that it be expressed in thindictment, in which of the divisions or ridings
thoffences happened, as apud R. in Westriding in com^ Ebor^ in quodam loco ibid'
vocat^ the lodge etc. for the Commissions, whereby the Justices of peace in
such ridings are ordained, have in them such words, as follow, viz. Sciatis
quod assignamus vos coniu^ctim and diuisim, and quemlibet vestru^ Iustic' n^os
ad pacem nostram in partibus de Westriding in com^ nostro Eborum conseruandam
etc. Mandamus enim tenore presentium vic' nostro Eboru^ quod ad illos dies and
loca, que vos vel aliqui hm^odi duo vel plures vr^m, vt praed' est, scir^
feceritis venire coram vobis vel hm^di duobus vel pluribus vestrum, vt dictum
est, tales probos and legales homines de partibus praedict' tam infra
libertates quam extra, per quos rei veritas in premissis melius sciri poterit
and inquiri etc. So that the power of such Justices extends no further then
to those ridings only in which they bin so made Justices, and therefore what is
by them done otherwise is coram non Iudice, and void.

Albeit the name of the person to whom thoffence is committed be in quod
defendens bona and catalla cuiusdam ignoti felonice cepit etc. in theft: or
quendam ignotum felonice depredauit etc. in robbery, is good for the Queens
advantage of the forfaiture thereby accrewing, so is it as it seems quod vi
and armis etc. insultum and affraiam in quendam ignotum fecit etc. Dier fol.
99. page 61. and 285. p. 38. But if the goods of a Church be taken away, quod
bona parochianorum in custodia gardianorum Ecclesiae de C. existen^ ceperunt,
and asportauerunt etc. if the goods of a man be taken, who makes his executors
and dies, the Indictment must be, bona testatoris etc. but if they be taken
after the testators death, it shall be bona testatoris in custod' execut^
existen^ etc. A grauestone is de bonis Ecclesiae, coat armor hanged over a
tomb, be the goods of the dead man's executors: goods taken from one, are the
goods of the trespasser, until the owner have recontinued his property: goods
bailed, are said bona, of the owner in custodia balliui. The bona and cattalla,
but vnum equum, or 2. equos and ouem, bouem etc. And the value of those things
in which offenses 8. E. 4. fo. 5. nor of Charters of land. And precij, or ad
valentiam: but of one living thing, or of one dead thing only, it is precij,
and not ad valentiam, but of diverse dead things ad valentiam, and not precij.
Of come not current, it shall be praecij but of coin curra^t shall neither be
said precij, nor ad valentiam, For the price and value thereof is certain, but
of counterfeit coin, shall be said ad valentiam, and in counterfaiting of coin
shall not be said x. li. libras in denarijs dominae Reginae, nor in pecunia
dominae Reginae, but ad instar pecuniae dominae Reginae.

The very manner of the fact or deed it self, and nature of the offense Dyer
fol. 99. pl. 63. And for slanderous words against the Queen, the very words
must be certainly set down. And for entry, into house, land or tenements must
be expressed, what manner of house, lands or tenements, as a message, a
cottage, arable land, meadow, pasture, or wood. And where in any Indictment,
times and places, both the times and places must be certainly expressed, as in
murdar and manslaughter, thassault and the striking, as apud B. in comitatu E.
etc. in quendam I. S. insultum fecit, and ipsum I. S. cum quoda^ gladio precij
etc. adtunc and ibid' felonice, and ex malitia sua praecogitata percussit and
murdrauit. And in theft, the thing stolen must certainly be laid down, 22.
Ass. pla. 75. and 29. Ass. 45. And an Indictment against an accessarie, must
show what felony the principal committed, and that knowing it, received the
felon feloniously, 7. H. 6.

Touching the several natures of several offenses, it is to be noted, that
proditorie: of murder, murdrauit: and of manslaughter, and all other felonies,
the deed must be said to be done felonice, and in burglary, Burglariter, or
intention ad felomam sieve murdrum faciend etc. in rape felonice rapuit, in
theft, felonice cepit and asportauit, if it be a dead thing: if living,
abduxit, or felonice furatus est, In petie Larceny and maime, must also be
said, felonice.

And notwithstanding the statute of 37. H. 8. ca. 8. it is not amiss in (vi
and armis (viz. gladijs, baculis, cultellis etc. And in a Forcible enter upon
the statute 8. H. 6. ca. 9. must be manuforti etc. or cum multitudine gentiu^
etc. And in an Indictme^t found upon statuts, it seems not needful to recite
the statute verbatim, as has bin heretofore used, and namely, if the statute
be general 5. H. 5. 11. 30. ass. 38. But fully and certainly to describe
thoffence against the tenor of the same statute. And then conclude with these
words. Contra formam statuti in hum^di casu prouisi and aediti: If there be
only one statute of that offense: but if there be diverse concerning the same,
then the conclusion must be, Contra formam diuersorum statutorum in hm^di casu
aedit^ and prouisorum etc.

And it is specially to be noted that in Indictments grounded upon 31. Eliz.
cap. 5.

But the forms of Indictments will best appear in the following

For keeping an Alchouse or Tiplinghouse.
IVratores pro Domina Regina presentant, quod A. B. de C. in dict' comitatu
Sect' 67.
E. yeoman, vicesimo die mensis Octobris, Anno regni domin^ nostrae
Elizabethae, Dei gratia Angliae, Franciae, and Hiberniae Reginae, fidei
defensoris etc. Tricesimo, and continue multis diebus postea, viz. vsque primum
diem dicti October. Ann^ supradicto, apud C. praedict' in comitatu praedicto,
obstinate atque ex aucthoritate propria ipsius A. B. sine vlla Iusticiariorum
pacis dictae dominae Reginae in comitatu praedicto admissione aut allocatione,
assumpsit super se custodire, and custodiuit vnam communem Tabernam (Anglice
vocata^ a common Tippling house) and ibidem dicto vicesimo die, and dictis
diebus tum postea, communiter and public vendidit ceruisiam, and potum
(Anglice dictum Ale and Beer) diuersis dictae dominae Reginae ligeis and
subditis. In dictae dominae Reginae contemptum, ac contra formam cuiusdam
statuti, in parliamento domini Edwardi nuper Regis Angliae sexti, tento apud

For silk in a Cappe.
IVratores pro Domina Regina praesentant, quod A. B. de C. in dicto Sect' 72.
Comitatu Tailor, natus infra hoc regnum Angliae, videlicet, apud C.
praedictam, sed filius aut haeres apparens alicuius militis, aut filius hominis
altioris gradus non existens, nec potens expender per annum viginti libras, in
terris, tenementis, feodis, officijs, aut alijs annuis reuentionibus, pro
termino vitae suae: nec valens ducentas libras de bonis suis proprijs: nec
vnquam Mayor, Balliuus, Aldermanus, aut capitalis officiarius in aliqua
Ciuitate, burgo, aut villa corporata existens, nec dictae dominae Reginae
seruiens in ordinario (vtens dictae dominae Regine liberata) existens: 20.
tamen die Octobris, anno regni dicte dominae nostrae Elizabethae, Dei gratia,
Angliae, Franciae, and Hibernie Reginae, fidei defensoris, etc. Tricesimo, apud
C. praedictam in comitatu praed', per totum dictum 20. diem Anno supradicto,
interiore part cuiusdam pilei sui (Anglice vocati a Cap, quodam serico
(Anglice dicto Taffata) (ad valorem 2. solidorum) illicite and palam vsus est:
contra formam cuiusdam Statuti, in parliamento Philippi and Mariae nuper Regis
and Reginae Angliae, tento apud Westminster in com^ Midd', Annis regnorum suoru^,
primo and secundo in huiusmodi casu prouisi and editi.

For using the Art of a Mercer against the Statute of Anno quinto of the Queen.
IVratores pro domina Regina presentant, quod A. B. de C. in comitatu Sect. 63.
E. Mercer, vicessimo die mensis Maij, Anno regni dictae dominae nostrae,
Elizabethae, Dei gratia Angliae, Franciae, and Hyberniae reginae, fidei
defensoris etc. Tricesimo primo, and multis alijs diebus continue post dictum
diem pre spacium duorum mensium, extu^c proxsequent^, vide licet, vsque
tricesimum diem Iulij, anno supradicto, apud C. praedict^ in comitatu E.
predicto, quandam artem, sieve mysterium (Anglice dictum Mercerie) illicte pro
lucro suo proprio vsitauit et exercuit: tunc ibidem vendendo diuersas merces
(Anglice vocatas Mercerie wares) diuersis dicte dominae reginae legeis and
subditis: vbi reuera idem A. B. nunquam fuit in dicta art sieve mysterio
educatus, tanquam apprenticeus per spacium septem annorum, nec idem A. B.
eandam artem (sieve mysterium praedictum) 12. die Ianuarij anno regni dictae
dominae nostrae reginae nunc quinto vsitauerit, aut exercuerit: In magnum
dictae Dominae reginae contemptum, ac contra formam cuiusdam Statuti, in
Parliamento dictae Dominae reginae nostrae nunc, tento apud Westmonast' Anno
regni sui quinto, in hoc casu prouisi ac aediti, vt supra dict'.

An Indictment upon the Statute of An. 1. Mar. cap. 12. for the assembly of
12. persons assembled together, to the intent to cut down a conduict head and
staying there 3. hours after proclamation made that they should depart.
IVratores pro domina regina, praesentant, Quod primo die mensis Octobris,
Sect. 74.
Anno regni dn^ae nostrae Elizabethae, Dei gratia, Angl', Franciae, and
Hyberniae Reginae, fidei defensoris etc. Tricesimo quinto A. B. C. D. E. F. And
so reciting xii. persons at the least, with their additions of occupations and
dwellings, apud quendam locu^ infra parochia^ de O. in comitatu E. pred',
(Anglice vocatum le old Court) inter horas decimam et vndecimam ante meridiem
eiusdem diei, vi and armis, tam inuasiuis, quam defensiuis, videlicet, gladijs,
pugionibus, Baculis, arcubus, sagittis, tunicis ferreis, et tormentis, seipsos
congregauerunt, et assemblauerunt: Ac tunc and ibidem intenderunt, conati sunt,
practicauerunt and in vsu posuerunt, vi and armis, illegitime, et ex
aucthoritate sua propria, secare, et prorsus euertere, prosternere ac destruere
quoddam caput vnius aquae ductus (Anglice vocatum a conduit head) tunc ibidem
in fundo cuiusdam R. S. de O. pred', in comitatu predicto generosi existens, et
cursum aquae in ipso habens, ea intention, vt idem caput aquae ductus
praedicti ex tunc apertum and vacuum remaneret ac iaceret: Et vlterius, quod
super quaerimonia inde facta coram T. W. vno Iusticiariorum pacis dictae
Dominae Reginae in comitatu E. predicto, omnes and singuli predicti A. B. C. D.
E. F. etc. tunc et ibidem per eundem Iusticiarium requisiti sunt ac iussi (per
proclamationem in nomine dictae dominae Reginae tunc and ibidem per cum palam
factam) ad habitationes, loca, and domos suas (vnde venerant) se inde in
pacifico modo retrahere, retirare, discedere et reuerti: quae quidem
proclamatio tun^ ibidem modo and forma sequentibus, habita and facta est, viz.
praedictus T. W. lusticiarus tunc ibidem fecit alta voce vnum Dies, ac tunc
ibid' immediate haec verba anglicana sequentia palam, and alta voce The
proclamation.
pronunciauit, dicens scilicet, The Queen our Sovereign Lady charge, and
commands all persons (being assembled) immediately to disperse themselves,
and peaceably to depart to their habitations, or to their lawful business,
upon the pains contained in the act lately made against unlawful and
rebellious assemblies: And God save the Queen. Et vlterius, Iurarores predicti
dicunt, quod non obstante dicta proclamatione modo and forma praedictis per
praefatum Iusticiarium tunc ibidem facta and habita, ijdem tamen omnes and
singuli There staying after the proclamations 2. hours.
praedicti A. B. C. D. E. F. etc. in dicto loco vocato le old Court infra
parochiam de O. predicta in dicto comitatu E. per spacium duarum horarum,
immediate and continue post dictam proclamationem sic vt praefertur factam and
habitam sequentium, seditiose and felonice insimul remanserunt and
continuauerunt, in magnum dictae Dominae reginae contemptum, ac contra pacem,
coronam, et dignitatem suas, necnon contra formam diuersorum Statutorum in
huiusmodi casu prouisorum and editorum.

Against a Barrettor.
IVratores pro Domina Regina praesentant, quod A. B. de C. in comitatu Sect. 75.
E. Tailor, secundo die Octobris, Anno regni dictae Dominae nostrae Elizab',
dei gratia Angl', Franciae, and Hyberniae Reginae, fidei defensoris etc.
Tricesimo quarto, apud C. predictam in comitatu E. praedict^, fuit, and adhuc
est co^munis Barectator, and pacis dictae Dominae Reginae perturbator assiduus
and publicus, necnon communis ac turbulentus calumniator, conuiciator,
pugnator, and litium inter vicinos suos seminator, adeo vt diuersas lites,
controuersias, necnon iurgia, and pugnas adtunc ibidem, et alibi in dicto
comitatu E. inter diuersos dictae Dominae Reginae ligeos and subditos, mouit,
procurauit, and excitauit: In magnam dictae Dominae Reginae pacis
perturbationem, ac contra formam diuersarum ordinationum ac statutorum huius
regni sui Angl', in huiusmodi casu antehac prouisorum ac editorum.

Against a Barrettor.

xx. die etc. apud G. praed' in comitatu praedict^, fuit and adhuc est communis

vicinorum suorum, and al' ligeorum dictae dominae Reginae in com^ D. praedicto,
ac communis malefactor, calumpniator, and seminator litium and discordiarum
inter vicinos suos predict^, ad magnum dispendium, grauamen, and perturbationem
vicinorum praedict^, and aliorum fidelium ligeorum dictae Dominae in com^ D.
praed', contra ordniationes, leges and statuta huius regni Angl' in huiusmodi
cas, edit^ and prouis. ac contra pacem dictae dominae Reg. coronam etc.

dominae Reginae ad Assisas in comitatu predicto capiend', necno^ ad gaolam

quod de vita sua desperabatur, in magnum iusticiae and legum huius regni Angl'
contemptum, and pernitiosum exemplum aliorum, ac contra pacem dictae Dominae

pacem dictae Dominae Reginae, coronam and dignitatem suas etc.

regis Angl' prima, progenitoris dominae Reginae nunc, prouisum sit, Quod
nullus Minister, vel aliquis alius manuteneat placita, querelas, vel negocias,

habend', nec aliquis ius suum sub huiusmodi co^ditione alteri dimittat^. Quidam
W. P. etc. simul cum R. S. etc. tali die and anno, quandam querelam cuiusdam
Ass. friscae que est in curia dominae Reg' nune Ciuitatis E. coram E. B. Maior^
and C. D. vicecom^ eiusdem ciuitatis, fine breui ipsius dominae Reg' secund'
consue^ ciuitatis praedict', inter quosdam I. R. and T. L. de vno mesuag' cum
pertin^ in ciuitate praedict', pro part eiusdem mesuagij* viz. pro medietate
mesuagij illius, sibi and hered' suis imperpetuum, and alio proficuo, viz. pro
medietate damnor^ in querela assise praed' recuperand' inde habend', per
conuentionem inter pref. I. ac praed' W. and R. S. apud E. praed' factu^
assumpsit manutenend', and manutenuit, ad grave dampn^ ipsius T. L. and contra
form^ prouisionis praed' etc.

For fighting with a weapon in the Churchyard, contrary to the statute of Anno
5. Ed, 6.
IVrat^ presentant, quod cum in statuto in Parliamento domini E. nuper Sect' 94.
Regis Anglie sexti, apud Westminster, anno regni sui quinto, tent^, edit^, inter
cetera stabilit^ existit etc. Quod sialiqua persona ad aliquod tempus* post
primum diem diem Maij, tunc proxim^ sequent^ malitiose percuteret aliquam
personam, cum aliquibus armis in aliqua ecclesia sieve cemiterio, vel post
eundem primum diem Maij, extraheret aliqua arma in aliqua ecclesia, seu
cemiterio, intention ad percutiendum alium c^m eisdem armis, quod tunc
quelibet persona si^ offendens and inde conuict' per veredictum xij. hominum,
vel per suam propriam confessionem, vel per duos legales testes, coram Iustic'
Assisarum, Iustic' audiend' and ternandi, sieve Iustic' pacis in Sessionibus
suis, virtute illius actus adiudicaretur per eosdem Iustic' coram quibus talis
persona sic conuinceretur, ad habend' vnam aurium suarum abscissam, and si illa
persona sieve personae sic offenden^ haberet sieve non haberent aliquas aures,
ita quod illiusmodi poenam subirent (vt prefertur) quod tunc ipse vel ipsi
signarentur in bucca, Angl* cheek, farrocandent Angl', a hot iron haben^ hanc
literam F. per quam ipse vel ipsi cognosci and haberi possint pugnar^
effectores, and pugnatores, and vltra hoc, quelibet talis persona foret and
staret ipso facto excommunicat^, prout in eodem statuto before continet^.
Quidam tamen G. B. nuper de S. etc. 2. die Iunij, etc. vi and armis, viz. etc.
cum quodam pugion^ in quendam T. C. in pace Dei and dictae dominae Reginae
existen^ apud C. in comit^ E. praedict' in cemeterio Ecclesiae parochialis de
C. praed' insultum fecit, and ipsum T. super caput suumadtunc and ibide^
maliciose percussit, and alia enormia ei intulit ad grave damnum ipsius T. and
contra pacem dictae dominae Reginae etc. ac contra formam statuti praedicti etc.

For conspiring and combining to indicte one for stealing of a horse of one of
the conspirators, and for procuring of diverse false suites to be brought and
pursued in the names of the conspirators, and of diverse others against diverse
persons.
IVratores etc. present^, quod I. P. nuper de I. in praedicto comit^ E. et
Sect' 97.
R. B. nuper de C. in praed' comit^ E. gener^ vna cum alijs quamplurimis
personis adhuc ignot^, contra legem domini regis ad formam statutoru^ in
huiusmodi casu prouisorum, conspiratione and couina apud T. praed^ die etc.
habit^, diuersis temporib* postea simul vnit^, confederati, et iurati falso
fraudulent^ and malicrose vener^ ad vindicand', destruend', perturba^,
placitand', adnihiland', and similit^ adnulland' fideles et innocents ligeos
dicti domini regis pro lucro ad eorum proprium vsum capiendo, societatem
inierunt, and adinuicem iurauerunt, ad simul standum contra dictu^ dominum
regem, et quoscunque ligeos suos in omnibus et singulis materijs placitis et
querelis, peripsos et eorum quemlibet motis seu mouendis. Et si eorum aliquis
cum aliquo, placita, materiam, seu querela^ moueret, quod ipsi and eorum
quilibet cum eo, sic materiam, querelam, seu placitum mouent^ stare, et
perseuerare deberent et deberet. Et si aliquis eorum aliquam querelam seu
placitum nomine alterius person cuiuscunque, versus aliam personam super se
assumpserit manutenend', extunc eorum quilibet querelam, sectam, seu placit^
praedict', tanqua^ querelam, sectam, seu placitum, nomine eorum prosecut^,
manuteneret, foueret et teneret, recto, veritate, Iustic' et iure, omnino
postpositis et sublat^: Virtute quorum quidem vnitionis, conspirationis,
iurament^, confederationis, et manutentionis, praedictorum I. P. R. B. et al'
sic in vnum globat^, et iurat^, postea, videlicet die etc. Anno etc.
conspiratione inter eos apud C. in comit^ praedict', prehabita, quendam I. H.
de eo quod ipse die etc. anno etc. vnum equum pretij etc. de bonis et catallis
praedicti I. P. R. B. apud S. inuent^ felonice furatus fuit cepit et abduxit,
falso and malitiose indictari procurauerunt. Et praedict' I. P. et R. B. et
alij modo et forma praed' unity et confederati diuersa falsa placita, sectas,
et querelas innumerabiles, tam nominibus eorum proprijs, quam nominibus aliarum
personarum eis falso and maliciose congregat^ and vnit^, prosecuti suerunt, et
manutenerunt and indies prosequntur et manutenent, videlicet praedict' I. P. ad
hundredum domini P. militis apud C. praedict' xiij. die, anno etc. tent^, eodem
I. adtunc Ballino eiusdem hundred' existen^, ad statum et possessionem R. S. et
A. vxoris sue adnulland': Et pro eo quod ad quamlibet curiam hundred' ibidem
successiue tenend', praedict' R. vxorem suam ibidem producere nequiret, ita
quod excessiua amerciament^ in status eorum depauperationem fierent and
euenirent co^sideration^ taxator^ amerciamen^ curie praedicte, semper de couina
praedict' praed' I. P. extiterunt, tresdecim querelas de placito
transgressionis, nomine W. Y. et R. B. quatuer querelas transgressionis nomine
W. E. absque vera materia seu iusta causa, seperatim versus praedictum R. S. et
A. leuauit and intranit, ac praedict' querentes huiusmodi querelas leuare
procurauit ad grave damnum ipsorum R. et A. et contra formam ordinationis in
huiusmodi casu prouis. etc.

Against Egyptians upon the statute of primo and secundo of king Philip and
Queen Marie.
IVr^ present^ quod cum in statuto in Parliamento domini P. and dn^ae M. Sect'
101.
nuper regis and Reginae Angl' apud W. die x. No. annis Reg' suorum 1. and 2.
tent^ aedit^ inter alia ordinatum existit, etc. quod si aliqua persona, sieve
person seipsos appellantes Egyptianos qui transportarentur, vel conueiarentur
in hoc regnum Angl' sieve Walliae, continuarent, and remanerent, infra idem, per
spacium vnius mensis, quod tunc ipse vel ipsi sic offenden^, virtute actus
praed', adiudicat^ and estimati essent felones, and proinde sustinerent penas
mortis, and forisfact' terrar^ and bonorum, vt in casu feloniae iuxta ordinem
communium legum huius regni, Et super examin^ eroum sieve alicuius eoru^,
triarentur in com^, ac per inhabitants illius com^, velloci, vbi ipsi vel ipse
apprehenderentur, sieve caperentur, and minime per medietatem linguae, and
amitterent libertatem and priuilegium Sanctuarij and cleri, prout in eodem
statuto before apparet. Quidam tamen M. P. and P. R. de etc. seipsos
appellantes Egyptianos, statut^ praedict' minime ponderantes, nec penam etc.
qui primo die Aprilis, anno etc. in hoc regnum Angl' transportat^ and conueiat^
fueru^t, ab eodem primo die Aug' anno etc. supradicto, vsque decimum diem Sept^
extu^c prox' sequen^ apud C. in praed' com^ E. continuauerunt and remanserunt
in eodem, otiosas vitas suas no^ relinquentes, nec seipsos in seruitio alicuius
habilis and honesti sub diti huius Angl' collocare q^rentes, neque seipsos in
aliquo opere licito sieve occupation^ honesta exercentes, in dn^ae Reginae nunc
conte^ptum, ac contra formam statuti praed' etc.

Against Egyptians upon the statute of 5. of the Queen.
IVr^ presentant etc. quod cum in statuto in parliamento dominae Reginae Sect.
102.
nunc apud Westmonasterium in com^ Middel', xiij. die Ianuarij, Anno regni sui
quinto tent^, edita inter alia etc. quod omnes and singula persona and person
que ab, and post primum diem Maij, tunc proxim^ sequent^ vise vel inuente
forent infra hoc Reg' Angliae sieve Walliae in aliquo commercio vel consortio
vacabundorum vulgo vocat^, sieve seipsos appellan^ Egyptianos vel seipsos
simulantes transmutantes sieve fucantes Anglic' disguising per eorum vestitum,
locutionem, aut aliam gesturam consimiles huiusmodi vagabundis communiter
appellat^ vel seipsos appellantibus Egyptianos, and sic facerent, continuarent,
and remanerent in eisdem, aut semel, vel sepe, per spacium vnius mensis, quod
tunc eade^ persona sieve person virtute huius actus estimate forent and
adiudicarentur felo and felones, and proinde sufferent penas mortis, ac
amissionem terrarum and bonorum, vt in easibus feloniae, secundum ordinem
communium legum huius regni. Et super eorum sieve alicuius eorum examinat^ in
hac part triarentur in comit^ ac per inhabitants comitatus vel loci, vbi ille
vel illi apprehenderent^ sieve caperentur, and non per medietat^ lingue, and
amitterent priuilegium and beneficium sanctuarij, and cleri, prout in eodem
statuto plene liquet. Quidem tamen A. B. C. D. etc. statutum praedictum minime
ponderantes nec penam in eodem content^ verentes, prost praed' primum diem Maij
scz. 3. die Aug' anno regni dominae Reginae nunc 35. apud E. in comitatu
praedict', visi and inuenti fuerunt in commertio and consortio vagabundorum
vulgo vocat^ and seipsos vocantiu^ Egyptianos, ac seipsos simulantium,
transmutant^, and fucant^, per eorum vestitum, locutionem, and gesturam,
consimiles huiusmodi vagabundis qui vulgo vocantur Egiptiani, and sic fecerunt,
continuauerunr, and remanserunt ibidem, and alibi in eodem comit^, a praedicto
tertio die August' anno xxiij. supradicto vsque vicesimum diem Iulij tunc
proxim^ sequen^ in dictae dominae Reginae nunc contemptum, ac contra formam
statuti praedicti etc.

H. in comitatu H. et in quendam N. M. adtu^c et ibidem in pace dei et domini
Reg. existen^, insultum fecit, et ipsum verberauit, vulnerauit, ac quodam

linguam ipsius M. adtunc et ibid' felonice eruit and amputauit, contra pacem

dominae nostrae Elizabethae, Dei gratia, Angliae, Franciae, et Hyberniae
Reginae, fidei defensoris etc. Tricesimo quarto, apud C. praedict' in comitatu
K. praedict', pro suspicione cuiusdam felony (videlicet, vnius Equ^, coloris
albi, pretij xl. solid' felonice per eundem A. B. vt dicebatur, capti and
abducti) arrestatus est and captus, and coram T. F. vno Iusticiariorum dictae
dominae Reginae ad pacem in dicto comitatu conserundam assignatorum ductus, et
super inde postea, viz. dictis die anno, and loco, cui^am B. D. in comitatu K.
praedicto Yeoman, custodi Gaolae dictae dominae Reginae apud M. in dicto

legitimo modo deliberatus: prefatus tamen I. F. (tunc vicecomes) postea,
videlicet, septimo die dicti mensis Maij Anno supradicto, apud M. praed' in
comitatu K. pred', praefatum A. B. (ad tunc and ibidem in dictis gaola and

and ad largum ite volu^tarie, et felonice permisit, contra pacem dictae dominae
Reginae, Coronam, and dignitatem suam etc.

praedict', ibidem moratur^ quousque idem I. B. abinde secundum legem and
consuetud' regni Angl' deliberatus foret: Et si p^d' I. C. R. B. and R. M.
dicto viij. die Decem^, anno supradict' praef. I. B. apud C. p^d' in p^d'
comitatu E. in cor^ custod' virtute deliberac' p^d' sic existen^, ibid'
negligent^ a custod' sua ad largum ire and euadere permiser^, contra pacem
dictae dn^ae Reginae, coronam et dignitatem suas etc.

An indictment against a Coroner upon the statute of Anno 1. H. 8. for
extortio^ in taking of a fee for his view of the body of one slain per
infortunium.
IVrat^ pro dn^a Reg' praesentant, quod cum per statut^ in parliament^ Sect.
108.
dn^i H. nuper regis Angl' octani, Anno regni sui 1. ordinat^ est, and
stabilit^ existit, quod super requisitione^ Coronator^ fact' adveniend' and
inquirendum super visum corporis alicuius personae per infortuniu^ occisae,
mersae, seu aliter mortuae, Coronator p^d' diligenter faceret officium suu^
super visum corporis cuiuscunque talis personae, vel personarum, absque aliqua
re proinde capiend', sub pena quod quilibet Coronator, qui officio suo vt
praedict' est fungi recusauerit, vel rem aliquam ceperit pro functione officij
praed', super visum corporis alicuius personae mortuae per infortunium, pro
quolibet tempore xl. s. prout in statut^ praedict' before continetur. Quida^
tn^ W. B. de H. in com^ praed' gener^ 12. die Dec' etc. adtunc exist' vnus
coronator^ dictae Dn^ae Reginae in com^ E. praed', apud M. in com^ E. predict',
color officij sui pred' extors. and iniuriose cepit pro feodo suo 20. solid'
de quodam Roberto S. de B. in comitatu praedict' yeoman, pro executione officij
sui praedict^ super visum corporis cuiusdam Iohannis C. nuper de B. in com^ E.
Lab. qui apud B. pred' in comitatu E. pred' 4. die Octob' ann^ etc. per
infortun^ occis. fuit, in contempt^ dictae dn^ae Reg', ad grave damnum ipsius
R. S. and contra formam statuti praed', and diuersor^ alior^ statut^ inde edit^
and prouis.

110.

Ioha^nis M. fregit and intr^, and 6. tergora corij voc' 12. hides of green

An indictment against the register of an Archbishop, for his extortious taking
of more fees then he ought, for the probate of a testament.
IVratores pro Domina Regina praesentant, quod A. B. de C. in dicto Sect. 111.
com^ E. generosus, primo die mensis Aug' etc. (adtunc scriba, (sieve
Registarius) reuerendi in Christo patris, D. tunc permissione diuina E.
Archiepiscopi existens, apud M. in comitatu E. predict' color officij sui
praedicti, extorsiue ac iniuriose cepit de quodam I. S. de M. praedicta in
dicto comit^ E. Tanner, duos solidos legalis morietae Angl', pro feodo ipsius
A. B. pro scriptione probationis vnius testamenti cuiusdam R. N. (qui quidem R.
N. apud M. praedictam infra dioecesem dicti D. Archiepiscopi vicesimo quarto
die Iulij, Anno supradicto mortuus est) vbi reuera idem Testamentum tunc ibidem
allatum est ad dictum scribam (sieve Registrarium) per dictum I. S. in pergameno
scriptum: and vbi omnia bona, Iura, and credita dicti R. N. dicto tempore
dictae mortis suae no^ excedebant summam quinque librarum: and vbi etiam tota
dicta scriptio probationis testamenti praedicti per praefatum scribam (sieve
Registrarium) sic vt praefertur facta, non continebat in se qua draginta lineas
quarum quaeque linea erat december pollicium in longitudine: In magnam dicta
Dominae reginae contemptum, ac contra formam cuiusdam statuti in Parliamento
Domini Henrici nuper regis Angliae octaui tento, Anno regni sui vicesimo primo,
in huiusmodi casu prouisi ac editi.

An indictment against an Escheator, upon the statute of 33. H. 8. for sitting
and inquiring by color of his office, without writ, of lands holden of the
Queen, above the yearly value of five pounds.
IVratores etc. quod cum in statut^ in Parliament^ Domini H. nuper regis Sect.
112.
Angliae octaui apud Westminster Ann^ regni sui 33. etc. quod nullus eschetor
sederet tantum virtute officij sui pro inquisitione, de tenura, titulo, vel
valor aliquarum terrarum, tenementor^, sieve hereditament^, vbi eadem terr',
ten^ta, seu haereditament^, sint valoris 5. librar^ per annu^, vel supra, and
tent^ de domino rege, sine breui domini Regis sibi inde dirigend', sub pena
amittendi and foris faciendi pro quolibet tempore quo sederet and faceret
inquisitionem contra formam huius statuti, quinque libras, in qua secta etc.
prout etc. Quidam tamen R. B. statutum pred' etc. existen^ escheator Dominae
Reg' in comitatu E. predict^ tali die and anno, apud D. in pred' com^ E.
sedebat, tantum color officij sui ad inquirend' post mort^ cuiusd' A. E. de
tenura, titulo, and valor duorum mes. xl. acrar^ pasc', 30. acrarum prati, 50.
acrar^ pasturae, and 20. acrar^ bosci, cum pertinen^ in O. in com^ E. praed'
annui valoris december librarum and vltra, et tent^ de dn^a Regina, absque aliquo
breui ipsius domin^ sibi inde directo, in dictae Dominae Reginae contemptum,
and contra formam et prouisionem statuti praed' etc.

An inquisitio^ taken before a Coroner upon the view of the body of one which
had hanged himself in a leather girdle upon the bough of a tree.
INquisitio indentat^ capt^ apud N. in comitat^ pred' 13. die April' anno Sect.
113.
etc. 35. coram Iohanne N. gen^, vno Coronat^ dictae domin^ Reg' comitatus
pred', super visum corporis cuiusda^ H. W. de D. in com^ E. praed' Sho. ibid'
mortui ia cent^, per sacrament^ etc. qui dicunt super sacrament^ suu^, quod
p^d' H. 4. die Apr^, ann^ regni dictae dn^ae Reg' 35. supradicto, circa hor^ 4.
post meridiem eiusd' diei, deum prae oculis suis non habens, sed instigatione
diabolic' seduct' in quoda^ prato cuiusd' W. S. gen^ apud T. pred' com^ G. voc'
E. Meadow, adtunc and ibid' solus existens, cum vno cingulo corij, precij 1.
deanr^, quoth ipse adtunc and ibid' in manibus suis tenuit and vnum finem inde
circa collum suum adtunc and ibid' posuit, and circa ramu^ cuiusda^ arboris
salicis alter^ fine^ indeligauit and seipsum adtunc and ibid' voluntar^ and
felonice suspend', fuffocabat, and strangulabat. Et sicu lur^ p^d' dicunt super

voluntary and felonice, vt felo de se, seipsum murderauit, contra pacem dictae
dominae Reginae, ac quod idem B. nulla habuit bona seu catalla, terras neque
tenementa. In cuius rei testimonium tam praefat^ coronat^ quam iur^ predict',
praesent^ sigill' sua apposuer^, datum die, anno and loco supradictis.

Of Forcible entry upon the Statute of Anno 5. R. 2. for pulling up by the
roots of 100. pearches of quick set.
INquiratur pro Domina Regina etc. quod cum in Statuto in Pa^liamento Sect. 114.
Domini R. nuper Regis Angliae secund' post conquest' apud Westminster in com^
Middl', Anno regni sui 5. tent^, edit^, inter caerere ordi^at^ sit quod nullus
faceret ingressum in aliquam terram sieve teneme^ta, nisrin cas. vbi ingressus
datur per legem, and in illo casu, non manuforti, nec cum multitudine gentium,
sed licito et quieto modo tantum. Et si quis contrarium fecerit, and inde
debite conuict^ fuerit, per imprisonamen' corpor^ sui puniatur, and finem ad
voluntat^ domin^ Regis fac', prout in eodem statuto inter alia before
continetur. Quidam tamen T. H. de I. in comitatu E. praedict^ Y. etc. et alij
malefactores ignot^ etc. statutum praedict^ minime ponderant^ secundo die M.
etc. vi et armis viz. baculis, gladijs, falcastris, et bisurcis, in vnam
clausum I. C. Militis iacent^ apud Arrow. in comitat^ E. praedicto, in quodam
loco ibidem voc' A. super possessionem eiusdem I. C. Militis, vbi ingressus cis
aut eorum alicui non datur per legem, illicite ingressum fecerunt, and ce^tum
particas sepium viuar^, ipsius I. C. Militis, adtunc et ibide^ crescent^
eradicauer^, euulserunt, et spoliauerunt, in dictae dominae Reginae nunc
contemptum, and ad grave damnum ipsius I. C. Militis, et contra forma^ statuti
predict^ etc.

For forcible Entry upon the statue of An. 5. R. 2. for entering into a
message and expulsing of the owner thereof.
INquiratur pro domina Regina, quod cum instatuto in parliamento Sect. 115.
domini Rich' nuper reginae Angliae post conquestum 2. apud Westmonast' Anno
regni sui v. tent^, ordinat^ et stabilit^ existit, quod nulla persona extunc
faceret aliquem ingr^ in aliquas terras vel tenementa, nisi in cas. vbi
ingressus ei datur per legem, and in huiusmodi casu, non manufort^, nec cum
multitudine gentium, sed quieto et pacifico modo tantum. Et si aliqua persona
extunc de caetero in contratium faceret, et inde debito modo conuinceretur,
puniretur per imprisonament^ corporis sui, and vlterius finem et redemptionem
eidem domino Regi, ad voluntatem et placitum ipsius domini Regis faceret, prout
in eodem statuto inter alia before continetur. Sed quidam W. nuper de K. in
comitaut E. predict^ Husbandman, I. W. senior de E. in comitatu E. predict^
Husbandman, and I. W. nuper de E. predict^ in comitatu E. predict^ Laborer,
statut^ predict^ minime ponder^, nec paenam in eodem statuto contentam
aliqualiter verent^, sed illud potius contemnentes, xxiiij. die Ianuar^ etc.
apud S. in com^ E. predict^, in vnum mesuagium sieve tenement^ existens liber^
tenement^ cuiusdam I. H. illicite et manuforti ingress. fecerunt, vbi nec ipsis
nec eorum alicui huiusmodi ingressus datur per legem, ac ipsum I. H. inde
unjust expuler^, ipsumque I. sic inde expulsum, a predict^ xxiiij. die Ian.
Anno pred', vsque ad xxxj. diem eiusdem mensis tunc proxim^ sequent^, illicite
et manufort^ extratenuer^, in contemptum dictae dn^ae Reginae nunc, et grave
damnum ipsius I. et contra formam statuti pred', ac contra pacem dictae dominae
etc.

An indictment upon the Statute of Anno 8. H. 6. for entering with force into a
barn in the possession of the farmer thereof, and for keeping of the same with
force.
IVratores pro domina Regina nunc praesentant, quod cum in statuto Sect. 116.
in parliamento dn^i H. nuper Reg. Angl' sexti, apud Westminster in com^ Midd', Anno
regni sui 8. tent^, aedit^, inter caetera co^tinet^, quod si aliqua persona
sieve aliquae personae, de aliquibus terris seu ten^tis manufort^ expuls. seu
disseisit^ sit, vel pacifice expellatur, and postea manufort^ extra teneat^,
vel aliquod feoffament^ vel discontinuatio inde post talem ingressum ad ius
possessoris defraudand' and tollend' aliquo modo fiat, habeat in hac part pars
grauat^, versus talem disseisitor^ Assisam nouae disseisinae, vel breue de
transgres. Et si pars grauat^, per assisam vel per actionem transgressionis
recuperet, and per veredictum vel aliquo alio modo per debit^ legis formam
inueniat^, quod pars defenden^ in terr^ and tenement^ illa, vi ingressa fuit,
vel ea per vim post ingress. suum tenuit: recuperet quer^ da^na sua ad triplum,
versus talem defend', and vlterius idem defend' finem and redemption^ dicto
dn^o Reg. faceret, prout in statuto p^d' before continetur. Quidam tamen W. W.
nuper de W. in praedict' com^ E. Husband, and C. D. nuper de W. pred', in
praed' com^ E. Labourer, statutum pred' minime ponderant^, nec paenam in ^odem
statut^ co^tent^ aliqualiter verentes, xix. die Febr. Anno etc. in vnu^ horreum
apud W. praed' adtunc existen^ liberum tenement^ R. W. gener^, vi and armis,
viz. gladiis etc. manuforti and illicite super possessionem cuiusdam A. M. tunc
firmarij praed' W. horr^ praed' intrauerunt and ingressum fecerunt, and ipsum
A. vi and armis praed' ac manufort^ and illicite tunc inde expulerunt and
eiecerunt, and praef. R. W. inde unjust disseisiuerunt, et praef. R. W. sic
inde disseisitum a praed' xix. die Febr. Anno xv. supradicto, vsque diem
captionis huius Inquisitionis, de praed' horreo vi and armis praed', et
manuforti extra tenuer^, and adhuc extratenent, in contemptum dictae dn^ae Reg.
nunc, and ad grave damnum ipsius R. and contra pacem dictae dn^ae Reginae, ac,
contra formam statuti praed', vbi nullus eorum nec ipsi nec aliquis alius cuius
statum ipsi, aut aliquis eorum habuit aut habuerunt, infra tres annos proximos
ante ingressum suum praed', aliquid in dictis horreis etc. aut in aliqua inde
parcella habuit etc.

An inquisition upon the Statute of Anno 8. H. 6. wherein is found that one was
with force and arms expulsed out of the possession of a manor and lands.
INquisitio capta apud W. in com^ S. primo die I. anno regni dn^ae Elizab.
Sect. 117.
dei gratia etc. 35. coram R. W. Mil' F. G. arm^ R. F. Iustic' dictae dn^ae
reginae ad pacem in com^ praed' conseruand', necnon ad diuersa felon^,
transgress. and alia malefacta in eodem comitatu perpetrat^ audiend' and
terminand' assign^ per sacramentum xij. Iur^ exist' praesent^, qui dicunt super
eorum sacrament^ quod cum in statuto in parliame^to domini H. 6. nuper regis
Angl' apud W. anno regni sui octauo tent^ edit^, inter cetera contineatur quod
si aliqua persona de aliquibus terris vel tenementis manuforti expulsa sit vel
disseisita, vel pacifice expellatur, et postea manuforti extra teneatur, vel
aliud feoffamentum vel discont^ inde, post talem ingressum, ad ius possessoris
defraudand' seu tollend' aliquo modo fiat, habeat pars in hac parta grauata,
versus talem disseisitorem. Ass. noue disleisin^, vel breue de transgr^, Et si
pars grauata per Ass. vel per actionem transgr^ recuperet, and per veredictum,
vel alio modo, per debitam legis formam inueniatur, quod pars def. in terras
and tenement^ ill' vi ingressum fec', vel ea post ingressum suum, per vim
tenuerit, recuperet querens damna sua ad triplum versus defend', and vlterius
finem and redemptionem domino regifaciat, prout in statuto praedict' before
continetur. Quidam tamen I. S. nuper de A. in comitatu S. praedict' Yeoman, and
alij ad numerum vj. personarum Iur^ ignot^ statutum praedict' minime verent^,
ix. die Aug. Anno regni dominae nosttae Elizab. nunc Reginae A. 24. R. W.
armig' de manerio de G. cum pertinen^ in A. in comitatu praedict', and de
ducentis acris terrae, xx. acr^ prati, and centum acr^ pastur^, cum prrtinen^,
in A. praedict' in comitatu praed', vi and armis and manuforti, viz. gladijs,
baculis, and cultellis, propulerunt and disseisiuerunt, and ipsum six expulsum,
and diss. a praed' nono die A. Ann^ supradict' vsque diem captionis huius
inquisitionis, manuforti and vi and armis, praed' R. W. extra tenuerunt, cont^
pacem dictae dn^ae Reginae nunc, and contra formam statuti praed' in hoc casu
editi and prouisi.

For counterfaiting of a protection and putting to it the great seal, taken
from other old letters Pattents.
IVrat^ praes. quod R. D. nuper de H. in com^ H. Husbandman, and Sect. 118.
alij machinantes, quomodo populum domini regis nunc subtilissime poterint
decipere vel defraudare, and dominum regem, de his quae ad ipsum regem
pertinent, and regalia sua, vt de feod' magni sigilli and huiusmodi,
exhaeredare, and veram legem Angl', a toto tempore vsitatam and approbatam,
subuertere and adnullare, xvj. die Februar^ etc. apud T. in comitatu M.
deceptiue, falso and proditorie quasdam falsas literas patentes, ad
similitudinem script^ cancellar^ domini regis, contrafac', quasi essent literae
patentes, de protectionoe ipsius reg. sub nomine I. K. clerici hanaperij Domini
Regis, ac vnius clericorum Cancellariae praedict' script^, hunc tenorem
continent^, viz. H. dei gratia etc. reciting the Letters patents verbatim, Ac
cum ijdem R. B. and alij etc. dictas falsas literas patent^ sic vt premittit^,
controfecissent, non habentes magnum sigillum dn^i regis, deceptorie, falso,
and proditorie, machinant^, qualiter ipsi falsas and fictas literas patentes
huiusmodi subtilius poterant sigillare, and magnum sigillum dn^i regis
contrafacere, dict^ 16. die Februarij anno supradict' apud B. in com^ pred'
quoddam magnum sigillum dn^i regis, super quasd' patent^ ipsius dn^i regis
praeante pend', and debit^ impositum, acceperunt, assumentes sibi regiam
potestate^, and ipsum regem regali sua auctorit^ (quantu^ in eis fuit)
priuant^, adtunc and ibid' cum quoda^ cultello arripueru^t, et illud', dictis
falsis, fictis et co^trafactis literis patent^, decept^ et proditor^
apposuerunt, et annexerunt, et easdem literas sigillauer^, sigill' ill'
subtilit^ recludendo, quasi sic non fecissent, et sic magnum sigillum domini
regis ad tunc and ibidem prodit^ co^trafecer^, et cum praemissa sic fecissent,
dictas falsas et contrafact^ literas patentes, ac vt praed' sigillatas, 8. die
Mart^ etc. apud villam de S. in comitatu M. ac in diuersis locis eiusd' com^,
tanquam literas patent^ ipsius domini regis de protect^, deceptor^, falso, et
proditorie, publicauerunt, and diuersas pecuniaru^ summas, de diuersis ligeis
dn^i reg. receperunt, virtute dictar^ falsarum fictarum and contrafactarum
literarum patent^, in deception^ dn^i regis, ac populi sui preiudic', et
exheredationem manifestam etc.

An indictment against a minister upon the Statute of Anno 5. H. 8. for
forgeing of an indenture of bargain and sail of lands.
INquitatur pro domina regina, quod cum in statuto in parliamento Sect. 119.
domini H. 8. nuper regis Angl' apud Westminster anno regni sui quint^, tent^,
aedit^, etc. quod si aliqua persona sieve personae quaecunque post primum diem
Iunij tunc proxim^ sequentem, ex sua propria mente and imaginatione, seu per
falsam conspirationem et fraudem, cum alijs, scienter, subtiliter, et falso
fabricaret sieve faceret, sieve subtiliter causaret, seu scienter consentiret
fabricari, sieve fieri, aliquod falsum factum, chartam, seu scriptum sigillatum,
Rotul' curiae, aut testamentum alicuius personae, sieve personarum in scriptis,
ea intention, quod status liberi tenementi, seu haereditatis alicuius
personae, sieve personar^ de, in, aut ad aliqua terras, tenementa, seu
haereditamenta liberae, tenurae, aut customar^, vel rectum, titulus, sieve
interesse, alicuius personae, sieve personarum, de, in vel ad eadem, sieve
aliquod eorum, molestari, perturbari, destrui, recuperari, vel onerari,
poterit, aut contingeret, aut post praed' primu^ die^ Iunij pronunciaret,
publicaret, seu ostenderet in euidentiam, aliquod tale falsum and effictum
factum, cartam, scriptum, Rotul' curiae, aut testamentu^, tanquam vera, sciens
eadem facta falsa ac ficta (vt praefertur) ad intentionem supramencionat^, and
inde foret conuictus, aut super aliqua^ actionem sieve actiones fabricandi falsa
facta, super hoc statut^ fundand' ad sectam partis grauatae, vel aliter,
secundum ordinem and debit^ cursum legum huius Regni Angl', aut super billam
vel informationem in Curiam camerae Stell' exhibend', iuxta ordinem and vsum
Curiae ill': solueret parti grauatae, custagia and damna sua ad duplum,
inueniend' seu assidend', in curia vbi huiusmodi conuictio foret: ac etiam
statueretur super collistrigium in aliqua aperta villa mercatoria, aut alio
loco aperto, and ibide^ haberet ambas aures suas absciscas, ac nares suas
interscissas and in parts diuisas, and ferro igneo cauterisatas, sic quod
remanere possent pro perpetua nota and signo falsitatis sue, and foresfaceret
dominae Regin^ heredibus and successoribus suis integr^ exitus and proficua
terrarum and teuementorum suorum durante vita sua, ac etiam sufferret and
haberet perpetuum imprisonamentum durante vita ipsius, praedictis damnis and
custagijs recuperand' ad sectam partis grauatae (vt prefertur) primo solnendis
and leuandis de bonis et catallis offendentis, and de exitibus and proficuis
dictarum terrarum, tenementorum, and hereditamentor^ huiusmodi partis
conuictae, aut vnius seu vtriusque eorum praed' titulo dict' dominae Reginae
hered' vel successorum suorum ad eadem, non obstante, prout in eodem statuto
inter alia before liquet. Quidam tame^ T. M. de C. in praedict' com^ E.
Clericus, statutum praed' non ponderans, nec paenam in eodem contentam verens,
post praed' primum diem Iunij, scilicet etc. apud T. in praedict' comitatu E.
exsua propriamente and falsa imaginatione, conspiratione, et couina, quoddam
falsum factum, viz. quand' Indenturam, per quam quidam T. A. barganizaret and
venderet omnes illas terras and tenementa vocat^ etc. cum pertin^ in T. in
praed' comitatu E. cuidam I. S. scient^, subtilit^, and falso fabricauit et
fecit, and eandem Inde^turam tunc et ibidem pronunciauit, publicauit, and
legifecit, and in euide^tiam ostendit, ad molestand', destruendum, and
perturbandum statum, possessionem, titulum and interesse praed' T. B. in terris
and tenementis predict, per quod idem T. B. de possessione, titulo, et
interesse suis, ad tenementa praedict' cum pertinentijs multipliciter
pregrauat^ and vexat^ existit, in dictae dominae Reg' legisque sue contemptum
manifestum, and ipsius T. dampnum non modicum and grauamen, ac contra formam
statuti praedict' etc.

For forestalling the Market, and buying Saltfishe by the way in coming to the
Market.
INquiratur pro domina Regina quod cum R. N. de ciuitate N. in comitatu Sect'
120.
ciuit^ N. mercator possessionatus fuit de mill salsament^ vt de suis bonis
proprijs, si I. T. de ciuitate N. praed' Fishmonger, tertio die etc. apud N.
praed' in com^ praedict' ciuit^ N. and diverse. alijs diebus tam antea quam
post, praefat^ R. N. tunc and ibidem obuiand' cum dictis mill salsament^ in
mercat^ ciuitat^ praedict' in comitatu praed' venditur^ praed' mill salfament^
de praeef. R. N. adtunc and ibidem extra mercatum ill' emit and forstallauit,
per quod, praed' R. N. praedict' mill salsament^ ad mercat^ p^d^ non adduxit
in contempt^ dn^ae Reg', ac contra formam diuersor^ statut^ in hm^di casu edit^
and prouis, ac contra pacem dictae dn^ae Reginae.

Blacksmith, apud quendam locum vocatum le Ferrie (in C. predicta in Comitatu E.

and praetij quatuor librarum legalis monetae Angliae, cuidam A. D. generoso
(natione homine Scoto) pro summa quatuor librarum in pecunijs numeratis
praedicto A. B. per prefatu^ A. D. tunc ibidem solutis voluntary vendidit. Ac
tunc and ibidem, cundem equmn eidem A. D. ca intention ad equum praedictum in
regnu^ Scotiae abdueendum and conueiandum (absque aliqua speciali licentia
dictae dominae Reginae nostrae nunc, per literas suas patentes sub magno
