lawfully take the issues and profits thereof by force of the same letters
patents, or that any other thing etc. All which matters the said defendant
etc. And prays that it may be ordered by this ho. Court, that the said
complainant may quietly enjoy the lands and tenements mentioned in the said
bill of complaint, without let, suit, vexation, or impediment of the said
defendant, or of his heirs, or any other person or persons by his or their
consent, aid, title, or procurement.

A Supplication exhibited by a Scot to the privy Counsel (his suit being
commended to the Queen by letters from the King of Scots) robbed by Pirates
upon the Sea, who desires a Commission to examine witnesses to prove the
Piraci^.
To the Right Ho. the Lords and others of her Majesty's honorable privy
Counsel.
MOst humbly beseeches your good Lo. your distressed Suppliant Sect. 182.
G. P. of the town of Leth in Scotland, being lately robbed and spoiled by
certain english pirates upon the seas of all his goods to the value of 400. l.
or there abouts, as by certain proceedings in the court of y^ Admiraltie
plainly appears, and for that this cause has bin commended to her Majesty
by the king of Scots his letters, your Lo. poor suppliant therefore hops the
rather to be relieved in any of his reasonable and conscionable suits and
requests at your ho. hands. It may therefore please your good Lo. to tender and
pity the case of your said Suppliant, and to grant unto him your ho. letters
of Commission to be directed to the Mayor of the town of H. in the County of
P. and others Justices of peace and Aldermen of the said town, giving them
Authority thereby to call before them the persons whose names be subscribed,
and upon their corporal oaths to examine the^ upon such questions or
interrogatories as upon your said suppliants behalf shall be ministered unto
them, and to certify their sayings and depositions touching the premises unto
your good Lo. under their hands and seals, with all convenient speed they
may. And your good Lo. poor suppliant shall daily pray to God for the
preservation of your good Lo. in all health and honor long to continue.

The indorsement of the Supplication.
13. Decembr^. 1600.
The humble petition of G. P. of Leth in Scotland.

And then endorse the contents of the petition.


the witnesses.
A. B. C. D. E. F.


A Supplication by two maimed soldiers, to have the Counsels license to beg,
or to have some maintenance allowed them for the^ present stay and relief,
until two Alms roumes which the Queen gave in reuercion do become void.
To the Right Ho. the Lords etc.
Humbly show and beseech your good Lo. your very poor and Sect. 183.
humble Suppliants A. G. and B. C. That whereas in consideration of the sundry
maymes and hurts of your ho. Suppliants in her Majesty's service, it pleased
her highness of her most gracious disposition and pitiful consideration of
us, to give and bestow upon us the reuercion of two several Alms rooms in
the Hospital of D. in the City of London during our lives when the same shall
become void, the which be yet full, and after their deaths which now be in
the possession of the same diverse reuercions are granted to several persons
of the same, by reason whereof your Lo. poor Suppliants are never likely to
enjoy the same roumes for their relief and sustenance. In consideration
whereof, and for that your ho. said suppliants be in very poor and weak
estate by reason of their said maymes and hurts, and greatly indebted to
diverse persons, being charged with wives and many children, not having any
thing now left them to maintain, help, or relieve themselves withal in this
their great poverty and extremities, but are ready to perish for lack of
sustenaunce and other means, It may therefore please your good Lo. the
premises being by your ho. tenderly considered, to grant unto your Lo. poor
Suppliants for their present stay, relief and comfort, your Honors license
for the taking and receiving of the Alms, and charitable benevolence of the
well disposed persons throughout the whole Realm, until the said Alms
roumes shall become void, or some other provision or maintenance for the
relief of their present necessity, such as to your Honors shall seem meet
and conueuient may be had and made, and your said poor Suppliants according to
their bounden duties will pray to God for your good Lordships in all health and
honor long to continue.

A Supplication by a Merchant stranger, who having been before called into
question for cosening of one in a barter of Pearl for Cloth, who desires the
same may be examined and ended by Aldermen of London, and other assistants of
skill and judgment: And that if they cannot agree, then the Lord Mayor of
London to be vmpier betwixt them, or else that the same may receive a trial in
any Court of Justice within the realm, and that in the mean time his liberty
may not be impeached.
To the Right Honorable the Lords etc.
IN all humblenes beseeches your honorable good Lordship I. C. of Sect'. 184.
the City of London Merchaunt stranger. That whereas R. S. of the same City
Merchant taylour has sundry times complained unto your Honor that the said
Suppliant had cosened him in delivering pearls for 185. pound, which were not
worth 20. pound, in consideration of a barter of cloth delivered to your
Lordships Suppliant, whereupon it pleased your Lordship to grant your warrant
for the bringing of the said Suppliant and his aged father before your good
Lordship to answer to the said supposed cosenage objected against them, which
they have already in some sort answered, according to the shortness of the
time. But for as much as for the full and plain discovery of the said
pretended cosenage, wherewith your Lordships said Suppliant is charged by the
said R. S. it seems requisite that the whole proceedings in the said barter
or contract were thoroughly examined by some Aldermen of the City of London,
calling unto them for their assistance therein two of the Dutch Church, of
sufficient judgment and skill in such cases to be indifferently nominated by
your said Suppliant and the said R. S. It may therefore please your good
Lordship to give full power and authority by your Honors letters to Alderman
S. and E. D. one of the Dutch Church chosen by your said Suppliant (if so it
may stand with the liking of your good Lordship) being of judgment and skill,
and very wise and discreet men, and to an other Alderman of the said City,
and any other of the said Dutch Church to be likewise nominated and appointed
by the said R. S. who may examine and try out the truth of the said supposed
cosenage: And that it may also please your good Lordship that the Lord Mayor of
the said City of London may be by your Honor nominated and appointed to be
vmpier in the said cause for the final ending thereof, if it should so happen
and fall out that the said four persons should not fully end the same cause
betwixt the said parties touching the said supposed cosenage, to the which
arbitrament and vmpiradge your said Suppliant will willingly submit himself
to stand unto and perform. And if the said cause can not by the said
arbitrators or vmpiers receive a full and final end through the wilfulnes or
frowardnes of the said R. S. according to the charitable and honest intent and
purpose of your Lordships said Suppliant. Then your said Suppliant humbly
beseeches your Honor that it may be ordered by your good Lordship that the
said cause may receive a short, speedy, upright, and indifferent trial at
the Common law in what Court in shall please your good Lordship to appoint.
And for that your said Suppliant doubts least by the practice of the said R.
S. his liberty may be impeached before the said supposed cosenage may be
fully tried and ended, the petitioner therefore humbly beseeches your good
Lo. that by your Lo. order his poor aged father may be protected and defended
from arrests or other trouble or molestation, until the said cause shall
receive a full and final end, and your said Suppliant shall daily pray to God
for etc.

A Supplication by an Inkeeper imprisoned for treason upon counterfaite letters
from the privy Counsel, who being thereof afterward discharged by letters
from the Counsel, had several accions of det laid upon him before his
enlargement. And afterward was from thence removed to the Fleet, and there
remaining for his det, prays that he may complain of abuses offered to him,
and to detect others of offenses and misdemeanors by them committed. And also
to write letters to the Commissioners for prisoners for det in the Fleet, to
compound all causes betwixt him and his creditors.
To the Right Ho. the Lords etc.
HUmbly shows and complains unto your good Lo. your poor Sect. 185.
suppliant and daily Orator I. W. of N. now prisoner in y^ Fleet. That where
about the month of September last past in the 32. year of her Majesty's
reign, one W. P. brought to the said town of N. certain counterfeit letters
under the names of the Lo. Chancellor, Lord Treasuror, and others of her Ma.
most honorable privy Counsel, with commandment to I. B. then Mayor of the
said town of N. by virtue of the said letters, to apprehend and take your said
suppliant upon suspicion of treason, and to commit him to close prison, with
beauy irons to be laid upon him, the which the said Mayor executed acordingly,
where your said suppliant so continued by the space of 5. weeks. And your
suppliant being so imprisoned, required the said Mayor that the said W. P.
might be stayed, for that he in the same year had counterfaited certain other
letters under diverse of your Lo. hands, but the said Mayor refused to stay him
because he came with your Lo. letters to him (as he supposed) so the said W. P.
departed, leaving your said suppliant in close prison. Whereupon your said
poor suppliant sent one to aquaint your ho. with his poor distressed case,
for redress and relief from your good Lo. therein, who thereupon received
your honorable letters in your suppliants behalf, directed unto the said now
Mayor of the said town of N. for his enlargement of his said imprisonment. But
your Lo. said letters notwithstanding, your poor suppliant was not set at
liberty, but detained in prison by the space of 8. days after your Lo.
letters were delivered unto the said Mayor, by means whereof there was one
execution for det, and diverse other Accions of debt laid upon him to the utter
undoing of him, his wife, and 8. poor children, your suppliant being a poor
Inholder in the sa^^ town of N. and having no other trade of living or means
to maintain himself and his poor family, by reason of which said untrue
slander of suspicion of Treason, and of his long imprisonment of seven months
or more, he has lost all his accustomes guests being many, which used to come
to his said house. May it therefore please your good Lo. the premises being by
your Honors tenderly considered, and for that your said poor suppliant upon
his remove to the prison of the Fleet, entered into bond to appear before
your good Lo. at what time soever it should please your Ho. to appoint im so to
do, to admit your said suppliant to complain before your Ho. of diverse wrongs
and abuses offered and done unto your poor suppliant, as also to discover and
detect y^ said W. and some others his confederates of very lewd parts and
offenses committed by the^: And also y^ it will please your Ho. to grant your
letters to ye Commisioners for poor prisoners for debt in the Fleet, for y^
speedy compounding and ending of all causes betwixt your said suppliant and his
creditors, and your said suppliant as he is most bounden shall daily pray for
your Ho. good Lordship in health and in honor long to continue.

A Supplication containing that upon a former supplication the Counsels letters
were directed to a knight and others of the country where both the parties
dwelled to hear and end a cause being a matter of account, whereupon the
knight and the others first wrote their letters to the parties and they not
coming before them, upon their letters they did thereupon by virtue of the
Counsels said letters send their precept unto them commanding them to appear
before them for ending of the said cause, who refused to come before the^, the
which his contempt was by the said knight etc. certified to the Counsel
against them. And now the petitioner prays the Counsels warrant to bring the
parties before the said knight etc. for the ending of the said cause, and if
the said parties wilfully refuse to stand to and obey their order, then to
commit them to the Jail, there to remain until they will be contented to
obey and perform the same.
To the Right Honorable the Lords etc.
HUmbly shows unto your good Lo. your humble suppliant N. Sect. 186.
C. Clothier, that whereas upon a former petition exhibited unto your good Lo.
declaring the injurious, unconscionable, and sinister dealings of one T. N. and
I. his son, touching a matter of debt and account, which was by your said
suppliant fully satisfied: Yet continued they suite against your said
suppliant for the space of seven years together only of purpose and malice to
the end to molest, trouble, and impouerish your said suppliant, as by diverse
certificates then to your Ho. by your said suppliant showed did fully and at
large appear, as also the lewd and evil conversation and demeanor of ye said
I. N. duly certified unto your good Lo. by the town of C. in the County of S.
under the common Seal of the same town: whereupon it pleased your good L. to
direct your honorable letters unto Sir G. T. of A. in the said County of S.
knight, and others, to call before them the said T. N. and all other persons
whom that matter did in any wise concern, and that upon due hearing and
examination of witnesses upon both parts to be produced to proceed to the
final ending and determining thereof according to equity and conscience, and
thereupon the said Commissioners according to your Lo. said letters of
Commission sent first their letters, requiring them to come before them for the
ending of the said cause: and for that they did not appear before them upon
their said letters, they then addressed unto the^ their precept, requiring and
commanding them and every of them by virtue of your Honors said letters of
Commission to them directed, to come and appear before them for the ending of
the said cause, both which letters and precept were delivered by one A. B. unto
the said T. N. who was the principal molestor and troubler of your suppliant
in these causes, who albeit he had received the said letters and precept, yet
that notwithstanding he would not appear before the said Commissioners, but
contemptuously by his letters to the Commisioners refused to appear before
them either upon the said letters or the precept from the said Commissioners,
as by a Certificate from the said Commissioners ready to be showed unto your
good Lo. may appear, to the great derogation and contempt of your good
Lordships. May in therefore please your Ho. for the bridling and checking of
such dissolute, froward, and wilful obstinacy, to the terrifying of such like
disobedient persons, to grant unto your said suppliant your Lo. warrant to be
directed unto the Sheriff of the said County of S. to bring the said T. N.
before the said Commissioners at such day, hour, and place, as by letters from
the said Commissioners to the said Sheriff shall be assigned or appointed: And
that if the said T. N. being so brought before the said Commissioners shall
wilfully refuse to o bay and perform such order, end, and determination, as
the said Commissioners shall think good to set down therein: That the said
Commissioners may have full power and Aucthority to commit the said T. N. to
the Jail within the said County, there to remain until he will yield to
perform and obey the order and determination of the said Commssioners, or that
your good Lo. shall give order and direction for his delivery out of prison.
And your said Suppliant shall daily pray for the preservation of your good
Lordships in all felicity and happiness long to continue.

A Supplication by one for himself and for eight other prisoners endicted of
murder in Wales (wrongfullie as they pretend) containing a former Supplication,
whereupon the Counsel ordered that they should receive their trials upon the
said Indictmens of life and death in the County of Salop, and not in the
County of M. where they were indicted, praying that they might be bayled, for
that he was a freeholder of good worth, and able to put in good suertie, that
the Counsel would be pleased to give order by their letters to the Lo.
President and Counsel in the marches of Wales for the bayling of them.
To the Right Ho. the Lords etc.
MOst humbly enformeth your good Lo. your humble suppliant and Sect. 187.
daily Orator E. D. of the County of C. for himself and 8. others, now
prisoners in the Jail of M. for a supposed murdering of one M. G. who died
about Pentecost last past: That whereas upon some sudden heat of words
bariance happening to grow between the same M. G. and your said suppliant L. in
the said County of C. upon the 28. day of May last past, about the having up of
a writ of Capias, with a fee formerlie given for the executing of the same
writ, at which time by hard hap a stander by giving a light blow to the said
M. G. with a stone upon the head, whereof he never languished so much as one
hour in outward appearance, neither did his Surgeon conceive any danger to
be therein, but the said M. G. traveled afterward without show of grief
from place to place about his affairs into foreign countries, using all
exercises and disports of pleasure, and afterward upon the 10. day of June
through sickness died in the said County of M. In which County of M. by favor
of the kindred and allies of the said M. G. your suppliant and 11. others were
uniustly endicted for y^ death of the said M. G. as for murder although there
were no manner of malice betwixt your Lo. said suppliant and the said M. G.
before the said hurt of him y^ said M. G. but great good will and liking
betwixt the^. For the same night that the said M. G. was hurt as is aforesaid,
he had appointed to lie at your Lo. said suppliants house, whereupon your good
Lo. said suppliant being an humble suitor to your Ho. for redress of the said
hard measure, it pleased your good Lo. in your very honorable consideration by
order from your Lo. to appoint the trial of your said suppliant, and the other
8. endicted persons at the Assizes to be holden for the said County of Salop,
as a place more indifferent and fit for the same, and yet nevertheless your said
poor suppliand and the rest remain in prison and cannot be bayled, and albeit
very good and sufficient bail have bin by your Lo. supplliant diverse times
offered not only for himself, but also for the rest of the people, being
endicted and imprisoned. And for that your ho. said suppliant is a freeholder,
of credit and worth well able to find very good and sufficient surety for his
own bail and his said people to appear and answer to the said indictment
against them before the Qu. Majesty's Justices of Assise for the said County
of Salop, at y^ next assizes to be holden within the said County of S^lop for
the said County. It may therefore please your good Lo. of your accustomed care
and commiseration of poor afflicted persons for their reliefes, to give such
order and direction by your honors letters to be directed to the Lo. President
and Counsel of the Marches of Wales, that your Lo. said Suppliant and his
poor people may not only receive their said trial upon the said indictment in
the said County of Salop according to your good Lo. former order and directions
therein, but also that they may be presently bayled upon good and sufficient
sureties to be of them taken by the said Lo. President and Counsel for their
personal appearance before the said Justices of Assise for the said County of
Salop at the said next Assizes to be holden before them for the same County,
then and there to answer to the said endictment, and to receive therein
according to law and justice: And your said poor Suppliant shall pray unto
God for the long preservation of your good Lordship in health and much honor
long to continue.

A Supplication to have the Counsels letters to two Bayliffes of a Town, to
take upon them the hearing of a controversy of an Account, or else to appoint
other two to do the same, and that they two to appoint an vmpier to end the
matter. And if the said vmpier cannot end it, then to certify the Counsel of
the state of the matter, and their opinions thereof, and in whom they conceive
the fault to be.
To the Right Honorable the Lords etc.
IN most humble and lamentable manner shows unto your honorable Sect'. 188.
Lordships your poor Suppliant A. B. of C. in the County of N. Merchant. That
whereas there are diverse matters of Account in question and controversy
between your said poor suppliant, and one H. B. of N. which will ask and
require some long time and great charges to be prosecuted and determined by the
due course of the common laws of the realm, the which would turn to the
utter undoing of your said suppliand, because he is now ready with his Ship to
depart toward the Straights, and therefore very uncertain of his return. It
may therefore please your good Lo. to grant your Ho. letters to be directed
unto the two Bayliffes of great Yarmouth, either to hear the said Account
betwixt them, or else to appoint two other indifferent persons to hear the
same and that those two may of themselves appoint an vmpier to end and
determine the said controversies, unto the which if the said H. B. or your Ho.
said Suppliant will not yield unto, that then they may certify unto your good
Lo. the state of the said controversies betwixt them, with their opinions
therein, and in whom they conceive the fault to be. And your said poor
Suppliant shall be bound during his life to pray for your good Lo. increase of
honor, and perpetual felicity.

A Supplication of H. K. and E. M. being prisoners in the Fleet for
misdemeanors sentensed in the Star chamber to be enlarged of their imprisonment.
To the Right Ho. the L. Keeper of the great seal of England.
THe Suppliants in Michaelmas Term last were sentensed for a Sect'. 189.


A Supplication of a prisoner in the Fleet for misdemeanors censured in the
Star chamber to be enlarged of his imprisonment, and to have the benefit of a
general pardon, and to be discharged of one of his fines imposed upon him.
To the Right Ho. Sir T. E. Knight, Lord keeper of the great seal of England.
IN all humblenes H. A. a very poor aged man of 70. years old and Sect. 190.
C. D. according to an order therein taken: And also to order and appoint the
said C. D. to pay your said suppliants prison charges, having been drawn into
that action by the said C. D. otherwise your Lo. poor suppliant is utterly
undone for ever, and shall never be able to procure his liberty, but of force
must perish in prison: And your said poor suppliant and his poor wife and
children shall daily pray for your Lo. good and honorable estate in all health
and happiness long to continue.

A Supplication of a prisoner in the Fleet for a misdemeanour censured in the
Star chamber to have the benefit of a general pardon, and to be discharged
of his imprisonment and fine, and that in respect of his very poor estate his
prison charges may be paid and discharged by one A. B. by whose means the
Suppliant was drawn into the action.
To the Right Ho. Sir T. E. Knight, Lord keeper of the great seal of England.
YOur Ho. very poor Suppliant H. M. being a very poor old man Sect'. 191.


The end of Bills and Answers etc.
HItherto of Bills, Answers, Replications, Reioinders, etc. and such

The manner of proceeding upon a special Certiorari.
THe party grieved exhibiteth his bill, and by the same prays not Sect. 192.
Certiorari, but also a Subp. against the def. to answer to his bill, as
appears by the last two bills. And if the Lord Chauncelor, Lord Keeper, or
Master of the Rols shall see good and probable matter in the bill, they
usually grant the same, taking bond of the plaintiff for the proof of the
surmises of his bill, within fourteen days after the return of his
special Certiorari, which writ of Certiorari follows in haec verba.

Elizabeth Dei gratia Angliae, Franciae, and Hyberniae, Regina, fidei
Maiori and Vicecomitibus London salutem,
volentes certis de causis certiorari super causa captionis and detentionis R.
S. in prisona sub custodia vestra, vos praefati vicecomites detenti vt dicitur,
vobis mandamus, quod causam praedictam cum omnibus eam tangentibus quocunque
nomine idem R. in causa illa censeatur nobis in Cancellariam nostram in
quindena pasche prox. futur^, vbicunque tunc fuerit, sub sigillis vestris
distinct and aperte mittatis, and hoc breue

test etc.
And if the pl. do not make proof of the surmise of his bill as aforesaid,
Procedendo is granted of course. But if there be witnesses examined, then to
have their examinations referred to a Master of the Chancery.

And if he find and so certify, that the plaintiff has proved the substance
Procedendo to proceed for the remuanding of the said cause.

A Corpus cum causa to remove a Prisoner.
REgina etc. Maiori and Vicecomitibus Lond' salutem. Mandamus Sect. 193.
vobis, quod R. S. quocunque nomine censeat^ captum and in prisona sub custodia
vestra vos praefat^ Vicecomit^ detent^, vt dicitur, habeatis coram nobis in
Cancellar^ nostra tali die proxim^ futur^, vbicunque tunc fuerit, vna cum causa
captionis and detentionis ipsius R. in prisona praedict'. Et hoc nullatenus
omittat^. Et habeatis ibi hoc breue. Test etc.

This writ is granted by the L. Chauncelor, L. Keeper, or Master de die in
diem, or further time, as the Court shall think fit, whereby many of her
Majesty's subjects are very much relieved in hard and extreme causes, lying
often times in prison upon great actions surmised against them, without just
cause, and thereby not able to put in such bail, as the common Law does
require in such cases.

Of a writ of Diem clausit extremum.
THis writ is to be sued forth by the heir of the kings Tenant in Sect'. 194.
33. H. 8. cap. 22. The form of which writ insueth.

Rex Eschaetori in comit^ Eb. salutem. Quia I. qui de nobis tenuit in

But if one that holds of the Queens ward by knights service die, the Diem
clausit etc. must be thus:

Regina dilecto etc. Quia I. de S. qui de haered' W. de O. defunct', vt supra.

And if the Queens ward, Thus:
Regina etc. Quia R. de H. filius and haeres I. de H. defuncti, qui de etc.
inquiras, quae terrae and quae ten^ta per mortem praedic^ I. and ratione
minoris aetatis haered' praedict^ I. ad manus nr^as deuener^, and sic in manu
nostr^ existunt, and quantum inde de nobistenetur in capite, and quantum de
alijs, and per quod seruitium, and quantum etc.

But if the wife of the Queens tenant which holds in Dower dye, his Heir
being the Queens ward, then the Diem clausit extremum must be made thus:

Rex dilecto sibi N. de B. Maiori ciuitatis suae London, and Eschaetori

If the Queen have the wardship of a reuersion, and the tenant for life die,
then thus.

Quia A. quasdam terras and quaedam tenementa de haered' E. consanguinei

After the death of the tenant by the Courtesy, thus.

Quia A. qui quasdam terras and quedam ten^ta de nobis tenuit per legem

But if the Queen have a remainder, and her tenant for life dies, then must
the Writ be thus.

Quia A. quae fuit vxor etc. qui quasdam terras and quaedam tenementa

But if the temporalties of a Bish. be in the Queens hands, and one that
holds of the Bishopric by knights service dies, the Diem clausit extremum
must be thus.

Regina etc. Quia A. de Archiepiscopatu Cantuar^ vacant^ and in manu

But if the Queens Idiot die, the writ must be such.
Quia B. de C. nuper fatuus and Idiota, cuius terrae and ten^ta ratione
fatuitatis

Datur nobis intelligi.
ANd if the Eschea^or receive a Diem ciausit extremum, and die, Sect. 195.
or be otherwise removed from his office before execution thereof, then issues
a writ of Datur nobis intelligi in this form.

Regina etc. Cum nuper datur nobis intelligi quod I. de B. qui de vt supra,
Mutatis mutandis. Ac idem W. ab offic' praedict^ iam sit amotus, per quod
executio breuis nostri praedict^ fieri non potest: Nos super praemissis volent^
cerciorari: Tibi praecipimus, quod persacramentum etc. diligenter super
praemiss* facias inquisitionem, and etiam distinct etc. T. etc.

Or thus.
Regina dilecto etc. Cum nuper datur nobis intelligi, quod I. de B. vt in primo
breui. Ac idem H. antequam praedict^ breue fuerat executum, ab officio
praedict^ fuerat amotus: Nos volentes super praemissis before cerciorari, ^ibi
praecipimus, quod super articulis praedict' and eorum singulis diligenter
facias inquisic', and eam distinct and aperte fact' etc. vt supra etc.

But if the first Escheator execute the writ, and die before the inquisition

Of a Mandamus.
IF the Kings tenant by Knights service die, his heir within age, and Sect.
196.
no writ of Diem clausit extremum be awarded within a year after his death,
then shall issue a Mandamus in this form.

Rex dilecto sibi W. de B. Eschaetori suo in com^ B. Salutem. Praecipimus

THe heir shall have but one writ of Diem clausit extremum only Sect. 197.
within a year after his auncesters death: But where thancester died ward to
the Queen and within age, for then a new Diem clausit extremum shall be a
warded a year after the Infants death, and not a Mandamus, per Regist. fol.

Of Commissions after the death of the Queens tenant.
ALso the heir of the Kings tenant by Knights service in chief, Sect'. 198.
may sue forth a special Commission, directed to certain persons, to inquire
what lands etc. (as above in a Diem clausit extremum,) which Commission will he
as beneficial for the heir, as a Diem clausit extremum: For upon Inquisition
taken by such a Commission, retornable into the Chauncerie, ^e may have Liuerie
at his full age. But he shall never have Liuerie upon a general Commission to
inquire of all Wards etc.

Quae plura.
THis writ lies when any of the Heirs lands be omitted in a former Sect. 199.
office or inquisition, to find the lands so omitted, and is such.

Rex Eschaetori suo etc. salutem. Quia datum est nobis intelligi

Melius inquirendum.
THis writ lies where an office found by virtue of a Diem clausit Sect. 200.
extremum or Commission is uncertain in the tenure, value, or tenants estate
of the lands, or otherwise. But if such incertaine office be found before the
Escheator ratione officij only, then it is void, and no Melius inquirendum
shall thereupon be awarded. And the Melius inquirendum is such.

Rex Escheatori suo etc. Salutem. Cum per quandam inquisitionem

And this writ is grauntable upon surmise made in the court, that

Another Melius inquirend' post inquisitionem imperfectam.
Rex eschaetori suo etc. Cum per inquisitionem coram te de mandato

A Writ de aetate probanda.
IT behooves the heir of the Queens tenant in chief being in ward, Sect. 201.
at his full age, and before livery, to have a writ to the Escheator of the
County where he was borne, to prove his age. And it seems, that such writ
may as well be made to the Escheator of the County where his land lies, for
it may be he was borne where the Kings writ runs not: as in Ireland, Calice.
Berwike, etc.

Rex dilecto sibi I. de B. Eschaetori suo in com^ B. salutem. Quia A. de ipsius
M. and quorum vna pars in manu nostra, and alia pars i^ custodia I. de H. ex
commissione dicti aui nostri vsque ad legitimam aetatem haered' eiusdem
existunt sibi reddend', per quod volumus, quod eadem M. quae apud G. in comit^
M. nata est, and in Ecclesia eiusdem villae, baptizat^ fuit vt dicitur, aetatem
suam probet coram te. Tibi praecipimus, quod ad certum diem and locum, quos ad
hoc prouideris, probationem illam per sacrament^, tam milit^ quam probor^ and
legalium hominum de balliua tua, per quos probatio illa capi, and veritas
aetatis p^d* melius sciri poterit and inquiri, capias, and sc. fa. praef. I.
quod tunc sit ibi ad ostendend' si quid pro se habeat vel dicere sciat quare
praed' H. and p^d' M. vt illi qui plenae aetatis est, si plene aetatis sit,
terras and tenementa praed' reddere non debeamus, and probationem illam sic
captam nobis sub sigillo tuo, and sigillis eorum per quos capta fuerit, sine
dilatione mittas, and hoc breue. Test etc.

Another form of the writ De Aetate probanda.
REx etc. Quia M. de F. filius and haeres I. defuncti, qui de nobis tenuit vt
supra.

But if the King commit the Wardship, the Aetate probanda must mention the same.

And if the Wardship by reason of the temporalities of a Bishopric be in the
Queens hands, the writ de Aetate probanda must mention the same: And yet that
is no Court in capite.

Commission pro aetate probanda.
Regina dilectis etc. Sciatis quod assignauimus vos ad inquirend' per

And upon this Commission a writ shall be sent to the Shirife to return

A Venire facias to the Shirife upon the same Commission.
REgina Vicecomit^ etc. Praecipimus tibi, quod summon^ per bonos Sect. 202


Whereby appears that the committee of the King shall be warned to be there.
But if the King have the Ward in his own hands, then this clause Et scire
facias E. and S. custodibus etc. shall be omitted in the writ.

Of Homage done or respited.
WHen a writ de Aetate probanda is executed and returned, and Sect. 203.
that the heir has proved his age, then he must do homage, or agree with the
Queen to respect the same, and pay relief before livery sued: and a writ
testifying homage to be done, when the heir is at full age at the death of his
ancestors.

Regina Eschaetor^ etc. Sciatis quod cepimus homagium I. de H. filij

But if the heir were in ward, and has proved his age, the writ of the homage
received must be thus.

Regina etc. Quia N. de E. fil' and haeres R. de C. defuncti, qui de domino te
sufficienter probauit, sicut per probationem de mandato nostro captam, and in
Cancellar^ nostram retornat^, est compertum, ceperimus homagium ipsius N. de
omnibus terris and tenem^tis quae idem R. pater suus tenuit de dicto auo nostro
in capite, die quo obijt, and ei terras and tenementa illa reddidimus. Ideo
tibi p^cipimus, quod eidem N. de omnibus terris and tenementis praedict' de
quibus praedict' R. pater suus fuit seisitus in dominico suo vt de feodo in
balliua tua die quo obijt, and per mortem eiusdem R. in manum dicti aui nostri
capta fuer^, and in manu nostr^ sic capta existunt, plenam seisinam habere
facias, saluo iure cuiuslibet. Test etc.

Diem claufit extremum post mortem felonis.
WHen the King has the lands of the Wife, by reason that her Sect. 204.
Husband was outlawed for felony, then after the Husbands death the Diem
clausit extremum is such.

Quia A. cuius terrae and tenem^ta, que ipse tenuit de iure and haereditate

Nihil simul and natum and perfectum.
W. WEST.

FINIS.
